fields.headline: Bungling officials on the carpet
fields.trailText: The officials who oversaw the farcical end to Saturday's FA Cup tie between Tranmere and Sunderland have been accused of breaching referees' regulations and will become the first to face a Football Association commission.
fields.body:
The officials who oversaw the farcical end to Saturday's FA Cup tie between Tranmere and Sunderland have been accused of breaching referees' regulations and will become the first to face a Football Association commission.

After reviewing reports from both clubs and the match officials the FA said yesterday that Rob Harris, who refereed the fourth-round tie which Tranmere won 1-0, had "less than proficiently applied the laws of the game" by allowing Tranmere to replace a player who had been sent off.

The fourth official David Unsworth and the assistant referee Tony Green are alleged to have committed technical irregularities in connection with the substitution.

Tranmere's Stephen Frail was introduced after Clint Hill had been dismissed but no other Tranmere player left the pitch. Subsequently a Sunderland free-kick was taken while Tranmere had 11 players on the pitch, before the error was spotted and Andy Parkinson was taken off. The FA decided on Monday that the match would not have to be replayed.

The three officials have 14 days to respond to the allegations and request a personal hearing before a commission of the FA referees' committee.

The FA has again demonstrated its willingness to use video evidence to punish players by handing Wimbledon's Ben Thatcher a two-match ban for elbowing the Sunderland midfielder Nicky Summerbee.

Thatcher pleaded guilty after being charged with misconduct over the incident which the referee Graham Poll failed to spot during Wimbledon's 1-0 victory at Selhurst Park 10 days ago.

Already this season Middlesbrough's Brian Deane and the Leicester defender Matt Elliott have been handed one-match bans for misuse of the elbow after the FA used video evidence against them.

Tottenham's Sol Campbell could face a new inquiry into an alleged fracas with a steward at Derby last season. The defender was charged with assault last April after Tottenham's 1-0 win in October 1998 but the case was discontinued last July. Police files have now been given to the FA who will judge whether Campbell must face a disrepute charge.

Michael Owen could play for Liverpool against Watford on Saturday after he was told by the sports injury specialist Dr Hans Müller Wohlfahrt that there was no damage to either his left or right hamstring.

Leeds will face Asia's player of the year Hidetoshi Nakata in their Uefa Cup fourth-round tie against Roma in March after the Serie A club yesterday completed the signing of the Japanese midfielder from Perugia in a £10m deal.

Belgian state police are threatening to strike during Euro 2000 unless new staff regulations are agreed before the finals start on June 10.

webTitle: And in the red and raw corner it's 'Killer' MacKenzie

fields.headline: And in the red and raw corner it's 'Killer' MacKenzie
fields.trailText: For those who savour sporting competition as raw, rough and basic, the announcement of a head-to-head between the BBC's Radio 5 Live and Talk Sport could be an ongoing contest to relish.
fields.body:
For those who savour sporting competition as raw, rough and basic, the announcement of a head-to-head between the BBC's Radio 5 Live and Talk Sport - the suddenly reconstructed Talk Radio - could be an ongoing contest to relish and help jolly us through the millennium's first few years.

It has all the elements. The establishment versus the upstart: a sort of Gentleman Jim Corbett v "I'll moider any bum in the house" John L Sullivan. For in this case the challenger, red and raw in tooth and claw, is that all-action crowd-pleaser, Kelvin "The Kentish Killer" MacKenzie.

The BBC's traditionally pretty and languidly time-honoured footwork could be not only rumbled but rushed into no end of dangerous corners.

Someone of the same ilk and family background has already been giving BBC's television cousins a nasty beating up for some time now. Except for a black eye or two, BBC radio has survived pretty well so far. But now the rude, ripe and ribald eminence of the Sun for more than a dozen years of over-the-top and topless everything between 1981 and 1994 - from Botham's Ashes to Taylor's turnip head, if you like - has declared his first British radio station dedicated to 24-hour sports coverage to be at all-out war with the BBC.

The only surprise is that a serious challenge to Radio 5 Live has not come sooner - and from a more sober-sided City establishment, too.

Since MacKenzie left the Sun his famous Fleet Street flair has been much less luminous than his reputation. He did not last long at Sky and his L!ve TV was a dud in spite, or because, of topless darts and weather forecasts in Norwegian.

In his first year at Talk Radio, which began broadcasting only in November 1998, his "revamp" lost 17% of the original audience. But that turn-around did not take in the ball-by-ball coverage of the England cricket team's Test matches this winter in South Africa. That coup seriously bloody-nosed BBC radio - which still cannot find a happy and contented home for its Test Match Special - however much the corporation has pretended otherwise.

And coming hard on Channel 4's serious capture of the home cricket Tests on television, the double-whammy painfully showed the vulnerability of the BBC against any channel able to turn its schedules into a single-subject concentration.

And with Mark Nicholas and his hairstyle fronting both radio and television, home and away, it has to be said that the coverage of both has been easily up to, and sometimes better than, the set-in-stone BBC standards - except, of course, for those ruddy adverts.

It was one thing last summer to have an England collapse interrupted 12 times between six wickets by the very same and indecipherable motor car ad, and it has been just as bad this winter when every wicket-fall has meant another mumbled exhortation, this time for Regus Offices Worldwide.

MacKenzie's first job, at 17, was as a cub reporter on the Kentish Mercury in 1963. After a couple of days he turned to his fellow apprentice Pat Collins and said he had sussed it. "It's obvious," he said, "this whole place is full of wankers, except you and me."

Obviously, and merrily, he still feels the same about any established order, certainly that at the BBC. He picks up the prizefighter's analogy: "The BBC enjoy taking taxpayers' money, then appropriating to themselves some kind of genius by knocking me out of the ring. But the BBC is like royalty. Their time is past but nobody has told the old dears."

How the Beeb must have winced when fledgling Talk Radio announced itself at the first Test in South Africa - those first 17 balls with England two runs to the good, four wickets to the bad. It was a dramatic baptism if ever there was one. The BBC's Test Match Special at once sacked their oldies Fred and Trevor.

MacKenzie has also got the wavelength (1089 MW) loud and clear, which to my mind is his absolutely crucial bonus. Far better than Long Wave - and Radio 4 where TMS uncomfortably survives - where many still spend their time cursing and re-tuning.

Radio 5 Live's £5m Premier League contract lasts until next year. Talk Sport has Gary Newbon under contract. The bidding war starts here.

fields.headline: United put their shirts on £30m
fields.trailText: Manchester United may have missed out on the £4m first prize in Brazil but they could be £30m better off when they arrive home from the World Club Championships tomorrow. They are reportedly poised to sign the biggest shirt sponsorship deal in history.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Manchester United may have missed out on the £4m first prize here but they could be £30m better off when they arrive home from the World Club Championships tomorrow. They are reportedly poised to sign the biggest shirt sponsorship deal in history.

United are said to be close to concluding a four-year agreement with the Middle Eastern airline Emirates worth £30m. That is almost quadruple the £2m a year they receive from Sharp, whose deal ends in May.

Emirates, which flies from Manchester, is keen to exploit the club's worldwide popularity. It is said to have bartered them down from £34m but clearly it holds the club in higher esteem than Vasco da Gama's chairman, Eurico Miranda, who was damning in his assessment of the treble-winners yesterday.

"We would not want any of Manchester United's players," he said. "They were a disappointment in these championships, on the sort of stage when you should be judged. People like David Beckham and Ryan Giggs have a high profile but they would not get into our team." The Brazilian public have been disappointed by United but Miranda may regret his words if United accept his club's challenge of a game at Old Trafford.

Without doubt it is the Premiership and the Champions League which will occupy the United manager's thoughts now. Domestic results have gone well in his absence and most of his first team will have had two weeks' rest before facing Arsenal on January 24. "Jet lag and tiredness won't be a problem," said Gary Neville. "We could never have expected it to go so well back home," added Andy Cole. "Now we have to go home and win the Premiership."

Meanwhile Ronaldo, who is in Brazil, has expressed his desire to move to the Premiership. The Internazionale striker, who is recovering from injury, said: "My dream is to play in British football. I am starting to learn English as a way to prepare for the future."

Nicolas Anelka, who could not wait to get away from British football, has been ruled out for two months after an operation on his right knee. The Real Madrid striker suffered the injury during Monday's victory over Raja Casablanca.

webTitle: England against plan for home nations' revival

fields.headline: England against plan for home nations' revival
fields.standfirst: FA worry over Uefa move to swap friendlies for regional tournaments
fields.trailText: England are to oppose strongly a Uefa proposal to scrap friendlies and reintroduce the home internationals as an annual mini-tournament.
fields.body:
England are to oppose strongly a Uefa proposal to scrap friendlies and reintroduce the home internationals as an annual mini-tournament.

Uefa has suggested staging regional competitions over a period of around two weeks every year. The home nations, for example, could be grouped to include the Republic of Ireland, with the teams playing each other once and the venue changing annually.

That would mark the end of friendlies, a scenario Kevin Keegan can be expected to greet with dismay. In the lead-up to Euro 2000 England's schedule includes matches against Argentina, Brazil and Croatia. Tactically, competitively and climatically the new proposal seems far from ideal.

Wales and Northern Ireland are weak opposition and the five teams play a broadly similar style. Before any major tournament or a qualifying competition England would prefer to sample the style of football that lies ahead. The Football Association is certainly less than enthusiastic.

"We believe the world is getting smaller and we take a more global view than just looking across our own borders," said the FA's executive director David Davies. Under the Uefa proposal, he added, "our matches with Argentina and Brazil would probably not be taking place. In terms of playing Scotland the interest on all sides generated over those last two matches leads me to believe we will play them more in the next decade than we did in the last.

"But we want to develop relationships worldwide and the events of the last 10 days [at the World Club Championship in Brazil] illustrate the importance of getting that right. We are not short of opposition throughout the world. People always want to play England."

However, Scotland's coach Craig Brown supported the plan. The traditionally competitive edge of home internationals appeared to influence his thinking. "It's a good idea," he said. "I would rather play England and the other home nations than play friendlies. The fans proved at Wembley and Hampden Park that they would like to see the games played more often. I'm sure the Irish and the Welsh will be very much in favour."

The Uefa proposal may be well received generally. A cross-border championship involving Holland, Belgium and France, for instance, might seem an attractive proposition. The Premiership clubs would also prefer to lose their players for a set period rather than on an ad hoc basis.

None of this will placate England. "We've been talking about the calendar and the place of international football within it with Uefa since last year and we are still working on it with them," Davies said.

"Our view is there needs to be a balance from which we can all go forward. I'm not sure where you are going to find room for extra games in the calendar."

Better news for the FA is that Sepp Blatter will today withdraw his public support for South Africa's 2006 World Cup bid. Fifa's president is conscious of the need to be neutral in the run-up to July's decision.

Blatter spent more than an hour with FA officials and leading members of England's 2006 campaign at a reception in Rio de Janeiro on Sunday night. But, although his public stance is positive for England's chances, privately little will change. He still wants the tournament to be staged in Africa if the continent is ready.

webTitle: Donald poised to quit Test scene

fields.headline: Donald poised to quit Test scene
fields.trailText: Allan Donald hinted yesterday that he may announce his retirement from Test cricket during the final match against England.
fields.body:
Allan Donald hinted yesterday that he may announce his retirement from Test cricket during the final match against England.

The 33-year-old fast bowler ranked No2 in the world, is still a tantalising 10 wickets away from achieving his ambition of taking 300 Test wickets, is expected to make an announcement on Sunday.

"There is a lot of talking and convincing to be done before I come to a decision, although I know what I want to do," he said.

If Donald does retire from Tests he is expected to return to Warwickshire under his former national coach Bob Woolmer. He will discuss his future with South Africa's selectors over the next few days.

Of his desire to become the first South African to take 300 Test wickets, Donald said: "It would be fantastic to do that in this Test and that would definitely give me more options."

Donald is believed to be unenthusiastic about next month's tour of India, where the combination of flat tracks and Sachin Tendulkar's batting genius pose daunting tests for any bowler.

He has captured 290 wickets in 60 Tests since South Africa's return in 1992 and it would be fitting for him to bow out against England, whose batsmen he has regularly terrorised and against whom he has forged a legendary rivalry with Mike Atherton.

His captain Hansie Cronje is keen for Donald to carry on, but said: "This stage of his career is the time which is the most lucrative and that may influence his decision... But only Allan will know when the time is right."

 A heavier police presence will attend one-day internationals in Australia after fans hurling bottles forced the Australia-India match in Melbourne to be halted for 17 minutes. Indian supporters were angered by the run out of Saurav Ganguly for 100. He was given out by the third umpire because he failed to ground his bat.

 John Emburey, 47, the former Test off-spinner, has been appointed Berkshire's player-coach.

fields.headline: Adams stares into the abyss
fields.standfirst: Will England give their attacking, new batsman one last chance?
fields.trailText: This series has not been the success story Chris Adams would have liked. So will England give their attacking, new batsman one last chance, asks Mike Selvey.
fields.body:
"Welcome," sneered the South African wicketkeeper Mark Boucher as Chris Adams arrived at the crease for his second innings in Cape Town, "welcome to the end of your Test career."

These sort of things get said all the time in Test matches and are shrugged off as a bit of quid pro quo, but even such a positive thinker as Adams must have wondered if Boucher was not right.

Tomorrow at Centurion, when the captains exchange their teams for the final Test, we shall know. Will Adams be the first in the reshuffle to be handed his Test match cards and money, or will he survive to sup in the last-chance saloon?

This series has not been the success story he would have liked. He has been playing against one of the top bowling sides, of course, and baptisms do not come more white hot than his at the Wanderers when, batting at No6, he found himself facing his first ball in Tests in only the third over of the match with Allan Donald on a hat-trick.

He made 16 there, with one in the second innings, but with luck - a commodity in short supply for England in that match - he might have made a deal more. Since then, though, in the excellent batting conditions at Port Elizabeth, Durban and Cape Town, he has made starts and failed to capitalise: 25 and one at St George's Park; 19 in the only innings at Kingsmead; 10 and 31 at Newlands.

The rumbustious nature of the Adams batting philosophy and the rigorous examination that is Test cricket at the cutting edge have not so far made contented bedfellows. Judge me, he says, on the whole tour rather than part of it. But he knows his future is on the line.

Adams feels he may have underestimated the chasm between the demands of county cricket and those at Test level, undone not by lack of temperament - an absence of "the right stuff" - but by a tech nique exposed by the almost military discipline of the opposing attack.

"There is no person yet I have met involved in the game who I believe can prepare anyone for the enormous jump to international cricket," he said yesterday. "It is something you have to experience for yourself and is so hard to explain.

"Only if you had been playing for three months against Donald, Shaun Pollock and Jacques Kallis would you understand what that jump is. It is more than just bowlers running up, it's the build-up, the interviews, the inner feelings, the family phoning to wish you well and then phoning again to share the disappointment, all the sort of things that don't happen in county cricket."

Temperamentally, he says, he has coped well, feeling "comfortable" in the middle. Instead it is technique that has let him down, he believes, something which, unlike temperament, can be worked on.

"The South Africans are just so disciplined," Adams said. "They have a plan, one for every England batsman, and they stick to it through thick and thin. They obviously saw me as a batsman who likes to play a lot of shots, score runs with a quick tempo.

"So their strategy for me has been perfectly simple: force me back, give me no drive balls and then, when the ball gets soft, bowl a foot-and-a-half outside off-stump, saying 'there you are then, if you want to score runs, make something out of that.'

"I don't feel uncomfortable with that but then they throw one up there and I haven't been in a position to put it away. The brain is saying 'half-volley, put it away' but the hands and feet are not in the right position, so you end up being vulnerable instead of scoring."

Maybe, though, the problem lies in the fact that he cannot - or more pertinently does not want to - recognise that another solution to disciplined bowling is disciplined batting; that on good pitches it becomes a mind game about who cracks first and that his technique is being exposed only because his discretion is letting him down.

The lesson, in other words, is to be selective, not reckless in the pursuit of how you think people want to see you play but thinking rather how you ought to play. Look at Nasser Hussain's great triumph of self-denial over instinct in Durban. Do you think, Adams was asked, that you will ever have the self-discipline to be able to bat like that?

"Ah well," he says, "that's probably the first innings in which Nasser has batted like that and how many Test matches has he played? If I am around in 50 Tests' time, then yes I think I will be able to bat like that."

For the moment, though, it may be best to concentrate on the morrow and no further. The stakes are high.

Will Adams be the first in the reshuffle to be handed his Test match cards and money, or will he survive to sup in the last-chance saloon? This series has not been the success story he would have liked. He has been playing against one of the top bowling sides, of course, and baptisms do not come more white hot than his at the Wanderers when, batting at No6, he found himself facing his first ball in Tests in only the third over of the match with Allan Donald on a hat-trick. He made 16 there, with one in the second innings, but with luck - a commodity in short supply for England in that match - he might have made a deal more. Since then, though, in the excellent batting conditions at Port Elizabeth, Durban and Cape Town, he has made starts and failed to capitalise: 25 and one at St George's Park; 19 in the only innings at Kingsmead; 10 and 31 at Newlands. The rumbustious nature of the Adams batting philosophy and the rigorous examination that is Test cricket at the cutting edge have not so far made contented bedfellows. Judge me, he says, on the whole tour rather than part of it. But he knows his future is on the line. Adams feels he may have underestimated the chasm between the demands of county cricket and those at Test level, undone not by lack of temperament - an absence of "the right stuff" - but by a tech nique exposed by the almost military discipline of the opposing attack. "There is no person yet I have met involved in the game who I believe can prepare anyone for the enormous jump to international cricket," he said yesterday. "It is something you have to experience for yourself and is so hard to explain. "Only if you had been playing for three months against Donald, Shaun Pollock and Jacques Kallis would you understand what that jump is. It is more than just bowlers running up, it's the build-up, the interviews, the inner feelings, the family phoning to wish you well and then phoning again to share the disappointment, all the sort of things that don't happen in county cricket." Temperamentally, he says, he has coped well, feeling "comfortable" in the middle. Instead it is technique that has let him down, he believes, something which, unlike temperament, can be worked on. "The South Africans are just so disciplined," Adams said. "They have a plan, one for every England batsman, and they stick to it through thick and thin. They obviously saw me as a batsman who likes to play a lot of shots, score runs with a quick tempo. "So their strategy for me has been perfectly simple: force me back, give me no drive balls and then, when the ball gets soft, bowl a foot-and-a-half outside off-stump, saying 'there you are then, if you want to score runs, make something out of that.' "I don't feel uncomfortable with that but then they throw one up there and I haven't been in a position to put it away. The brain is saying 'half-volley, put it away' but the hands and feet are not in the right position, so you end up being vulnerable instead of scoring." Maybe, though, the problem lies in the fact that he cannot - or more pertinently does not want to - recognise that another solution to disciplined bowling is disciplined batting; that on good pitches it becomes a mind game about who cracks first and that his technique is being exposed only because his discretion is letting him down. The lesson, in other words, is to be selective, not reckless in the pursuit of how you think people want to see you play but thinking rather how you ought to play. Look at Nasser Hussain's great triumph of self-denial over instinct in Durban. Do you think, Adams was asked, that you will ever have the self-discipline to be able to bat like that? "Ah well," he says, "that's probably the first innings in which Nasser has batted like that and how many Test matches has he played? If I am around in 50 Tests' time, then yes I think I will be able to bat like that." For the moment, though, it may be best to concentrate on the morrow and no further. The stakes are high.

fields.headline: Money money money
fields.standfirst: It's what makes Hollywood go round: Boyd Farrow gets a head for figures
fields.trailText: It's what makes Hollywood go round: Boyd Farrow gets a head for figures
fields.body:
Hollywood thrives on records being broken, and 1999 was another record-breaking year at the US box office, with ticket sales up a headline-grabbing 8% to $7.3bn. But this figure, like nearly everything else in Tinseltown, bears little relation to reality. While more than 350 films reached American screens last year, nearly 40% of the total box-office haul was accounted for by 17 blockbusters that each took in more than $100m. If that's not scary enough for the creative community, then how about this: three of the year's top-grossing four films - The Phantom Menace, Toy Story 2 and Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me - were sequels (or in Phantom's case, a prequel) and several others in the top 20 were either sequels, remakes or TV spin-offs.

But even high-grossing films do not mean soaring profits for the studios these days. According to the Motion Picture Association of America, which represents the Hollywood studios, while the average cost of producing a Hollywood film actually fell 1.4% to $52.7m in 1998, the cost of marketing and distributing movies in the US leaped 13% to $25.3m per picture. In other words, it now averages almost $80m to make and release a studio picture.

Even this does not reflect the whole story. Production costs would be still higher if it wasn't for the fact that major stars and 'name' directors are increasingly forgoing their upfront fees in return for a huge slice of the box-office spoils. For example, actor Tom Hanks and director Steven Spielberg might end up earning $80m between them from their cut of Saving Private Ryan's ticket sales and ancillary revenues. Spielberg and Tom Cruise will enjoy a similar profit-sharing package on their upcoming collaboration Minority Report. Meanwhile, Cruise could pocket $60m for his dual role as producer and star of Mission Impossible 2. So even if average production costs are stabilising, the profits going back to the studios are being greatly diminished.

Rising marketing costs reflect the fact that many of the 350-odd studio films released annually earn 40% of their total American box-office revenue during their opening weekend. If they fail to ignite the public, they're swiftly yanked off screens to make way for fresh product. This is why the studios have traditionally relied on a handful of big stars to 'open' a picture and why the salaries of those chosen few have skyrocketed in recent years.

In 1994, two days before the release of Ace Ventura: Pet Detective, Time Warner-owned New Line Cinema refused to pay the film's unknown lead Jim Carrey $1m to star in another project, Dumb & Dumber. But a fortnight is a long time in Hollywood. Two weeks later, with Ace Ventura a massive hit, the same studio were forced to pay the same star $7m to sign up to the same movie.

Over the next 12 months, competition for big names went berserk. In early 1996, struggling Columbia Pictures was so desperate for a hit it paid Carrey a record $20m to star in the black comedy The Cable Guy. Suddenly this was a no-questions-asked industry standard for the big guns of the acting profession.

Cut to three years later and not all the maths is adding up.

Anyone remember Random Hearts, the Harrison Ford vehicle directed by Sydney Pollack? Or Payback starring Mel Gibson? Or Message In A Bottle starring Kevin Costner. And don't even mention Wild Wild West to the studio. Fat fees for actors, it seems, doesn't automatically translate into fat returns at the box office.

One of the few ways producers can keep the stars' costs down is by offering them 'challenging' against-type roles in smaller films - the hope being that the prospect of winning awards will be as alluring as winnebagos with cable. So Bruce Willis gets to make Breakfast Of Champions, Carrey takes a big cut to make Man On The Moon, Denzel Washington signs on for Hurricane, Annette Bening turns down $4m for a Kevin Costner film in favour of American Beauty and Tom Cruise has a cameo in Magnolia. Brad Pitt - who was paid $17.5m for Fight Club - is receiving far less for British crime caper Snatch, while Leo DiCaprio took home $10m under his usual asking price for his starring role in The Beach.

It's not just movie costs that are chastening studios. The demographic shift in the film business is also giving them cause for concern. Currently, 20% of Americans account for 66% of the box-office, and the frequent movie-going group is increasingly dominated by what number-crunchers term "young adults". Nearly half of film-goers between the ages of 16 and 24 average at least one visit to the cinema per month, compared with just 22% of those aged 25-34, 16% of those aged 35-44 and 15% of those between 45 and 54.

Such figures may explain the 1999's glut of cheap and cheerful horror flicks, or the high-school makeovers of classic novels starring the teen idols of Dawson's Creek, Buffy The Vampire Slayer and Party Of Five. It's a win-win situation. Several of these films feature among Hollywood's most proportionately profitable films in years (hence the forthcoming Scream 3). And even if they fail to ignite the box office - take the cruelly underrated Cruel Intentions, their low production costs and cheap talent virtually guarantees them turning a profit.

The downside of this is that when stars rise, their demands are index-linked. This week Catherine Zeta-Jones was presented with her own production deal with a studio, while Ashley Judd was rewarded for Double Jeopardy with $4m for the romantic comedy Animal Husbandry. True, in a year's time this might look like a bargain. But no-one has forgotten how Alicia Silverstone went overnight from Clueless darling to Excess Baggage two years down the line. Nor that nearly every studio passed on Pulp Fiction, which starred the 'has-been' John Travolta, the unknown Samuel L. Jackson and the freefalling Bruce Willis.

Of course, while the Hollywood studios are walking a tightrope they all make use of that most reliable safety net of all - the sequel. This year alone promises the arrival of Mission Impossible 2, Nutty Professor 2, 102 Dalmations, Rugrats In Paris and a prequel to The Flintstones. Meanwhile two sequels to The Matrix are in pre-production - as is Jurassic Park 3 and Episode 2 of the Star Wars saga.

Oh, and there is also a sequel and a prequel being made to last year's most profitable film, The Blair Witch Project, which starred three unknown actors and was made for the kind of money that would barely cover the hairdressing budget of most of today's 'blockbusters'.

fields.headline: Tyson to enter Britain
fields.trailText: Boxer Mike Tyson will be allowed to enter the country, the home office announced early this evening.
fields.body:
Boxer Mike Tyson will be allowed to enter the country, the home office announced early this evening.

Home secretary Jack Straw said he was using special powers to instruct immigration officers to allow the convicted rapist into the country to take part in a bout at the end of the month.

He said: "In the special circumstances of this case, it would be invidious for an individual immigration officer to weigh the competing considerations involved.

"I have looked very carefully at the representations that have been submitted today to the Immigration Service by Mr Frank Warren and I consider that there are exceptional circumstances that justify my decision."

Frank Warren was delighted with the news.

"I take my hat off to the immigration department and the professional way they've dealt with it," he said.

"It's always boxing that gets it in the neck," Mr Warren added.

He said that other entertainers such as James Brown had entered the country without a passport but boxers were dogged by bad reputations.

He said: "We've got a great card up there. I really am pleased, because a lot of work went into securing the fight and bringing it over here."

Gary Mason, former heavy weight boxer, said: "It's the chance to see a great artist perform live."

He added that Britain had shown Tyson "respect" by offering him a second chance.

Tyson will arrive at Heathrow airport by Concorde on Sunday in time to prepare for a bout against British boxer Julius Francis in Manchester on January 29. He was convicted for raping a Miss Black America contestant in 1992 and was this morning on a list of UK "undesirables" who were barred from automatic entry to the country.

Mr Francis said: "People make mistakes, people change. I don't think that Mike Tyson should be punished every time he steps a foot sideways, frontways or backwards."

Mr Straw said he had been swayed by the potentially devastating effect on businesses depending on the boxing match.

He said: "I have taken full account of these representations and, in particular, of evidence presented to me in these representations and, of the effects on small providers of ancillary services, some of whom could be facing bankruptcy because they have invested heavily in the contest and are innocent third parties.

"I have also taken account of the effect on business in the Manchester area and of the inconvenience and disappointment of the many thousand members of the public who have purchased tickets for the fight in good faith if entry had been refused and the contest therefore cancelled," he added.

webTitle: Gas chamber claims impossible, says Irving

fields.headline: Gas chamber claims impossible, says Irving
fields.standfirst:
Libel action author denies that Holocaust was systematic
Simon Wiesenthal Center
The holocaust history project
fields.trailText: The author David Irving yesterday denied in the high court that the Nazis used gas chambers to murder millions of Jews during the second world war.
fields.body:
The author David Irving yesterday denied in the high court that the Nazis used gas chambers to murder millions of Jews during the second world war.

The alleged Nazi apologist is suing for libel over a book that called him a "Holocaust denier" and his claim came as he entered the witness box on the second day of the trial.

Mr Irving said it was logistically impossible for millions of people to have been gassed to death, and denied that the Holocaust had been "systematic" or ordered by the Third Reich's leadership.

He is taking legal action over a book, Denying the Holocaust: the Growing Assault on Truth and Memory, which he says ruined his career. Mr Irving is suing its author, the American academic Deborah Lipstadt, and her publisher, Penguin Books.

Questioned by Richard Rampton QC, for both Professor Lipstadt and Penguin, Mr Irving said he believed that the Nazis had killed between one and four million Jews during the second world war.

Asked by Mr Rampton: "Do you deny that the Nazis killed millions of Jews in gas chambers in purpose built establishments?", he replied: "Yes".

Mr Irving, who is representing himself, said: "I deny that millions died in the gas chambers because of the logistical problems for a start."

He said that a million people would weigh 100,000 tonnes and that the "logistical and architectural impossibilities" in constructing extermination camps could not be over looked.

Mr Rampton quoted from a transcript of a 1991 press conference Mr Irving gave, where the author said: "The biggest lie of the lot, the blood libel on the German people, is the lie that the Germans had factories of death in which they liquidated millions of their opponents."

Mr Irving conceded that he had cut the word Holocaust which had appeared in his 1977 biography of Hitler, for its second edition in 1991.

Mr Rampton quoted Mr Irving as saying about the revision of the book: "You won't find the Holocaust mentioned in one line, not even in a footnote, why should [you]. If something didn't happen, then you don't even dignify it with a footnote."

Mr Irving insisted that this passage referred only to the Holocaust via gas chambers. He said that he found the term Holocaust "offensive and unhelpful" and that it "should be avoided like the plague" because it was so imprecise.

Mr Irving accepted that his view about the non-existence of the gas chambers put him at odds with the public's view that they existed.

The author repeatedly denied the mass murder of Jews had been systematic, and said: "The defendants will find it very hard to prove it was a Third Reich decision and an Adolf Hitler decision. There were multiple shootings but it was not pursuant to any programme."

Mr Irving stood by this position despite being challenged by Mr Rampton, who said it was undermined by a 1942 report seen by Adolf Hitler detailing the massacre by one German unit of 363,211 Jews on the eastern front.

In August 1941 Hitler had ordered that he be kept informed of the activities of the unit, the Einsatzgruppen, a special SS death squad operating behind German lines.

Mr Irving described the document as "an orphan", saying there were no other reports of this nature which existed and were addressed to the fuhrer.

Three-and-a half hours in the witness box left Mr Irving looking tired.

Mr Irving said he had at first ignored Prof Lipstadt's book. But by 1996 he found its allegations had led to the ruination of his career. A US contract for a biography of Goebbels was terminated.

He said her book had exposed him to "a burden of hatred" that had led to him being attacked by a Jew shouting that he was a "Holocaust denier".

Mr Irving added that after the recent death of his disabled daughter, a wreath was sent in the name of the head of the Nazis' extermination programme of the disabled.

It emerged yesterday that Prof Lipstadt will not testify in her defence. But Mr Irving played a videotape of her on a 1994 Australian television programme, in which she said of revisionist historians: "They are the equivalent of people who believe the earth is flat, Elvis Presley is alive and well, or there was no slavery."

The trial, which is being heard before Mr Justice Gray without a jury, continues.

webTitle: Union takes mayoral vote row to court

fields.headline: Union takes mayoral vote row to court
fields.trailText: A high court judge will rule tomorrow on a voting rights dispute between the Labour party and one of its affiliated unions which could prove crucial in the race to become the party's candidate for mayor of London.
fields.body:
A high court judge will rule tomorrow on a voting rights dispute between the Labour party and one of its affiliated unions which could prove crucial in the race to become the party's candidate for mayor of London.

Six London members of the Manufacturing Science and Finance union today accused the party of acting unlawfully in barring the union from taking part in the electoral college vote for the mayoral candidate because its subscriptions to the party were paid late.

It is predicted that the majority of the MSF's 15,000 London region members would back Ken Livingstone, as would a substantial number from two other barred unions - the Rail Maritime and Transport, with 7,000 London members, and train drivers' union Aslef, with 3,000.

If those unions are reinstated to the voting process, the close race between Frank Dobson and Mr Livingstone could result in the nomination of the former Greater London Council leader.

Laura Cox QC, for the six MSF members, told Mr Justice Jonathan Parker that their union was affiliated nationally and regionally to the Labour party.

Under that affiliation, the six all paid a political levy to the union and they expected to be entitled to participate in the mayoral candidate selection process by voting in a ballot to decide who the MSF should support.

"We say they are being denied that right unlawfully and we seek a declaration to that effect," said Miss Cox.

The Labour party, she said, argued that the union was not qualified to vote because it was not fully paid-up at the designated cut-off date of December 31, 1998.

But the fact was that, however late the payment was made, it was accepted by the party and formed the basis of a binding agreement entitling the union to participate in the party's activities.

Gavin Millar, counsel for the Labour party, argued that the union members' case was "misconceived".

Labour's executive committee, he said, had quite properly decided last year to enfranchise only those organisations which were paid-up at the end of the last complete affiliation year - 1998.

There was nothing capricious or arbitrary in this - the same procedure was adopted in the selection of Parliamentary candidates.

The six union members are: Hugh McGrillen; Jim Mortimer (a former general secretary of the Labour party); his wife Pat Mortimer; Sue Michie; Glen Sutherland and Ian Rez.

The judge said he would give judgment at 10.30am tomorrow.

Under that affiliation, the six all paid a political levy to the union and they expected to be entitled to participate in the mayoral candidate selection process by voting in a ballot to decide who the MSF should support. "We say they are being denied that right unlawfully and we seek a declaration to that effect," said Miss Cox. The Labour party, she said, argued that the union was not qualified to vote because it was not fully paid-up at the designated cut-off date of December 31, 1998. But the fact was that, however late the payment was made, it was accepted by the party and formed the basis of a binding agreement entitling the union to participate in the party's activities. Gavin Millar, counsel for the Labour party, argued that the union members' case was "misconceived". Labour's executive committee, he said, had quite properly decided last year to enfranchise only those organisations which were paid-up at the end of the last complete affiliation year - 1998. There was nothing capricious or arbitrary in this - the same procedure was adopted in the selection of Parliamentary candidates. The six union members are: Hugh McGrillen; Jim Mortimer (a former general secretary of the Labour party); his wife Pat Mortimer; Sue Michie; Glen Sutherland and Ian Rez. The judge said he would give judgment at 10.30am tomorrow.

webTitle: Win tickets to The End of the Affair

fields.headline: Win tickets to The End of the Affair
fields.trailText: Win tickets to The End of the Affair
fields.body:
Directed by Oscar-winning Neil Jordan from the classic novel by Graham Greene, The End of the Affair is an intense love story played out in a London buckling under the Blitz.

Ralph Fiennes headlines as Greene's semi-autobiographical hero - picking over the bones of a doomed romance with the aid of Ian Hart's weaselly private-eye. Julianne Moore (Safe, Boogie Nights) co-stars as his enigmatic mistress, while Jordan-regular Stephen Rea provides a brilliantly lugubrious turn as a fusty civil-servant. Already nominated for four Golden Globes and hotly tipped as an Oscar contender, The End of the Affair follows in the footsteps of films like Brighton Rock and Our Man in Havana. It's another Greene screen triumph.

webTitle: Irving denies deliberately portraying Hitler as 'merciful'

fields.headline: Irving denies deliberately portraying Hitler as 'merciful'
fields.trailText: Controversial historian David Irving today rejected an accusation that he had deliberately tried to portray Adolf Hitler as "merciful".
fields.body:
Controversial historian David Irving today rejected an accusation that he had deliberately tried to portray Adolf Hitler as "merciful".

On the third day of his high court libel action over a claim that he is a "Holocaust denier", the 62-year-old author dismissed an allegation that he had deliberately "mis-translated" documentary evidence to achieve his exoneration of Hitler.

The accusations were put to him during cross-examination by Richard Rampton QC, counsel for American academic Deborah Lipstadt and Penguin Books, who deny libelling Mr Irving in Professor Lipstadt's 1994 book Denying the Holocaust: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory.

Mr Rampton told Mr Justice Gray, who is sitting without a jury in London, that Mr Irving had written in the introduction to his book Hitler's War that there was "incontrovertible evidence" that Hitler ordered on November 30, 1941 that there should be no liquidation of the Jews.

But this reference should have been to a particular trainload of about 1,000 Jews deported from Berlin to Riga, Latvia, in November 1941, Mr Rampton said. He accused Mr Irving, who is representing himself, of "deliberate mis-translation".

He said: "You inflated it from one trainload of Jews generally and you inserted an order from Hitler for which there was no evidence." Mr Irving, giving his evidence from the witness box, denied the allegation.

He agreed that he should have written "a liquidation of a transport of Jews", but stressed that there was not a "shred of evidence" of deliberate inflation on his part. As soon as the evidence had been brought to him that the reference was to a trainload, he changed it "to the narrower interpretation" in subsequent editions of his book.

His reference to an order from Hitler was a "commonsense" interpretation of the facts rather than a perverse one. He rejected Mr Rampton's suggestion that he had mis-translated the evidence "so as to make Hitler appear the more merciful".

Asked if he agreed he had been "caught out", Mr Irving replied: "Historians are constantly being caught out by fresh documents."

The defendants' case is that this subject is just one example which illustrates "disreputable methods" in Mr Irving's work.

Mr Irving says Professor Lipstadt's book alleges that he has denied the Holocaust and distorted statistics and documents to serve his own ideological purposes and reach historically untenable conclusions. He claims her book has generated "waves of hatred against him".

Mr Rampton referred Mr Irving to a document about the interrogation of Walter Bruns, which came into Mr Irving's hands before 1985, in which Bruns described his experience as a colonel in the German Army Engineers force in Riga, Latvia, in November 1941.

Bruns recounted that when he tried to prevent the shooting of 5,000 Jewish women and children, he was told by a 21-year-old SS officer, Altenmeyer, that they were to be killed "in accordance with the Fuhrer's orders" and shown the orders.

Bruns said that a few weeks later, the same officer showed him a just-issued order prohibiting future mass shootings on that scale. Bruns recalled the officer saying that they were to be carried out "more discreetly".

Mr Rampton said that the reference to the "Fuhrer's orders" had never appeared when the incident was alluded to in any of Mr Irving's books. "Absolutely true," he replied. "I discounted it."

He added that he was familiar with other instances when officers would say they were acting on Hitler's orders as a way of fending off criticism and shutting someone up. "There are no orders. They have not been found. We have now been in and out of the archives of the world for the last 55 years and no primary, secondary or tertiary evidence has been found of the existence of these orders.

"I concede that in interrogations in war crime trials, people are ready to talk about these orders but the fact remains that if there had been any such order, it would have surfaced by now."

Asked why he had not put these exchanges into his biography of Hitler, Mr Irving said that would have been descending into an inappropriate and boring level of textual analysis.

"I discounted it because other evidence shows that Adolf Hitler had not issued the order - it is not in the archives."

Mr Rampton said that this amounted to an "absence of evidence - a negative piece of evidence".

Later, Mr Irving told the court that "the German government has asked for my extradition to Germany on an alleged offence that I committed".

He referred to a press clipping, dated January 12, from a German newspaper about the extradition request and told Mr Justice Gray it was another "incidence of the kind of hatred I face and the problems I face because of the repugnant allegations against me".

Mr Irving is the author of Hitler's War and Goebbels: Mastermind of the Third Reich.

fields.headline: Gallant Fulham flunk shoot-out
fields.trailText: Leicester moved into the semi-finals with a resounding penalty shoot-out success last night after they had come from 2-0 behind in ordinary time and then from 3-2 in the extra period after Ian Marshall's second goal had neutralised Chris Coleman's 93rd-minute header.
fields.body:
Leicester moved into the semi-finals with a resounding penalty shoot-out success last night after they had come from 2-0 behind in ordinary time and then from 3-2 in the extra period after Ian Marshall's second goal had neutralised Chris Coleman's 93rd-minute header.

Penalty failures by Coleman, Paul Trollope and Geoff Horsfield saw the Premiership club enjoy a 3-0 triumph in the shoot-out.

When Horsfield had slipped the ball into an empty net to give Fulham a 2-0 lead with 15 minutes remaining, Paul Peschisolido having put them ahead just before the hour, a weakened Leicester side looked certain losers.

Then in the 85h minute Ian Marshall hooked the ball past Maik Taylor after Steve Walsh had headed on Stefan Oakes's cross and in the 87th Walsh himself drove in a fierce shot following Marshall's nod-down.

Leicester were again missing several injured or ineligible players, among them Tony Cottee, Muzzy Izzet, Darren Eadie and Steve Guppy. Fulham were lacking three important men - Barry Hayles, Lee Clark and Kevin Ball - but after five cup victories over Premiership opposition in a year the threat their brisk, imaginative passing game posed was still considerable.

Indeed the Nationwide side needed little time to find their rhythm, easily gaining possession through Leicester's poor, predictable distribution though not achieving sufficient penetration early on to disturb their big three at the back. Once Fulham began to move forward in any numbers, however, their precise movements began to unravel Leicester's cover, with Paul Peschisolido holding the ball up well.

O'Neill's team badly missed Izzet's ability to get hold of the ball and make things happen. Wayne Collins and Steve Hayward tended to show more imagination for Fulham in midfield while Steve Finnan quickly found opportunities to turn Leicester's defence on the right.

Finnan's pursuit of a ball which appeared to be running into touch produced the first serious scoring chance just past the quarter-hour. From his centre Chris Coleman produced a powerful header which was blocked by Gerry Taggart before it could trouble Pegguy Arphexad in the Leicester goal.

Leicester had to wait until the 27th minute before they created an opportunity of any significance. A lob from Stefan Oakes was nodded down to Heskey by Ian Marshall but before the striker could shoot Andy Melville whipped the ball off his toes.

Leicester's best hope of going ahead lay in upping the pace and disrupting Fulham's careful patterns. O'Neill's side tend to rely on well-worked set pieces for goals and Fulham were inclined to give away free-kicks in dangerous areas.

Such was the disorganisation behind him that Emile Heskey was increasingly likely to rely on individual improvisation to break through, although O'Neill did bring on Arnar Gunnlaugsson to give him Icelandic support. Support was certainly what Leicester needed once Fulham had scored three minutes before the hour.

Horsfield showed impressive control as he worked the ball into the penalty area from the right, laying it across and back for Peschisolido to beat Arphexad with a shot into the roof of the net.

A long cross from Robbie Savage found Heskey near the penalty spot but the striker's header was weak. Then a centre from Theo Zagorakis reached an unmarked Gunnlaugsson at the far post but he wafted the chance wide.

Leicester City (3-5-2): Arphexad; Elliott, Taggart, Walsh; Sinclair, Savage, Zagorakis (Gilchrist, 105), Oakes (Fenton, 120), Impey (Gunnlaugsson, 54min); Heskey, Marshall.

Fulham (3-5-2): Taylor; Melville, Symons ,Coleman; Finnan, Morgan, Collins, Hayward, Trollope; Horsfield, Peschisolido (Brevett, 79).

Referee : M. Reed (Birmingham).

webTitle: Hill start leaves Tranmere one step from Wembley

fields.headline: Hill start leaves Tranmere one step from Wembley
fields.trailText: After all the recriminations, the weekend histrionics and the trauma of the subsequent inquest, Tranmere Rovers returned to the land of footballing sanity last night to pencil in a coveted but improbable place in the Worthington Cup final with another fine example of their new-found prowess in knock-out competition.
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor at the Reebok Stadium
fields.body:
After all the recriminations, the weekend histrionics and the trauma of the subsequent inquest, Tranmere Rovers returned to the land of footballing sanity last night to pencil in a coveted but improbable place in the Worthington Cup final with another fine example of their new-found prowess in knock-out competition.

John Aldridge's admirable side possess too much inexperience for this to be written off as a foregone conclusion but, even if the Wembley suits are not being measured up just yet, Tranmere will commence the second leg of this semi-final having taken the initiative courtesy of a crucial away goal from Clint Hill.

The prospect of First Division representation in next month's final is hardly filling the organisers with undiluted joy at a time when the troubled competition is in chronic need of an image overhaul.

But who could deny that either of these two sides deserved their 15 minutes of fame? Altogether they have taken seven Premiership scalps already this season - one more than Sheffield Wednesday and Bradford City have managed between them in five months of League action.

If Aldridge harboured any lingering fears that his players would be threatened by an FA Cup-induced hangover following Saturday's fourth-round triumph over Sunderland, his concerns were quickly dispelled in an opening 45 minutes played at a frenetic pace.

Dave Challinor's immensely long throw-ins can no longer be classed as a secret weapon in Tranmere's armoury, but it remains a potent threat. One sling of his arm almost manufactured an early breakthrough when Hill rose unchallenged above a static home defence to flash a header against the outside of Steve Banks' right-hand post.

That served as a warning to Bolton and the next time Hill had a sight of goal his aim had improved. Once again Bolton's defenders were guilty of some amateurish ball watching and Tranmere benefited from a clinical set-piece manoeuvre.

Alan Morgan's corner enticed Banks to his near post, only for Gary Jones to get there first and flick the ball over the goalkeeper with a deft header. Hill was loitering inside the six-yard area and got the decisive touch despite the close proximity of several white shirts, and even more red faces.

Bolton's response was impressive. Traditionally a better side in attack than defence, they had struck the woodwork themselves when Michael Johansen arrowed a venomous drive past Tranmere's goalkeeper John Achterberg and against the right-hand post.

Again, however, Tranmere found it difficult to finish a cup tie without the slightest hint of a refereeing controversy. That duly arrived shortly after the hour when Banks inexplicably charged 25 yards off his goal-line and scythed down David Kelly in a misguided attempt to intercept a long through- ball.

Whereas Rob Harris had been left to carry the can following the FA Cup debacle, here it was Graham Barber who ruled to the surprise of everyone, not least Banks, that the offence merited only a yellow card.

Tranmere's players were al ready holding a grievance from a few minutes earlier when Andy Parkinson had gone down under the challenge of Franck Passi inside the penalty area without the Frenchman being penalised. But even without the referee's assistance they were doing a pretty good job.

The substitute Dean Holdsworth struck the upright with a left-foot drive and Eidur Gudjohnsen had a header saved from point-blank range during an onslaught in the final few minutes.

Bolton Wanderers (4-4-2): Banks; O'Kane, Bergsson, Ritchie, Whitlow; Johansen (Warhurst, 65), Jemsen, Passi, Gardner; Hansen (Holdsworth, h-t), Gudjohnsen.

Tranmere Rovers (4-5-1): Achterburg; Yates, Challinor, Hill, Roberts; Morgan, Jones, Mahon, Parkinson, Taylor (Frail, 86); Kelly.

Referee: G Barber (Tring).

fields.headline: Weah strikes right on cue
fields.trailText: The script was probably written beforehand. Three minutes from time, with Chelsea struggling to beat a lively Tottenham, George Weah rose high above two defenders to head home the winner for his new side on his debut.
fields.body:
The script was probably written beforehand. Three minutes from time, with Chelsea struggling to beat a lively Tottenham, George Weah rose high above two defenders to head home the winner for his new side on his debut.

This Boys Own denouement was tough luck on a Spurs side who themselves could do with a new striker, so many chances did they squander. But few inside Stamford Bridge cared.

The game had started cloaked in mystery about the absence of another of Chelsea's former Serie A players, Gianfranco Zola. Having found himself neither in the team nor on the bench for what would have been his 150th Chelsea game, the Italian had reportedly stormed off in a huff just before kick-off. However his being omitted from last night's squad was understandable given his measly tally of two goals all season.

It was not as if Weah had replaced him in the team because Chelsea chose to start their new signing on the bench rather than pick him from the start only hours after stepping off the plane from Milan even though they had rushed through his international clearance to play in this game.

Apparently, it had been a tearful farewell from Milan, the club he served for five years during which time he had won a huge place in the supporters hearts. But he did not fancy being fifth-choice striker at the San Siro and after Chelsea deputed Marcel Desailly to sell west London to his friend and former Milan team-mate, Weah agreed to join on loan until the end of the season for a wage of about £700,000.

It is not often a former world footballer of the year sits on the bench alongside a £10m striker - Chris Sutton. But Gianluca Vialli chose to repeat a recent ploy of playing one striker, Tore Andre Flo in front of a six-man midfield.

With Desailly injured and Celestine Babayaro on international duty with Nigeria, two home-grown youngsters were handed a rare chance of shining in Chelsea's normally cosmopolitan team, John Terry in central defence and Jon Harley at left wing-back.

Both were quickly on the back foot as Spurs, seeking their first win over Chelsea since 1990 and inspired by the jinking runs of David Ginola, began brightly, creating five chances to Chelsea's one before the break.

Sol Campbell went close after five minutes then Chris Armstrong shot wide from a great position shortly after.

Chelsea forced the first save when Ian Walker dived to thwart Bernard Lambourde's 20-yard volley, but Spurs were soon back on the attack.

Justin Edinburgh shot just wide, then the injury-plagued Darren Anderton, making his first start since August, produced a shot which Ed De Goey could not hold. The keeper did well to smother the follow-up shot from Steffen Iversen, and soon after blocked another shot from the same player. It was only Tottenham's familiar penchant for missing chances that had prevented the home side being sunk without trace.

Anderton's return on the right gave Spurs an alternative outlet to Ginola on the left as well as giving them a better balance. Their hunger for the fray against one of their fiercest rivals was most impressive and though Chelsea began the second half showing more purpose, by the 57th minute they had failed to really trouble Walker.

That was when Weah came on, along with Sutton, to form a twin spearhead. Weah received a warm welcome on a cold night and looked comfortable in unfamilair surroundings as he laid the ball off silkily. He then just failed to get on the end of a Dennis Wise through ball.

Tottenham (4-4-2): Walker; Carr, Perry, Campbell, Edinburgh; Anderton, Sherwood, Clemence, Ginola; Iversen, Arsmtrong.

Referee: N Barry (Roxby).
fields.bodyText: The script was probably written beforehand. Three minutes from time, with Chelsea struggling to beat a lively Tottenham, George Weah rose high above two defenders to head home the winner for his new side on his debut. This Boys Own denouement was tough luck on a Spurs side who themselves could do with a new striker, so many chances did they squander. But few inside Stamford Bridge cared. The game had started cloaked in mystery about the absence of another of Chelsea's former Serie A players, Gianfranco Zola. Having found himself neither in the team nor on the bench for what would have been his 150th Chelsea game, the Italian had reportedly stormed off in a huff just before kick-off. However his being omitted from last night's squad was understandable given his measly tally of two goals all season. It was not as if Weah had replaced him in the team because Chelsea chose to start their new signing on the bench rather than pick him from the start only hours after stepping off the plane from Milan even though they had rushed through his international clearance to play in this game. Apparently, it had been a tearful farewell from Milan, the club he served for five years during which time he had won a huge place in the supporters hearts. But he did not fancy being fifth-choice striker at the San Siro and after Chelsea deputed Marcel Desailly to sell west London to his friend and former Milan team-mate, Weah agreed to join on loan until the end of the season for a wage of about £700,000. It is not often a former world footballer of the year sits on the bench alongside a £10m striker - Chris Sutton. But Gianluca Vialli chose to repeat a recent ploy of playing one striker, Tore Andre Flo in front of a six-man midfield. With Desailly injured and Celestine Babayaro on international duty with Nigeria, two home-grown youngsters were handed a rare chance of shining in Chelsea's normally cosmopolitan team, John Terry in central defence and Jon Harley at left wing-back. Both were quickly on the back foot as Spurs, seeking their first win over Chelsea since 1990 and inspired by the jinking runs of David Ginola, began brightly, creating five chances to Chelsea's one before the break. Sol Campbell went close after five minutes then Chris Armstrong shot wide from a great position shortly after. Chelsea forced the first save when Ian Walker dived to thwart Bernard Lambourde's 20-yard volley, but Spurs were soon back on the attack. Justin Edinburgh shot just wide, then the injury-plagued Darren Anderton, making his first start since August, produced a shot which Ed De Goey could not hold. The keeper did well to smother the follow-up shot from Steffen Iversen, and soon after blocked another shot from the same player. It was only Tottenham's familiar penchant for missing chances that had prevented the home side being sunk without trace. Anderton's return on the right gave Spurs an alternative outlet to Ginola on the left as well as giving them a better balance. Their hunger for the fray against one of their fiercest rivals was most impressive and though Chelsea began the second half showing more purpose, by the 57th minute they had failed to really trouble Walker. That was when Weah came on, along with Sutton, to form a twin spearhead. Weah received a warm welcome on a cold night and looked comfortable in unfamilair surroundings as he laid the ball off silkily. He then just failed to get on the end of a Dennis Wise through ball. The Spurs keeper, standing directly under his goal, dropped Harley's high and speculative cross, the ball hit the ground, bounced up on to the bar and Walker calmly caught the rebound. webTitle: Dinner plates, Microwave ovens and Toast

fields.headline: Dinner plates, Microwave ovens and Toast
fields.trailText: WHO WILL BUY THIS WONDERFUL SUTTON?
fields.body:
WHO WILL BUY THIS WONDERFUL SUTTON?

Chris Sutton's Chelsea career is not over. That would be like saying General Pinochet is only a bit poorly and had been sticking the thermometer under his armpit. In fact the three-goal striker's prospects at Stamford Bridge have never looked better. Well, we hope they do, because nobody else seems to want him.

Take Peter Ridsdale for instance. Leeds United's busy chairman took time out from his hectic schedule today (the new Harry Kewell six-piece dinner sets arrived today and Peter had to count every one) to announce that his best pal David O'LearyO'Leeds will not be purchasing the England 'hit'man, even at a discount £8m.

"We have made no bid and as far as Chris Sutton is concerned, we don't intend to make a bid," Ridsdale told Leeds's official website. But, Peter being Peter, he couldn't stop there. "I would be lying if I said we have never discussed Chris," he confessed, with the Whites supposedly in the market for a target man. "We did so in the last 24 hours - when it's looked as if Chris might become available."

Which all lends credence to the paper talk that Ken Bates started touting Sutton around Premiership clubs as soon as George Weah got on the plane at Linate (that's Milan airport for those of you without a degree in ponce). A whole half a year after buying him. Say what you like about Bates, he knows how to run a good hotel.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

MEDIA STUDIES

Television companies are bang up for investing in companies. Rather than, say, buying a stake in Zoe Ball's midriff, the country's brightest moguls are looking to snap up stakes in Premiership clubs. BSkyB already own stakes in Man United, Leeds and Sunderland, cable firm NTL have a share in Newcastle and Granada bought into Liverpool. Now Arsenal and Aston Villa look set to join the club.

Arsenal are believed to be in talks with Telewest Communications, who own a company who own award winning crap channel Bravo, and NTL - both of whom wish to acquire a 9.9% stake in the club (they're not superstitious, it's just that 9.9% is the maximum they can buy if they want to invest in other clubs too --which they do). NTL are also supposed to be talking with Villa about a 9.9er. Which could be dirty if you think about it for long enough.

The interest of media companies in footy clubs has nothing at all to do with increasing fears that the days of collective bargaining for TV rights are numbered. Neither does it have anything to do with the approaching advent of broadband internet services which would allow you to watch matches on your PC (or microwave oven most likely). Just as well really, as who'd want to watch 'Good Morning with Doug and John Gregory' while re-heating a cup of coffee?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It has been a fantastic experience for us" - Gary Neville on the World Club Championshop. Ho ho.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE DAILY RECORD: YOUR ONE-STOP POP SHOP

'Wake up in the morning, wanting some aggro, what kind of paper should I read with my toast? Oh o o o o o oh, the Daily Record.' That would be the advert for Scotland's number one tabloid if they had given the account to Fiver, Fiver and Monkey (he's the brains behind the operation). "Why?" we hear you ask. Because, we answer, for controversial interviews, they just can't be beat.

Take this morning's edition for example. Inside there was an interview with Cov manager Gordon Strachan, who gave his response to the Alex Ferguson LHR autobiography. Six months after it came out. "When I see Alex, I'm always civil, but there's no exchange of Christmas cards," said the tempestuous redhead, whom Fergie believed "you wouldn't turn your back on".

"I don't want to analyse him and it's one man's opinion," Strachan went on, "But whether you're a knight or a lord, it's well proven that it doesn't make you a better person. A lot of knights have been caught telling porkies, top managers have taken money or are alcoholics." Surely he doesn't mean...? He couldn't...?!

But there was no time to dwell on the scandalous implications of Strachan's diatribe because, flick over the page, and here's Dick Advocaat dissing Ruud Gullit. Dick and the Ruud boy famously fell out when Dick was Dutch national coach. Dick had told his team that all complaints should be kept behind closed doors but Ruud, uncharacteristically, shared them with the press on more than one occasion. "I still like Gullit, honestly," insists Dick this morning, "I just don't understand why he did that, never will."

The Daily Record, we salute you!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Spurs are interested in £4 million-rated South Africa striker Sean Bartlett, who plays for FC Zurich.

Chelsea want to buy 21-year-old Dynamo Tbilisi captain Rati Alexidze. But they are unable to obtain a work permit for the midfielder.

West Ham want Bolton striker Dean Holdsworth on loan.

Ronaldo has denied he ever said he was interested in a move to Manchester United. But we all saw him say just that to our Gary only a couple of days ago. How could you Ronnie?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Liverpool have denied reports that Robbie Fowler will have to undergo another operation on his troublesome ankle. "Contrary to press reports, Robbie will not be undergoing surgery today," said manager Gerard Houllier. "He did see a specialist last week and we expect the final verdict later."

Tottenham's Tim Sherwood has been charged with misconduct by the FA after making obscene gestures to the crowd during Spurs' match at Newcastle last November.

Aberdeen goalkeeper Jim Leighton is likely to retire at the end of the season. 41-year-old former Scotland international is hoping for a long-term post as goalkeeping coach at Pittodrie, but admitted "You are retired a long time and it's not something I am looking forward to."

Bolton have signed 19-year-old French striker Mickael Kaprielian for a nominal fee from Marseille.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World football (2.45am) The latest ups and downs in the Burmese Super League.

Channel 4: Football Italia (2.50am) Those Italians, always rousin' and a-carousin' until the early hours.

Channel 5: Football review (1.30am) Which is more than can be said for this moribund lot.

US Major League Soccer (3.10am) Apparently it's the time of year when the best of the West meet the beasts from the East, or something. Expect some 52-year-old Ecuadorian to be the pick of the bunch.

Sky Sports 1: Football League Review (6.30pm) There needs to be a reappraisal of physical theatre, and sharpish, says Matthias Svensson.

You're on Sky Sports (10.15pm) Deep, deep underground, lies Mephistopheles' lair...

Fifa TV (12.15am) This week your host, Sepp Blatter, presents a special celebrity edition of Bureaucrats in their Eyes!

Spanish football (12.45am) Those Spaniards wouldn't make it up this late if it wasn't for their siesta, you know.

Sky Sports 2: Five-a-side football (8pm) At last the fat, low-skilled football community gets their moment in the spotlight.

Sky Sports 3: World Cup classics (10pm) Italy v North Korea 1966. Can the Koreans score a symbolic victory for communism over the international forces of capitalism? Fingers crossed...

Eurosport: International Tournament of Maspalomas - Live! (7.30pm) We do not know who the Maspalomas are, or what they stand for, but we've got a fair idea they're not the Belgian Indoor Chocolate Masticating Championships. Again.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live sport (7.30pm) Alan is away tonight. The gantry breathes a sigh of relief.
