webTitle: No one can be simultaneously free yet live in fear

fields.headline: No one can be simultaneously free yet live in fear
fields.standfirst:
Jack Straw's speech to the Institute of Public Policy Research

Crime and liberty | A crusade against crime | Bringing offenders to justice | The future | Conclusion
fields.trailText:
This morning I want to talk about crime, liberty and liberalism and the links between them. I want to argue that our commitments to modernising and strengthening individual liberty and to bearing down hard on crime and disorder are not contradictory but rather are complementary parts of an ambitious overall package of reform which we are pursuing to create a safe, just and tolerant society. A package which I believe represents the most comprehensive and coherent plan to tackle crime devised by any government since the war.

Crime and liberty

Crime always involves the deprivation of one person's liberty, health, happiness or well being by another and, in extreme circumstances, the deprivation of life itself.
fields.body:
This morning I want to talk about crime, liberty and liberalism and the links between them. I want to argue that our commitments to modernising and strengthening individual liberty and to bearing down hard on crime and disorder are not contradictory but rather are complementary parts of an ambitious overall package of reform which we are pursuing to create a safe, just and tolerant society. A package which I believe represents the most comprehensive and coherent plan to tackle crime devised by any government since the war.
Crime and liberty
Crime always involves the deprivation of one person's liberty, health, happiness or well being by another and, in extreme circumstances, the deprivation of life itself.

No one can be simultaneously free yet live in fear. True liberty is literally impossible if your neighbourhood has descended into lawlessness and intimidation. Some of those who have suffered serious racial harassment for example, - night after night of broken windows and racist chants, of arson attacks and stone throwing have literally become prisoners in their own homes, forced to surround themselves with razor wire, steel bars, CCTV and guard dogs designed not to keep the criminals in - but to keep them out.
The fight against this and other types of crime and disorder will always require a proper balancing of competing rights and freedoms. The rights of defendants to cross-examine witnesses in person for example versus the need to protect vulnerable victims in court or the right to individual privacy as against the right to safer streets. Over the years the public have shown that they are more than able to weigh up the relative importance of these different liberties. The rapid spread of CCTV systems for example, with little or no public opposition suggests that most of us have been more than happy to trade a right to privacy in public spaces for a more tangible feeling of increased safety.

These sorts of discussions about competing rights can spark off interesting contradictions. In an important book published at the beginning of 1996, David Rose pointed to the ambiguity that those on liberal left often showed in their attitudes towards how different kinds of crime should be dealt with. Whilst in general, as he pointed out, such people tended to argue that our criminal justice system was too harsh - that suspects rights weren't taken seriously enough, that punishments were too severe, that the police should have fewer not more powers, when it came to certain crimes - notably racial and domestic violence and sexual offences - they would quite often argue the exact opposite - for much stiffer legislation, tougher police action and harsher penalties, with process weighted towards the prosecution.
It's a habit which dies hard, as I found last week. After months of criticism for the damage I was allegedly doing to the rights of defendants through our legislation to abolish the right to elect trial by jury and our new, permanent, terrorism laws I suddenly found myself being attacked by a range of normally liberal activists and commentators for failing to use powers which I do not have to order the arrest and indefinite detention of an 87 year old suspected war criminal. (This is called internment by the way). Whilst these people may want to abolish the very clear division which has developed over many centuries between the executive and the judiciary and give politicians the power to order the arrest and detention of whoever they please - regardless of the rules of evidence and police procedure - it is not a vision of our criminal justice system which I, in even my least liberal mood, have ever contemplated.

But then Labour home secretaries are always bound to be damned from both sides. This was true even for Roy Jenkins - who's rightly remembered as the home secretary who gave government support to private members bills to legalise abortion, homosexuality and abolish theatre censorship. He ran into severe opposition with his plans to introduce majority verdicts in jury trials, saw an 11% increase in the prison population in 1966 and 1967 and then during his second stint at the department introduced a prevention of terrorism act which was criticised for years afterwards by those on the left as draconian and illiberal.
The debate about the Jenkins' proposal to change from unanimous to majority verdicts in jury trials in 1967 is particularly interesting for the lessons it holds for a similar debate we are having more than thirty years later about our mode of trial bill. Then, as now, the arguments were about the loss of a supposedly ancient English right (in the case of unanimous verdicts dating back to the 14th century, whereas the right to elect was not established until the mid 19th century) - though majority verdicts had long been standard practice in Scotland. Then, as now, the move was supported by the lord chief justice and by the police service, (in particular by Robert Mark who was keen to reduce the effect of criminal intimidation of juries) but opposed by an opportunist Conservative opposition voting with more principled opponents from the liberal Left.

During the report stage in the House for the 1967 Bill MPs queued up to criticise the measure. One MP [Mr Hale, Oldham West] even stated that "never before in the history of Parliament has there been a provision undermining the constitution of the nation, the liberties of the people and a system of justice that, with all its faults, is the envy of the world, on less evidence, with less consideration, and with a more complete absence of reasoning in its support". (Hansard 26 April 1967 col 1744).

The veteran Labour MP, Sydney Silverman begged Jenkins "not to spoil the magnificent record he is building up as the most progressive home secretary we have had for many years by this foolish thing at the dictation of a lord chief justice who seems to me to know nothing about the criminal law" (Hansard 26 April 1967, col 1758).

In spite of this extraordinary hyperbole, the measure passed and proved a great success and opposition to the change soon melted away.
This is a pattern that has become all too familiar over the years. There have been a whole string of changes like the abolition of peremptory challenge and the introduction of a prosecution right of appeal against unduly lenient sentences which though bitterly opposed by the legal profession have turned out to work without problem. As Helena Kennedy - who now opposes our mode of trial bill - pointed out in her book 'Eve was Framed' (1992) "unfortunately, the knee jerk response of most lawyers, even those with progressive attitudes, is to resist any change which might affect the position of the defendant". I am firmly convinced that the change we are planning to make to the right of defendants to elect jury trial is the right one. It is a sensible procedural reform which will speed up justice for defendants, witnesses and victims alike and ensure that we retain the confidence of the public in the system as a whole. Perhaps the ultimate irony given the views of many who oppose the change, is that one effect of the reform may be to reduce the prison population by increasing the number of people sentenced in the magistrates rather than crown court.

The changes we are introducing through the mode of trial bill are just one part of a much broader package of measures we are introducing to modernise the criminal justice system and drive down crime.
A crusade against crime
There is still a huge job of work to be done. Though crime is lower now than it was at the time of the election, England and Wales remains the most crime prone area in western Europe across a wide range of offences. Crime and the fear of crime are reducing business profits, widening inequalities in wealth and opportunity and diverting millions of pounds of precious resources away from priority areas like the health service and schools. Over the past two and a half years we have been laying the foundations for the most co-ordinated and coherent attack on crime in a generation. At every stage in the criminal justice process from the collection of evidence at scenes of crime to the treatment of victims in court to the programmes that are provided in our prisons, we have been working with those in the criminal justice system to provide the legal framework and the resources they need to lever up performance. That means more money for the DNA database and CCTV cameras, a 50% increase in funding for victim support, new legal powers to deal with young offenders, a huge increase in funding for drugs programmes in prison. For the first time ever we have finally got all of the different agencies within the system - police, prosecutors, court clerks, probation and prisons working together on common priorities with joint business plans and shared boundaries. Week by week, month by month we are getting delays down and the quality of justice up. We are targeting resources and effort on those groups who we know account for a large proportion of all crime such as persistent young offenders and people addicted to hard drugs. We are putting in place the strong leadership and support that will be needed to bring out the best from every crime and disorder partnership - to make sure that every police force and local authority is aiming at the standards set by the best. And for the first time ever we will be publishing national crime statistics next week which will show crime figures not just for police force areas but for individual police divisions to give the public the information they need to make relevant comparisons and scrutinise local performance. Bringing offenders to justice
But there is one other key area - what should be a core business of the criminal justice system, catching and convicting criminals - where we are embarked on a particularly ambitious programme of reform. If the cases, which defined the crisis on our criminal justice system in the 1970s and 1980s, were those of the Birmingham six and Guildford four then I suspect that the defining case of the 1990s will come to be seen as that of Stephen Lawrence.

This was a case where the injustice was not that of a wrongful conviction but of a failure to convict at all. Where the outcry was not that innocent men had spent too long in prison - but that no-one had been sent to prison at all. It was, I hope, a defining moment in the attitude of the liberal left towards punishment and prosecution as many realised, perhaps for the first time, that the person just as likely to suffer when our justice system breaks down as the unjustly convicted is the victim and their family.
A key message from Labour in opposition was that there was "more crime, and more criminals getting away with it". We pointed out that whilst crime had doubled under the previous government, the number of criminals convicted had fallen in absolute terms by a third. As a result, for example, the ratio of convictions to recorded crimes for assault had fallen from over a half in 1980 to just 14% in 1997, for sexual offences from 38% to 14% and for burglaries from 11% to 3% or 1 conviction for every 33 crimes recorded. Overall, by 1997 more than 3.2 million crimes a year were not being cleared up.

What is more, the evidence from across the Atlantic was that this could not be blamed on some sort of more global trend. Whilst conviction rates were falling in England and Wales they had actually been increasing in the United States to the point where by 1996 a person committing a crime in the America was more likely to be caught and convicted than one committing a crime in England for all major crimes except murder.

The proportion of rapes ending in conviction in 1996 was almost twice as high in the US as in England and the proportion of robberies ending in conviction was nearly four times greater.
In other words, by the time we were elected, the levels of what those working in the system call attrition had simply become unacceptable for almost all types of crime. Public confidence was waning and the perception that offenders were getting away with it was becoming depressingly true. Labour in government has made the effective prosecution and conviction of offenders a priority. First, and most urgently we have radically overhauled the CPS which had been introduced in a botched and severely under-resourced way in the 1980s causing a disastrous dip in the number of convictions. In particular, we have restored the local links between police and prosecution by creating 42 local chief crown prosecutors - one for each police force area to provide much greater local accountability for prosecution decisions. Secondly, we are, I hope, encouraging more victims to pursue their case by making it significantly less traumatic for vulnerable victims to tell their story in court. fields.bodyText: This morning I want to talk about crime, liberty and liberalism and the links between them. I want to argue that our commitments to modernising and strengthening individual liberty and to bearing down hard on crime and disorder are not contradictory but rather are complementary parts of an ambitious overall package of reform which we are pursuing to create a safe, just and tolerant society. A package which I believe represents the most comprehensive and coherent plan to tackle crime devised by any government since the war. Crime and liberty Crime always involves the deprivation of one person's liberty, health, happiness or well being by another and, in extreme circumstances, the deprivation of life itself. No one can be simultaneously free yet live in fear. True liberty is literally impossible if your neighbourhood has descended into lawlessness and intimidation. Some of those who have suffered serious racial harassment for example, - night after night of broken windows and racist chants, of arson attacks and stone throwing have literally become prisoners in their own homes, forced to surround themselves with razor wire, steel bars, CCTV and guard dogs designed not to keep the criminals in - but to keep them out. The rights of defendants to cross-examine witnesses in person for example versus the need to protect vulnerable victims in court or the right to individual privacy as against the right to safer streets. Over the years the public have shown that they are more than able to weigh up the relative importance of these different liberties. The rapid spread of CCTV systems for example, with little or no public opposition suggests that most of us have been more than happy to trade a right to privacy in public spaces for a more tangible feeling of increased safety. These sorts of discussions about competing rights can spark off interesting contradictions. In an important book published at the beginning of 1996, David Rose pointed to the ambiguity that those on liberal left often showed in their attitudes towards how different kinds of crime should be dealt with. Whilst in general, as he pointed out, such people tended to argue that our criminal justice system was too harsh - that suspects rights weren't taken seriously enough, that punishments were too severe, that the police should have fewer not more powers, when it came to certain crimes - notably racial and domestic violence and sexual offences - they would quite often argue the exact opposite - for much stiffer legislation, tougher police action and harsher penalties, with process weighted towards the prosecution. It's a habit which dies hard, as I found last week. This was true even for Roy Jenkins - who's rightly remembered as the home secretary who gave government support to private members bills to legalise abortion, homosexuality and abolish theatre censorship. Then, as now, the arguments were about the loss of a supposedly ancient English right (in the case of unanimous verdicts dating back to the 14th century, whereas the right to elect was not established until the mid 19th century) - though majority verdicts had long been standard practice in Scotland. Then, as now, the move was supported by the lord chief justice and by the police service, (in particular by Robert Mark who was keen to reduce the effect of criminal intimidation of juries) but opposed by an opportunist Conservative opposition voting with more principled opponents from the liberal Left. The veteran Labour MP, Sydney Silverman begged Jenkins "not to spoil the magnificent record he is building up as the most progressive home secretary we have had for many years by this foolish thing at the dictation of a lord chief justice who seems to me to know nothing about the criminal law" (Hansard 26 April 1967, col 1758). In spite of this extraordinary hyperbole, the measure passed and proved a great success and opposition to the change soon melted away. This is a pattern that has become all too familiar over the years. There have been a whole string of changes like the abolition of peremptory challenge and the introduction of a prosecution right of appeal against unduly lenient sentences which though bitterly opposed by the legal profession have turned out to work without problem. Perhaps the ultimate irony given the views of many who oppose the change, is that one effect of the reform may be to reduce the prison population by increasing the number of people sentenced in the magistrates rather than crown court. The changes we are introducing through the mode of trial bill are just one part of a much broader package of measures we are introducing to modernise the criminal justice system and drive down crime. A crusade against crime There is still a huge job of work to be done. Though crime is lower now than it was at the time of the election, England and Wales remains the most crime prone area in western Europe across a wide range of offences. Crime and the fear of crime are reducing business profits, widening inequalities in wealth and opportunity and diverting millions of pounds of precious resources away from priority areas like the health service and schools. Over the past two and a half years we have been laying the foundations for the most co-ordinated and coherent attack on crime in a generation. Week by week, month by month we are getting delays down and the quality of justice up. We are targeting resources and effort on those groups who we know account for a large proportion of all crime such as persistent young offenders and people addicted to hard drugs. We are putting in place the strong leadership and support that will be needed to bring out the best from every crime and disorder partnership - to make sure that every police force and local authority is aiming at the standards set by the best. And for the first time ever we will be publishing national crime statistics next week which will show crime figures not just for police force areas but for individual police divisions to give the public the information they need to make relevant comparisons and scrutinise local performance. Bringing offenders to justice But there is one other key area - what should be a core business of the criminal justice system, catching and convicting criminals - where we are embarked on a particularly ambitious programme of reform. If the cases, which defined the crisis on our criminal justice system in the 1970s and 1980s, were those of the Birmingham six and Guildford four then I suspect that the defining case of the 1990s will come to be seen as that of Stephen Lawrence. webTitle: More doubt on Pakistan arms exports

fields.headline: More doubt on Pakistan arms exports
fields.standfirst: Pakistan coup: special report
fields.trailText: The chances of new licences for arms exports to Pakistan being approved by the government look increasingly unlikely after disclosure by the Guardian yesterday of the inter-departmental battle over its ethical foreign policy.
fields.body:
The chances of new licences for arms exports to Pakistan being approved by the government look increasingly unlikely after disclosure by the Guardian yesterday of the inter-departmental battle over its ethical foreign policy.

The department of trade and industry, usually the powerhouse in backing exporters, insisted it would abide by any advice from the foreign office.

A leaked cabinet office minute published in the Guardian had revealed the DTI and the ministry of defence joining forces to "expedite" 80 export licences frozen after the military takeover in Pakistan in October. Both the foreign office and the deparment of international development opposed the lifting of the unofficial embargo.

A DTI source said yesterday the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will not act against the advice of the foreign office on such matters.

Pakistan has been treated almost as a pariah state since the coup. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, led a campaign that saw Pakistan suspended from most of the Commonwealth bodies as a way to express protest at the overthrow of a democratic government, albeit a tarnished one.

The official government line was that it does not comment on leaked documents but various government sources confirmed privately that the minutes were accurate. If the battle between the DTi-MoD axis and the FO and international development duo had continued, the issue would have had to be resolved by Downing Street.

The treasury was also involved in the discussion but the papers had not been passed to the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

At prime minister's question time, Tony Blair played down the disclosures of a rift between ministers over foreign policy. He was pressed by Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, who said he wanted to challenge him over his promise of pursuing an ethical foreign policy.

"Now does he support the foriegn secretary and the international development secretary in opposing the resumption of arms sales to Pakistan until democratic guarantees are in place?" Mr Kennedy asked.

Mr Blair replied: "This question is based on a misunderstanding. As far as I am aware, there is no dispute between government departments at all. As far as I am aware, there are no proposed [arms] sales taking place."

Later, Mr Kennedy wrote to Mr Blair: "It is reported in today's Guardian, based on a cabinet minutes of December 8 1999, that there should be a return to normal sales of arms to Pakistan - a move that was strongly resisted by Clare Short and Robin Cook. Was that not the case?"

fields.headline: Another fine mess
fields.standfirst: Cowboy builders are about to be reined in, the government claims. But  John Crace  asks if voluntary rules will be enough to control the real bad guys: the damp-proofers
fields.trailText: Two-and-a-half years ago, James and Ondine Park bought a new home in north-west London. Like every other house-buyer, they asked for a structural survey, and like nearly every other survey, theirs turned out to be largely unintelligible and contained several references to damp. Several months after moving in, the Parks decided to get the damp problem sorted. Friends recommended a builder and they asked for a quote.
fields.body:
Two-and-a-half years ago, James and Ondine Park bought a new home in north-west London. Like every other house-buyer, they asked for a structural survey, and like nearly every other survey, theirs turned out to be largely unintelligible and contained several references to damp. Several months after moving in, the Parks decided to get the damp problem sorted. Friends recommended a builder and they asked for a quote.

"He told us our problem was comparatively minor and that it would be simple to fix," says James Park. "We took him at his word and employed him." Six months later, Park tried to plug in the hoover and the entire socket came away from the wall. "The plaster was so wet it had turned to putty," he explains. "The builder had mistaken a ventilation grille for a hole in the wall and sealed it up."

The very least one expects from a damp-proofer is that the problem is not made worse, but the Parks' builder couldn't even manage that. And needless to say, there was only one person who was out of pocket. "The builder turned out to have huge financial problems, so there was no point pursuing him," Park says. "So we ended up paying for someone else to redo the work."

Falling out with your builder is a rite of passage for any homeowner. Disputes and rip-offs, it seems, come with the territory, which is why the government is trying to clean up the industry. The final report of its Cow boy Builders Working Group proposed introducing a quality mark scheme for builders, together with insurance for the consumer. Trial runs of the scheme begin in Birmingham in the spring and in Somerset during the summer and, all being well, it will be rolled out nationwide next year.

A government spokesman insists that this is a great deal more than the reinvention of the kite mark: an independent agency will scrutinise the work of builders who sign up, and the insurance scheme will protect consumers if builders go out of business or fail to finish a job. But whether the scheme can really protect consumers remains to be seen.

If builders in general are cowboys, then damp-proofers are the industry's rodeo riders. Mystification, quasi-science, and incompetence are so common that it is virtually impossible for consumers to know whether they have got a good deal.

Take the Parks. Even now, they can't be sure that their problem was correctly identified and, if it was, that it was correctly treated. Surveyors are notoriously quick to spot damp as they prod the suspect walls with their meters. But the devices are often inaccurate and, in any case, only measure moisture content; they don't say where the water is coming from.

In tests conducted anonymously by Which?, the Consumers' Association magazine, a large number of damp-proofing specialists have consistently failed to identify problems such as condensation, badly pointed walls and leaky gutters, and recommended the installation of a damp course instead. And, surprise, surprise, the damp course was generally a great deal more expensive than the correct treatment.

Even if your home does need damp-proofing, how do you know that the specialist has recommended the right solution? You don't. All you can do is rely on the 25- or 30-year guarantee you will have been given and hope for the best. But the guarantee will almost certainly not be as foolproof as you had been led to believe. The company that issued the guarantee may not still exist by the time you ask them to honour their commitment, and even if the company is still trading or you have sensibly paid a premium for guarantee protection, you can still get stung.

Alex Benady has been caught out twice. "The first time, the damp-proofer admitted liability and said he would fix the problem," he explains. "He also pointed out that he was not liable for any making good, such as replastering. So, although he fulfilled his end of the bargain, his bad workmanship ended up costing me an extra couple of hundred quid.

"On the second occasion, the damp-proofer agreed that his work was covered by the guarantee, but argued that it had failed because the builders who had made good after the installation of the damp course had not used the right products. The builders disagreed. Without spending a small fortune on an independent surveyor and chemical analysis, it was impossible to resolve the situation. Again, I had to cough up."

Benady's experience is not unusual. "Given the inconsistency of diagnosis and treatment between companies," says Duncan Larder, an assistant editor at Which?, "you can only conclude that some damp-proofers are either inept or are blatantly trying to rip off the public."

Unfortunately, there is little hope of legal redress. Getting two sets of damp experts to agree about anything is next to impossible. And if they can't make up their minds, how can a judge?

But damp problems aren't going to go away. So what are your options? At present your best bet is to use a company that is a member of the British wood-preserving and damp-proofing association (BWPDA). The BWPDA cites strict codes of practice and rigorous levels of workmanship, and offers itself as a mediation ser vice for the public, but, as with most trade associations, it is compromised by the fact that its survival depends on its members' subscriptions. When push comes to shove, it's not hard to guess where its sympathies will lie. Which is why, presumably, it elects not to make anonymous spot checks on its members' work.

Dr Chris Coggins, director of the BWPDA, is aware of the industry's poor image, but defends his organisation's role as mediator. "Last year we received 1,500 enquiries, of which 80 could not be resolved on the phone and needed to be referred to the contractor," he says. "Five of these went to our mediation service. In three cases we found in favour of the contractor and in one we found shared responsibility. The other case has been held over at the request of the client."

Coggins also defends the industry's conduct on guarantees, and says that differing diagnoses of a problem are common in medicine and law, not just in the world of damp-proofing. But he acknowledges that the BWPDA is trying to improve professional standards with certification schemes.

All of this is fine, but it is still a long way short of the protection the consumer needs. For that, we are going to have to hope that the government's new voluntary scheme has teeth. "If it doesn't work, we will introduce legislation to make membership compulsory," says a government spokesman. To which the cynics among us will say: "Legislation it will be, then."

How to beat the bandits

1 Always get at least two opinions and quotes for any work, preferably from members of the BWPDA.

2 Make sure you receive a report in writing and that you have a detailed specification, itemising any products or chemicals to be used, before you accept a quote.

3 Get one survey from an independent specialist who is not connected to any firm who will be doing the work. Be prepared to pay for this to protect your investment in the long run.

4 Ask if you have any queries. If you are not satisfied with any replies, do not deal with the company.

5 For work involving large sums of money, consider getting an independent specialist to oversee various stages of the damp-proofing.

6 Only release the final payment when you are as sure as you can be that the work has been completed satisfactorily.

7 Make sure you have protection for your guarantee in case the company ceases trading.

BWPDA, 6 The Office Village, Stratford, London E15 4EA, tel: 0181 519-2588

Mystification, quasi-science, and incompetence are so common that it is virtually impossible for consumers to know whether they have got a good deal. Take the Parks. Even now, they can't be sure that their problem was correctly identified and, if it was, that it was correctly treated. Surveyors are notoriously quick to spot damp as they prod the suspect walls with their meters. But the devices are often inaccurate and, in any case, only measure moisture content; they don't say where the water is coming from. In tests conducted anonymously by Which?, the Consumers' Association magazine, a large number of damp-proofing specialists have consistently failed to identify problems such as condensation, badly pointed walls and leaky gutters, and recommended the installation of a damp course instead. And, surprise, surprise, the damp course was generally a great deal more expensive than the correct treatment. Even if your home does need damp-proofing, how do you know that the specialist has recommended the right solution? You don't. All you can do is rely on the 25- or 30-year guarantee you will have been given and hope for the best. But the guarantee will almost certainly not be as foolproof as you had been led to believe. The company that issued the guarantee may not still exist by the time you ask them to honour their commitment, and even if the company is still trading or you have sensibly paid a premium for guarantee protection, you can still get stung. Alex Benady has been caught out twice. "The first time, the damp-proofer admitted liability and said he would fix the problem," he explains. "He also pointed out that he was not liable for any making good, such as replastering. So, although he fulfilled his end of the bargain, his bad workmanship ended up costing me an extra couple of hundred quid. "On the second occasion, the damp-proofer agreed that his work was covered by the guarantee, but argued that it had failed because the builders who had made good after the installation of the damp course had not used the right products. The builders disagreed. Without spending a small fortune on an independent surveyor and chemical analysis, it was impossible to resolve the situation. Again, I had to cough up." Benady's experience is not unusual. "Given the inconsistency of diagnosis and treatment between companies," says Duncan Larder, an assistant editor at Which?, "you can only conclude that some damp-proofers are either inept or are blatantly trying to rip off the public." Unfortunately, there is little hope of legal redress. Getting two sets of damp experts to agree about anything is next to impossible. And if they can't make up their minds, how can a judge? But damp problems aren't going to go away. So what are your options? At present your best bet is to use a company that is a member of the British wood-preserving and damp-proofing association (BWPDA). The BWPDA cites strict codes of practice and rigorous levels of workmanship, and offers itself as a mediation ser vice for the public, but, as with most trade associations, it is compromised by the fact that its survival depends on its members' subscriptions. When push comes to shove, it's not hard to guess where its sympathies will lie. Which is why, presumably, it elects not to make anonymous spot checks on its members' work. Dr Chris Coggins, director of the BWPDA, is aware of the industry's poor image, but defends his organisation's role as mediator. "Last year we received 1,500 enquiries, of which 80 could not be resolved on the phone and needed to be referred to the contractor," he says. "Five of these went to our mediation service. In three cases we found in favour of the contractor and in one we found shared responsibility. The other case has been held over at the request of the client." Coggins also defends the industry's conduct on guarantees, and says that differing diagnoses of a problem are common in medicine and law, not just in the world of damp-proofing. But he acknowledges that the BWPDA is trying to improve professional standards with certification schemes. All of this is fine, but it is still a long way short of the protection the consumer needs. For that, we are going to have to hope that the government's new voluntary scheme has teeth. "If it doesn't work, we will introduce legislation to make membership compulsory," says a government spokesman. To which the cynics among us will say: "Legislation it will be, then." How to beat the bandits 1 Always get at least two opinions and quotes for any work, preferably from members of the BWPDA. 2 Make sure you receive a report in writing and that you have a detailed specification, itemising any products or chemicals to be used, before you accept a quote. 3 Get one survey from an independent specialist who is not connected to any firm who will be doing the work. Be prepared to pay for this to protect your investment in the long run. 4 Ask if you have any queries. If you are not satisfied with any replies, do not deal with the company. 5 For work involving large sums of money, consider getting an independent specialist to oversee various stages of the damp-proofing. 6 Only release the final payment when you are as sure as you can be that the work has been completed satisfactorily. 7 Make sure you have protection for your guarantee in case the company ceases trading. BWPDA, 6 The Office Village, Stratford, London E15 4EA, tel: 0181 519-2588

webTitle: How much can you pay for . . .

fields.headline: How much can you pay for . . .
fields.standfirst: A cheese grater?
fields.trailText: A cheese grater?
fields.body: If you were cheese (for some reason people often take offence when I ask this question), you would want to be grated by the best, wouldn't you? I mean, if you were, say, a nice bit of creamily mature Irish cheddar, or a piece of chalkily flaking lovely sharp parmeggiano, having spent a year or much much more getting that way, you'd be a bit gutted if someone just brought out a rusty old grater and rubbed away. And that, me old cheeses, is why that most thoughtful of shops, Oggetti (0171-581 8088), is offering their cheese grater set in pearwood, for just £72. No cheese need blush to be cut up in tiny pieces with this! Oh no.

fields.headline: Cybershopping: sportswear
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited's Sport and the outdoors section.
fields.trailText: The best thing about going online to buy the wherewithal for your new fitness regime is that you don't even have to stir from your chair.
fields.body:
The best thing about going online to buy the wherewithal for your new fitness regime is that you don't even have to stir from your chair.

The DKNY Active range for women from www.boo.com - trackpants £90, hooded jacket £72, bike shorts £39 - may end up costing as much as gym membership, but hell, you'll look great even if you never make it near a treadmill. The men's range is not extensive, but there are some nice Fred Perry fleece tops (from £55) and DKNY Active drawstring pants (£37) for frosty morning runs.

Serious runners may want to check out the recommendations at www.runnersworld.co.uk before investing in new trainers. Suitably informed, head to www.sportsshoes.com for a good selection of brands and lots of discounts: £25 off the Adidas Radiant (now £49.99); £20 off the Puma Cell Complete MC (now £39.99). A "fast link" from the site takes you to the Lady Fitness Clothing page, where you'll find Nike Dri Fit Sports Bras (£9.99), specially designed to soak up perspiration (hmm, lovely), and much more.

Newitts (www.newitts.com ) is one of the largest catalogues online, and is surprisingly easy to search.

If you plan to stay on the sidelines, visit www.kitbag.com , where, for a limited period, replica football kits cost a maximum of £39.99.

webTitle: Hillary holds her own on The Late Show

fields.headline: Hillary holds her own on The Late Show
fields.standfirst: Watch David Letterman chat to Hillary Clinton on CBS.com
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton was on the electoral trail again last night with an appearance on one of the US's most popular television chat shows.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton was on the electoral trail again last night with an appearance on one of the US's most popular television chat shows.

Mrs Clinton was the guest of David Letterman's late show in New York, the state she hopes will vote her into the US senate.

The chat show host has been a harsh critic of Mrs Clinton's, saying she is a carpet-bagger with few real connections to New York.

"We have to give this woman a tremendous amount of credit for just showing up," he told the audience.

Mrs Clinton admitted to being "just a little" nervous, but told Mr Letterman: "I knew if I was going to run for Senate, I was going to have to come and sit in this chair and talk to the big guy."

Mr Letterman playfully threw a ball to Mrs Clinton and asked her to "tell us a little bit about yourself."

She smiled and told Mr Letterman she grew up in the Midwest - as he did - has a mother named Dorothy - as he does - and was unable to resist the temptation to follow him to New York.

During the interview, Mrs Clinton gave correct answers to Mr Letterman's New York quiz, correctly identifying the state bird - bluebird - and the state tree - the sugar maple.

She explained that she had always wanted to live in New York. "New York has always attracted people from all over the world. That's what makes it such a great place to live," she said.

Mrs Clinton finished the interview with a list of ten reasons why she came on the show. Borrowing Frank Sinatra's line, she concluded: "If I can make it here, I can make it anywhere."

Her opponent in the senate race, New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani, has been on the show 14 times and joined the host in comedy skits. Mr Giuliani said he often watched David Letterman but remained vague about whether he would be tuning in to see the first lady.
Hillary Clinton's Top Ten List: Reasons I finally decided to appear on the late show
10 I lost a bet with Tipper.
9 I thought this was a show where you answer a couple of easy questions and win a million dollars.
8. If Dan Quayle did it, how hard can it be?
7 I was already in town to interview for the Jets' head coach position.
6 Four words: severe lapse of judgement.
5 I needed an excuse to get out of dinner with Donald Trump.
4 When they threw in a Late Show tote bag, I said, "Gas up the Taurus, Bill, we're goin' to Dave's."
3 I haven't been in the Ed Sullivan Theater since I was dating Ringo.
2 Um, to tell you the truth, I thought Johnny hosted this show.
1 If I can make it here, I can make it anywhere!

fields.headline: Bye, bye American pi
fields.standfirst: Textbooks can't teach maths to most young US students, says  Keith Devlin
fields.trailText: American students aren't stupid - they just can't cope with textbooks. This has been the remarkable finding of a test devised to find the best way of teaching mathematics to different types of people.
fields.body:
American students aren't stupid - they just can't cope with textbooks. This has been the remarkable finding of a test devised to find the best way of teaching mathematics to different types of people.

The test revealed that among males aged between 18 and 25, just 17% are suited to learn through reading text. For the remaining 83%, the standard college textbook is little more than dead weight to carry around in their bag.

But such people are not beyond hope. For the test, developed and administered by Diablo Valley College, a state-funded, college outside San Francisco, California, recommends other ways of learning. "I'm not stupid, I'm auditory," was how one student reacted after taking it.

By far the most powerful method of learning among all age-groups is visual nonverbal: diagrams, tables, illustrations, pictures, and video. Among the 18-25 age-group, 48.1% of males and 36.2% of females favour this method. The figures for the over-35s are almost identical: 46.0% and 38.8%. Half a century after the dawn of the television age, these results are perhaps not surprising. But the vast majority of mathematics courses are still structured around the traditional college textbook.

The college's mathematics instructor Suzanne Miller gave a report on the test she gave at the California Mathematics Council meeting in Monterey, earlier this month. The test is based on her research into learning styles, and was written by the college's learning disability specialist Catherine Jester. It comprises 32 multiple-choice questions designed to ascertain a student's natural learning style, and has been freely available on the web (http://silcon.com) since January 1998. It takes just a few minutes to complete, and a profile of the student's learning style along with specific suggestions of how best to study is available immediately.

To date, more than 10,000 students from Diablo Valley College and elsewhere have used it to overcome maths anxiety and improve their performance in mathematics. Miller's initial analysis of the test's data found that just under 35% of women aged between 18 and 25 can learn from textually presented information.

These figures contrast with those for students aged 35 or over, a substantial proportion in colleges. Of these 27% of males and more than 42% of females find it natural to learn from reading.

Miller does not know whether the difference between the two age-groups is a direct consequence of growing older, or a reflection of changes in the environment in which today's under 25s grew up. The answer will have to await a follow-up study she hopes to carry out when today's younger respondents grow older.

At a time when many people are taking college courses on the internet, it is worth noting another of Miller's findings: that a surprisingly high proportion of people learn best from listening. In the 18-25 age-group, 38.0% of men and 31.3% of women are predominantly auditory learners; among the over 35s, 35.2% of men and 25.7% of women.

Among Miller's own online maths students is a married couple with a four-month-old child. The husband is visual non-verbal, draws pictures and can then "see" the answer to the problem. His wife is a reader who works step by step.

As Miller remarks: "They have not been able to collaborate because his way confuses her and vice versa."

A fourth group learn best by manipulating objects or gesticulating with their hands. Among the younger age-group, 20.2% of men and 20.7% of women learn best in this fashion; among the older students, the figures are 14.1% and 13.1%, respectively. Don't expect those individuals to succeed unless they are free to stand up and move around.

Between 20% and 24% of students exhibit a hybrid style that spans two or more of the four categories.

A professional mathematician, I took the test myself. It diagnosed me (correctly) as primarily suited to learning by reading and secondarily by visually presented information (diagrams, graphs, tables, etc).

My diagnostic report said I should "write out sentences and phrases that summarise key information obtained from your textbook and lecture", that I should "make flashcards of vocabulary words and concepts that need to be memorised," and that "when learning information presented in diagrams or illustrations, write out explanations for the information". I did all of these when I was a student. Indeed, the only suggestions I did not use are those involving computers, which were not available in my own student days.

Looking back, I was lucky that my learning style fitted so well into the educational system prevalent at the time. I did well. Many are not so lucky. In her presentation at Monterey, Miller observed that "the project has made faculty more aware of the importance of understanding diverse learning styles and designing course work to reach the broadest possible spectrum of styles".

Dr Keith Devlin is dean of science at Saint Mary's College of California. His latest book, The Math Gene: Why Everyone Has It But Most People Don't Use It will be published in the UK in April by Weidenfeld and Nicolson

webTitle: Tension mounts as Straw stands by trial plans

fields.headline: Tension mounts as Straw stands by trial plans
fields.trailText: Home secretary Jack Straw today defended his plan to limit the right to trial by jury in England and Wales as tension mounts between the House of Lords and the government over the reforms.
fields.body:
Home secretary Jack Straw today defended his plan to limit the right to trial by jury in England and Wales as tension mounts between the House of Lords and the government over the reforms.

Standing by his proposals in a speech to the Institute for Public Policy Research in London, Mr Straw said that the reforms would save money, speed up justice and ensure continuing public confidence in the legal system.

"I am firmly convinced that the change we are planning to make to the right of defendants to elect jury trial is the right one," he said.

The proposals, currently in the House of Lords, would end the right of a defendant to choose jury trial in all circumstances.

Former Law Lord Lord Ackner is planning to table amendments to the government's bill. He has the backing of the Tory and Liberal Democrat front benches and some Labour peers, and the move could kill off the proposals in the Lords.

Mr Straw said the justice system had to be modernised and that legal reforms always sparked accusations of erosions of justice.

"I can't quite believe that the Lords are going to make such an undemocratic decision to refuse even to allow the elected House of Commons to debate this measure.

"There is this extraordinarily opportunistic alliance taking place at the moment between the Conservatives, under whom this proposal originally came forward, and Liberal Democrats and others," he told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme.

But Labour peer Baroness Kennedy QC insisted that it was "profoundly wrong" to refuse to allow some defendants appearing in magistrates' courts the right to elect to go for trial by jury.

It would be "invidious" to allow magistrates to decide in which court, and under which system, defendants should be tried, she told Today.

Mr Straw believes that many defendants use the right to choose to be tried by a jury rather than by magistrates as a "racket" to string out cases. Planned reforms will take the decision out of defendants' hands and put it into the hands of magistrates. A right of appeal is also proposed, to safeguard the rights of those accused of crimes.

webTitle: Harrods loses Prince Philip's royal warrant

fields.headline: Harrods loses Prince Philip's royal warrant
fields.trailText: The feuding between Mohamed Al Fayed and the Duke of Edinburgh took a fresh turn today, when Buckingham Palace announced the Duke's royal warrant awarded to Harrods would be withdrawn.
fields.body:
The feuding between Mohamed Al Fayed and the Duke of Edinburgh took a fresh turn today, when Buckingham Palace announced the Duke's royal warrant awarded to Harrods would be withdrawn.

A Palace spokesman insisted the decision not to renew the honour at the end of this year was taken because of "the significant decline in the trading relationship between the [Duke's] household and Harrods over several years".

During the recent libel case brought by Neil Hamilton, Harrods' owner Mr Fayed called the Duke "a Nazi" and alleged that Prince Philip and MI5 were responsible for the death of Mr Fayed's son, Dodi, and Diana, Princess of Wales.

It was subsequently reported that the Palace had lost patience with Mr Fayed and would not renew any of the royal warrants granted to Harrods from Prince Philip, the Queen, the Queen Mother and the Prince of Wales.

Renewal letters are being sent out to all the holders of the Duke of Edinburgh's royal warrants in the next couple of weeks. The warrants granted by the Queen and the Prince of Wales are not up for review until next year.

A spokesman for Harrods said the store had received a letter from Buckingham Palace this morning informing them of the withdrawal of the royal warrant, but he added that no reference had been made to Mr Fayed's libel case comments.

"This simply reflects the dwindling patronage between the Duke and Harrods over recent years," the spokesman reiterated.

Harrods now has until the end of the year to have the warrant removed from the front of the store and from its stationary and packaging. It received its first royal warrant in 1913 from Queen Mary. Prince Philip's warrant to Harrods was first granted in 1956.

For centuries, royal warrants have been granted to trades people and companies who regularly supply goods or services to the monarchy. There are around 920 warrant holders today, who hold over 1,150 royal warrants between them,

The head of the royal household, the Lord Chamberlain, advises the Queen, the Duke of Edinburgh, the Queen Mother and the Prince of Wales where to grant warrants, which are renewed every five years and can be revoked at any time.

Their issuing of warrants, and their withdrawal, still carries symbolic significance. Last year, the withdrawal of a royal warrant for Gallaher, the manufacturer of Benson & Hedges and Silk Cut cigarettes, was widely interpreted as the palace seeking to take a more sensitive line on health issues.

Harold Brooks-Baker, publishing director of Burke's Peerage, said the loss of the warrant could hit Harrods' prestige and profits, with a reduction in its tourist trade.

He said: "The Royal Warrant is very impressive and very significant because it tells people that this is a business whose products are used by a member of the royal family.

"Warrants are becoming more important, not less, and I think that is a fact that Mr Al Fayed privately recognises. It is not a good day for any business when it loses a royal warrant."

Before the withdrawal of the warrant, a Harrods spokesman maintained the withdrawal of a warrant would have little effect on the store's profitability: "The cachet of royals shopping at Harrods no longer has the same impact."

During the recent libel case brought by Neil Hamilton, Harrods' owner Mr Fayed called the Duke "a Nazi" and alleged that Prince Philip and MI5 were responsible for the death of Mr Fayed's son, Dodi, and Diana, Princess of Wales. It was subsequently reported that the Palace had lost patience with Mr Fayed and would not renew any of the royal warrants granted to Harrods from Prince Philip, the Queen, the Queen Mother and the Prince of Wales. Renewal letters are being sent out to all the holders of the Duke of Edinburgh's royal warrants in the next couple of weeks. The warrants granted by the Queen and the Prince of Wales are not up for review until next year. A spokesman for Harrods said the store had received a letter from Buckingham Palace this morning informing them of the withdrawal of the royal warrant, but he added that no reference had been made to Mr Fayed's libel case comments. "This simply reflects the dwindling patronage between the Duke and Harrods over recent years," the spokesman reiterated. Harrods now has until the end of the year to have the warrant removed from the front of the store and from its stationary and packaging. It received its first royal warrant in 1913 from Queen Mary. Prince Philip's warrant to Harrods was first granted in 1956. For centuries, royal warrants have been granted to trades people and companies who regularly supply goods or services to the monarchy. There are around 920 warrant holders today, who hold over 1,150 royal warrants between them, The head of the royal household, the Lord Chamberlain, advises the Queen, the Duke of Edinburgh, the Queen Mother and the Prince of Wales where to grant warrants, which are renewed every five years and can be revoked at any time. Their issuing of warrants, and their withdrawal, still carries symbolic significance. Last year, the withdrawal of a royal warrant for Gallaher, the manufacturer of Benson & Hedges and Silk Cut cigarettes, was widely interpreted as the palace seeking to take a more sensitive line on health issues. Harold Brooks-Baker, publishing director of Burke's Peerage, said the loss of the warrant could hit Harrods' prestige and profits, with a reduction in its tourist trade. He said: "The Royal Warrant is very impressive and very significant because it tells people that this is a business whose products are used by a member of the royal family. "Warrants are becoming more important, not less, and I think that is a fact that Mr Al Fayed privately recognises. It is not a good day for any business when it loses a royal warrant." Before the withdrawal of the warrant, a Harrods spokesman maintained the withdrawal of a warrant would have little effect on the store's profitability: "The cachet of royals shopping at Harrods no longer has the same impact." fields.headline: Time for him to go
fields.standfirst: Pope on the ropes
fields.trailText: The 13th century pope St Celestine has become one of those figures who emerge from obscurity into the glare of forensic publicity. Why? Because he is the only pope to have voluntarily resigned. Now Pope John Paul II, too, is being urged to retreat to that Polish monastery and spend his remaining years in contemplative prayer.
fields.body:
The 13th century pope St Celestine has become one of those figures who emerge from obscurity into the glare of forensic publicity. Why? Because he is the only pope to have voluntarily resigned. Now Pope John Paul II, too, is being urged to retreat to that Polish monastery and spend his remaining years in contemplative prayer.

While a row rages over how the question of a papal resignation erupted in the Italian media this week - what exactly did Bishop Karl Lehmann, the head of the German bishops' conference mean when he suggested that the Pope should have the courage and confidence to resign if he felt he was no longer "capable"? - the result is that an issue widely believed to be discussed behind episcopal closed doors is now out in the open; exactly where the Curia doesn't want it. After all, Curia officials have plenty to gain from the current scenario: the suffering Pope represents one of the most powerful global media images. As he stoops over his staff, his brow furrowed in agony, or as he bows his shoulders in prayer, he conveys powerfully the message of Catholic Christianity: the pain, the self-sacrifice and the overriding belief in duty.

On a more mundane level, the Curia is able to exploit the Pope's failing energy. The conservative Cardinal Sodano, the Vatican secretary of state, is widely feared as benefiting from the power vacuum. The Curia has always been regarded as an arena for powerful ambitions and agendas and requires a strong pope to keep the factions in balance; but, increasingly, the conservative wing of the Catholic church has the upper hand - the latest example being the resignation in this country of broadcaster Sister Lavinia Byrne, who left her order of nuns this week after pressure from the Vatican. This isn't good for the church. And it is exacerbated by the kind of papacy John Paul II has pioneered. The pontiff is the victim of his own success. On his visits abroad now, more attention is focused on the state of his shaking hands and nodding head than on what he is preaching. This is absurdly self-defeating. The danger is of a lame duck papacy as everyone tries to guess who the Holy Spirit will pick next. In the interim, the Catholic church, with one billion believers, continues to struggle to keep all of them on board.

Furthermore, it is not good for the man. I would not offer the Pope spiritual advice but I find the sight of John Paul II grimacing in physical agony pretty horrible. Surely he deserves, at his ripe age of 79 after decades of devoted service to his church, a peaceful retirement, cared for by sweet-natured nuns in his beloved homeland, with time to listen to birdsong and watch the apple trees blossom? That would send a powerful message about the place rest has always had in God's scheme, on which it would be good for a workaholic western culture to ponder.

It would also conjure up the image of a loving, compassionate God rather than a punitive taskmaster. It looks as though St Celestine in 1294 understood something of this; God may have "called" him (or some powerful Italian princes may have plotted to put him in office) but one look at the job and he issued a papal bull to enable popes to resign, and promptly did so. Wise man.

The pontiff has emphasised that he is called by God to the job and must carry on, but it seems a kind of hubristic lack of faith to think that a) there aren't plenty of men around with the energy and experience to take over and b) that the fate of the Catholic church depends at this juncture in history upon the presence of Karol Wojtyla.

It is a harsh church which drives its servants on until they, quite literally, drop.

webTitle: The head of a billion Catholics faces calls that he should resign

fields.headline: The head of a billion Catholics faces calls that he should resign
fields.standfirst: His decrepitude, conservatism and attitude to women are diminishing his support
fields.trailText: When the Pope bequeathed his millennium message to 50,000 children in St Peter's Square last week, he enlisted their good hearts against the horrendous exploitation of children in the world - economic, sexual and military. But to that he added: "How can we forget the many children who are denied even the right to be born?" Those children in the square, by the time their own bodies begin procreating, will surely hear the Pope's injunction against abortion with even greater scepticism than their parents.
fields.body:
When the Pope bequeathed his millennium message to 50,000 children in St Peter's Square last week, he enlisted their good hearts against the horrendous exploitation of children in the world - economic, sexual and military. But to that he added: "How can we forget the many children who are denied even the right to be born?" Those children in the square, by the time their own bodies begin procreating, will surely hear the Pope's injunction against abortion with even greater scepticism than their parents.

The Pope has already lost these awed children because he has already lost the argument. His reputation as one of the most potent popes of the last century seems assured. But his authority is only almost absolute. The regulation of birth, death, sex and the bodies of women is both his mission and his nemesis.

Abortion is the last bastion of papal misogyny and megalomania. It was always an alibi for the regulation of unruly women. The papal ban on abortion is relatively recent and chimed with 19th century attempts by both secular and religious states to regulate women's bodies and a medley of sexual acts.

Lest we forget, it was the 1861 offences against the person act in Britain that, in its application in Northern Ireland, still prohibits abortion. Secular states have now been forced to relinquish their grip on life and death through control of women's bodies. Women may or may not feel they are ending - or killing - a potential life when they have abortions, but unlike the Pope they also know that the will and wellbeing of the vaunted mother is vital to a child's life.

The Pope and the Catholic hierarchy have created the conditions of their own crisis by their restless and even reckless attention to birth, death and sex. Prohibiting all abortion - rather than abortion after "quickening", that is, after a woman senses the active presence of a baby - the Pope has opened up what he hoped to close down.

Ireland exemplifies the papal crisis. Scandals of sexual abuse and brutalism have blown the church's reputation. Many Catholics balk at confessing their sins to a priest who may have his own sexual secrets. But fundamentalists forced a referendum to copperbottom the constitutional ban on abortion. Many Catholics feared the triumph would paradoxically lead to their demise: by forcing the debate they transformed the taboo. It not only enlisted the nation in a conversation, it created several dialectics.

The notorious Baby X case, in which a girl was sexually abused and left pregnant, tested the limits of the fundamentalists' excess and exposed the impossibility of the constitution. Ultimately the supreme court could not make the girl endure that coerced and criminal pregnancy.

Fr Kevin Hegarty in Mayo, editor of the Catholic journal Ceide, opposed a referendum in the past "because I felt it would damage the Christian consensus". And although it seemed that the traditionalists had won, it was temporary; "They may be in power but they're not in control. It awakened people to the idea that there can't be a moral absolute against abortion."

In Germany, where abortion is still technically illegal without counselling, the church ran counselling centres. Only one in four of their clients proceeded with a pregnancy. When bishops were ordered to pull out of the counselling service, lay Catholics set up their own alternative. The papal intervention caused yet another split in the church.

Events such as those in Ireland and Germany show that a humane church, defined by respect for human rights, has to sort out its relationship to women at the end of the patriarchal era.

fields.headline: Trial by jury
fields.standfirst: Jack Straw's proposal to curb the right of trial by jury is one  of the most contentious issues in the home secretary's plans for  legal reform. He now faces a House Lords rebellion that could  kill it. Mark Tran looks at one of the oldest traditions in the  British legal system
fields.trailText: What is trial by jury
fields.body:
What is trial by jury

The right to a trial by jury is a tradition embedded in the British legal system. The tradition of being "tried by a jury of ones peers" probably has its origins in Anglo Saxon custom, which dictated that an accused man could be acquitted if enough people came forward to swear his innocence.

Trial by jury was first enshrined in law in what has been seen as the world's first proclamation of human rights - the Magna Carta. The document, decreed in 1215 by King John after a rebellion by his barons, stated that a "freeman shall not be... imprisoned... unless by the judgement of his peers".

The right to trial by jury was finally established absolutely in the legal system following the trial of William Penn in 1670. A jury of 12 randomly chosen citizens of London refused to convict the Quaker of "leading a dissident form of worship", despite being directed to by the judge and subjected to imprisonment and starvation in a bid to force their hand.

How does the present system work

Under the current system, the majority of criminal offences can be tried by either magistrates or a judge and jury. At first, the magistrates consider the case. If they decide that it is too serious for them, the accused will automatically be sent to the crown court for trial by jury. But if the magistrates consider themselves able to deal with the case, the accused person has the final say: they have the right to elect for trial by jury.

What is the government proposing

The government wants some defendants to lose the right to choose trial by jury over magistrates' hearing. The government wants to introduce changes which will make the magistrates' decision final. Thus if the magistrates consider the case to be suitable for their court, the accused person cannot overrule them, except by appealing that decision.

The proposed changes affect an Act of 1855 allowing some crimes to be tried by magistrates instead of a higher court if the defendant agreed. The act was designed - like the new proposals - to speed up the legal process. The offences covered included theft, burglary, actual bodily harm and criminal damage. Minor offences, such as drunkenness, could only be tried by magistrates, and major offences, such as murder and rape, only by jury. The government seeks to justify this change essentially on grounds of cost and convenience.

What is Jack Straw's argument

The government says the measure would cut costs and delays. There has been some rhetoric about countering manipulative criminals, who play the system in order to gain time.

What do opponents say

The government's attempt to curb delays will back-fire under the current proposals. In an attempt to safeguard against injustice, the bill will make it possible to appeal if the magistrates refuse to send a case to the crown court to be tried by a judge and jury. Therefore, if there are defendants who are intent on "putting off the evil day" - as the government alleges - there will be a whole new appeal mechanism for them to exploit, before preparations for trial even begin.

Is it true Mr Straw once opposed these changes

Yes. In 1997, he said: "Let me now refer to [Michael Howard's] proposal to end the right of many defendants to elect for trial by jury, even though they may face charges of dishonesty, and their reputation and their whole future may be at stake. Surely, cutting down the right to jury trial, making the system less fair, is not only wrong but short-sighted and likely to prove ineffective. Is it not the case that that is not only the view of the opposition and many practitioners and jurists but was the view of the home secretary, at least until today?"

How does he justify these changes

In an interview in the Observer, Mr Straw said defendants and their lawyers are using the present system to 'string along' the courts by electing for crown court trial and then pleading guilty at the last moment. He told the Observer: "It's true and I do not know a single practitioner, when I put this to them, who does not come out with a wry smile and says 'Yes', every single one."

webTitle: Heard the one about the fat women?

fields.headline: Heard the one about the fat women?
fields.standfirst: It's official: it's OK to be overweight. But only if you're rich and famous, says  Kate Clanchy
fields.trailText: Of course, I think it's great that The Women's Press has brought out Sizeable Reflections, a book about fat women leading fulfilled lives. I believe absolutely that Dawn French and Jo Brand and Jenni Murray are good at their jobs and also very sexy.
fields.body:
Of course, I think it's great that The Women's Press has brought out Sizeable Reflections, a book about fat women leading fulfilled lives. I believe absolutely that Dawn French and Jo Brand and Jenni Murray are good at their jobs and also very sexy.

I also believe that fat people are routinely discriminated against and that the constant scrutiny of the media, diet magazines, thin models, fashion pages and that weird, embryonic-looking Calista Flockhart are all instruments of oppression. Oh yeah and that hipster jeans and the sizing system in Agnès b (I mean, I can't get my arm in those trousers) are not just instruments of oppression but probably a worldwide misogynist conspiracy.

Naturally, I hate worldwide misogynist conspiracies - don't we all? - and I also hate Lynda Lee-Potter for being so horrid in yesterday's Daily Mail about the book and about anyone else, like lovely Kate Winslet, who has happened to put on a pound or two. I also hate being stuck in a changing room with too-small trousers around my knees and my bottom reflected in the mirror like unkneaded dough. I hate the deep, undermining blows experiences like this deal to my sense of self-worth and the pain I see in the faces of my friends when they go through similar experiences. I hate seeing the girls I teach go through anorexia and bulimia, and the circular, mind-numbing tedium of trying to counsel them.

Most of all, I hate the number of hours in my life I have spent learning the calorific value of everything and thinking the thoughts outlined above. I'm bored of them. And I don't think Sizeable Reflections is going to help. It isn't the contributors' fault: after all, they're not advocating solutions, just offering up their exceptional lives as examples.

The problem is that these women are exceptional, not just in being so talented and successful, or even so fat, talented and successful, but in being fat and rich. For, though more than 40% of British women are overweight, they are also disproportionately represented in the working class. It is a commonplace of anti-fattist literature to state that other cultures celebrate fat, but the fact is that such societies usually lack food, so fat means wealth. In our society, fat means poor, or at any rate non-aspirational, and while this is true, it will never be sexy, whatever the example of powerful individuals.

Fat in Britain means cheap, high-fat, processed food and a sedentary working life with poor access to leisure facilities. Fat means Asda - that trim pocket full of change is a lie - or, since the recent take-over, Wal-Mart, with its drive-in cheap food. Have you seen what Wal-Mart has done to the inhabitants of Middle America? Look, next time you tune in to Rikki Lake or see the teenagers stagger away from a gun-wielding classmate on the news. Even the children look as if they've been blown up with a bicycle pump.

The strange thing is that, even though fat is clearly related to what we eat, and what we eat is clearly related to the society we live in and the amount of exercise our society allows us to take, the solutions offered are always individual ones. Diets are lonely and guilt-fuelled, the exception to the rule. Exercise is an extra (probably drive-in) to our lives, not integral. Women are particularly susceptible to guilt and personal responsibility, which is why they diet more. Over Christmas, I read the "food diary" of one of Britain's most fashionable nutritionists. Her diet - and she was rake thin - was strikingly unrelated to the people around her. She lived on her own. She ate alone. She ate only foods that were imported (sinful pecorino cheese!) or out of season ("a passion fruit as a pick-me-up"). When she ate bread, she had to lie down to recover from the starch shock. Nothing she ate was available at Asda, or could have been shared with a family.

This sort of diet is not going to help our ever more obese nation to get thinner, any more than Dawn French can stop me hating my bottom or posh gyms can make the population healthier. Time was when The Women's Press, with its 70s little iron logo, would have advocated collective action. We could have linked arms round Wal-Mart, for instance, bicycled en masse round its car park, picketed Cadbury's or organised a boycott. All horribly uncool now, of course. Collectivism badly needs rebranding. Political action makes you thin? Now, that might have mileage.

 Sizeable Reflections: Big women living full lives is by Shelley Bovey

Even the children look as if they've been blown up with a bicycle pump. The strange thing is that, even though fat is clearly related to what we eat, and what we eat is clearly related to the society we live in and the amount of exercise our society allows us to take, the solutions offered are always individual ones. Diets are lonely and guilt-fuelled, the exception to the rule. Exercise is an extra (probably drive-in) to our lives, not integral. Women are particularly susceptible to guilt and personal responsibility, which is why they diet more. Over Christmas, I read the "food diary" of one of Britain's most fashionable nutritionists. Her diet - and she was rake thin - was strikingly unrelated to the people around her. She lived on her own. She ate alone. She ate only foods that were imported (sinful pecorino cheese!) or out of season ("a passion fruit as a pick-me-up"). When she ate bread, she had to lie down to recover from the starch shock. Nothing she ate was available at Asda, or could have been shared with a family. This sort of diet is not going to help our ever more obese nation to get thinner, any more than Dawn French can stop me hating my bottom or posh gyms can make the population healthier. Time was when The Women's Press, with its 70s little iron logo, would have advocated collective action. We could have linked arms round Wal-Mart, for instance, bicycled en masse round its car park, picketed Cadbury's or organised a boycott. All horribly uncool now, of course. Collectivism badly needs rebranding. Political action makes you thin? Now, that might have mileage.  Sizeable Reflections: Big women living full lives is by Shelley Bovey

fields.headline: Biology is no destiny
fields.standfirst:
Libby Brooks reacts to the latest study showing that women are genetically programmed to prefer tall men
Plus: Mother of all battles
fields.trailText: It's official (again): biology is destiny. Robert Dunbar, an evolutionary psychologist from the University of Liverpool, today reports that tall men are significantly more attractive to women and, consequently, more likely to father children. Women, it would seem, really do want a man they can look up to.
fields.body:
It's official (again): biology is destiny. Robert Dunbar, an evolutionary psychologist from the University of Liverpool, today reports that tall men are significantly more attractive to women and, consequently, more likely to father children. Women, it would seem, really do want a man they can look up to.

In these biologically determined times, everything from youthful criminality to a propensity to enjoy the films of Lars Von Trier are regularly laid at the door of genetics.

The double helix overshadows our woefully predictable lives, denying the human race any personal agency. But, as British neurobiologist Steven Rose would have it: "If biology is indeed destiny, then that destiny is constrained freedom."

There is, of course, something intensely beguiling about being so thoroughly explainable. But if history has taught us anything, it is that there is no unitary principle governing genetic or social change.

And feminists have struggled for many years against reductive notions of gendered characteristics: woman as caring, unambitious nurturer, man as helplessly promiscuous aggressor.

By reducing culture to biology, we develop a fractured relationship with our own free will and responsibility. On the one hand, we are entirely constrained by our genetic history. On the other, biological advances offer an infinitely governable future, where we can manipulate the genetic blueprints of future generations.

In abnegating responsibility for our developing selves, while delving into the dangerous realm of what constitutes a "normal" genetic blueprint, we also reveal a fear of the internal, emotional world that has never been solely governed by the order of our chromosomes. If biology is destiny, then that destiny threatens to be dreary.

Related story and link
It's no tall story that women go for height
The university of Liverpool's psychology department

Mother of all battles

Mother of four Aisling Sykes yesterday won her claim of unfair dismissal against investment bank JP Morgan. A tribunal ruled that the firm was wrong to dismiss the pregnant executive who had offered to work from home so that she could spend more time with her children.

Mrs Sykes, who was told by her employers that her request was akin to someone asking for time off to play squash, noted that there was a prevailing sense in the firm that having more than two children was "viewed as somehow irresponsible".

Is there a career-appropriate average of progeny? How ironic that a multi-million pound enterprise like JP Morgan should conceptualise procreation in terms of greed

Useful links
JP Morgan
Work Unlimited
