fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
Those poor folk down at the Data Protection Register are having a busy new year. Not only have they received numerous complaints about Frank Dobson's handy list of London's 68,000 Labour members, but now the registrar, Elizabeth France, has been inundated with complaints about the use of constituency membership lists provided by sympathetic leftwing MPs to Ken Livingstone. My source close to the bearded one tells me: "We know there have been nine complaints about Ken. He knows perfectly well there's nothing in breach of data protection law in using lists for an internal party contest. It's a case of the pot calling the kettle black." Livingstone's right-hand man, Simon Fletcher, is perplexed. "The Data Protection Register has received a few letters but they haven't had a chance to deal with them yet and we don't know the nature of the complaints. We've always said it was perfectly fine to use the lists. We've never mentioned pots or kettles. It's all very odd." Indeed. And so much washing-up as well.

Cheering news for Charlie Whelan, erstwhile spindoctor to Gordon Brown, who may soon see an end to those long, lonely months in the political wilderness since leaving the treasury. He has been spotted dining in a Westminster curry house with assorted smartly-suited types from Tory Central Office, including none other than William Hague's personal mouthpiece Amanda Platell. My man at Smith Square is convinced that a "more permanent liaison" could be in the offing. Whelan, however, insists on playing his cards close to his chest. "They just invited me for a curry," he splutters. "I'm a member of the Labour party and I hate the Tories. Maybe they thought they could pick up a few tips." So no hope of a new job at Central Office, then? "You're joking! That's the most outrageous smear I've ever heard. If you print that, I'll sue you." A non-denial denial if ever there was one . . .

Those excitable types at the BBC are keenly awaiting the arrival of their new DG, Greg Dyke. And no wonder. The latest issue of Ariel, the Beeb's in-house magazine, offers "an invitation from Greg", to meet the great man himself and hear his introductory words of wisdom in studio six at Television Centre on January 31. Such is the overwhelming demand predicted, staff must enter a ballot to attend, returning a handy cut-out-and-reply slip to be thrown in a hat and picked out at random. The much fairer selection procedure of an electoral college was, sadly, rejected, as was the option of asking employees to complete the statement "I want to meet Greg Dyke because . . ." in no more than 10 words. But for the unlucky ones who don't get picked from the hat, tapes and transcripts will be available afterwards. Please form an orderly queue.

There may be a long waiting list to get a hip replacement, but if it's a rapid rebuttal you want, the NHS can knock one out for you days before you even know you need it. Jonathan Street, a "PR consultant" with the Ambulance Service Association is already on the case of a Panorama programme about paramedics which, he claims in an internal memo, is "a poorly researched and shallow piece of broadcasting that does no credit to Panorama or the BBC". Not that Jonathan has actually seen the programme, which is not due to air until next Monday. The production team can, however, console themselves with the thought that Jonathan does at least plan to video the show.

Congratulations to young James Major and his model wife, Emma Noble, who are having a baby. John and Norma Major are said to be "overjoyed" and, not wanting to be left out, the proud great-uncle-to-be wastes no time in ringing to discuss the happy news. "It's wonderful," trills Terry Major-Ball (for it is he!). "It would be very flattering if they named the baby after me, but I don't think it's very likely, do you?"

The much fairer selection procedure of an electoral college was, sadly, rejected, as was the option of asking employees to complete the statement "I want to meet Greg Dyke because . . ." in no more than 10 words. But for the unlucky ones who don't get picked from the hat, tapes and transcripts will be available afterwards. Please form an orderly queue. There may be a long waiting list to get a hip replacement, but if it's a rapid rebuttal you want, the NHS can knock one out for you days before you even know you need it. Jonathan Street, a "PR consultant" with the Ambulance Service Association is already on the case of a Panorama programme about paramedics which, he claims in an internal memo, is "a poorly researched and shallow piece of broadcasting that does no credit to Panorama or the BBC". Not that Jonathan has actually seen the programme, which is not due to air until next Monday. The production team can, however, console themselves with the thought that Jonathan does at least plan to video the show. Congratulations to young James Major and his model wife, Emma Noble, who are having a baby. John and Norma Major are said to be "overjoyed" and, not wanting to be left out, the proud great-uncle-to-be wastes no time in ringing to discuss the happy news. "It's wonderful," trills Terry Major-Ball (for it is he!). "It would be very flattering if they named the baby after me, but I don't think it's very likely, do you?"

webTitle: Putin to beef up secret service

fields.headline: Putin to beef up secret service
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Vladimir Putin, Russia's acting president, who has spent the bulk of his professional life as a KGB spy, is planning sweeping reforms of Russia's security services as part of his drive to restore the country to its Soviet-era status as a great power, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Vladimir Putin, Russia's acting president, who has spent the bulk of his professional life as a KGB spy, is planning sweeping reforms of Russia's security services as part of his drive to restore the country to its Soviet-era status as a great power, it emerged yesterday.

Mr Putin, who led the FSB, the KGB's successor organisation, has issued a decree making "radical" changes to Russia's national security strategy, officials said yesterday.

The daily newspaper Segodnya reported that the acting president intends to establish a new "super special service" by merging departments of FSB counter-intelligence with elite police departments. The new body, which will combat widespread corruption in Russia, would be modelled on the United States' FBI.

"He'll certainly try to rationalise the security organs," said Dmitri Trenin, a security analyst at Moscow's Carnegie Centre. "There's a real need for law and order and fighting corruption."

"Steps need to be taken ... in very sore areas - notably the fight against corruption, banditry and strengthening the role of law," Anatoly Chubais, an influential Kremlin insider, said yesterday. "The thing most needed is a radical strengthening of the key state functions."

Over the next couple of months' campaigning for the Russian presidency, Mr Putin is expected to promise tough law and order policies which should prove popular with a public fed up with rampant criminality and sleaze.

In the few policy statements he has made in recent weeks, Mr Putin has emphasised the need for a strong Russian state and its "guiding role".

He is seen as a centraliser who will seek to rein in the country's 89 regions and concentrate power in Moscow. His spin doctors are keen to highlight his reputed admiration for Lady Thatcher, triggering talk of the "Iron Man" who learned from the "Iron Lady".

In the communist era, the KGB and its predecessors were key instruments of repression and power in Russia. Although the FSB is not nearly as powerful as the old KGB, Mr Putin was described by the analyst Dmitri Furman as "a post-communist Andropov; an Andropov without the remnants of communist idealism". Yuri Andropov was the KGB chief who became Soviet president in 1982, a position he held until his death in 1984.

Shortly before becoming acting president on New Year's Eve, Mr Putin went to the Lubyanka, the notorious secret police headquarters in Moscow, to deliver a paean to the FSB and its predecessors on the anniversary of the establishment of the Cheka, the revolutionary secret police founded in 1917.

"A few years ago we fell victim to the illusion that we have no enemies. This cost us dearly. Russia has its national interests and we have to defend them," he told an assembly of secret police officers.

Mr Putin's decree on national security strategy, signed on Monday, stresses the need to combat corruption and organised crime.

His shift in emphasis will also affect foreign policy. Foreign states are seeking to deny Russia influence in various parts of the world, the document states. "A threat is also posed by strengthening political and military alliances: first of all Nato's eastward expansion and the possibility of foreign military bases and troops appearing close to Russia's borders."

Mr Putin spent 16 years in the KGB, working in what was then Leningrad (now St Petersburg) and in the communist former East Germany, where he received an award for services rendered from East Germany's powerful Stasi chief, Erich Mielke. German reports this week claimed he also worked as a spy in Bonn in West Germany in the 1970s.

Mr Putin left the KGB as a colonel in 1990. But in July 1998 Boris Yeltsin made Mr Putin the head of the FSB, a post he held until becoming prime minister last August. At the FSB, he rapidly gained a reputation for ruthless streamlining, abolishing three important FSB departments and firing 2,000 employees.

"Putin's arrival was marked by the promotion of [his] former colleagues to top FSB posts," noted Alexei Mukhin, a Moscow analyst.

Mr Yeltsin then made Mr Putin secretary of his advisory security council, a Kremlin post now held by Sergei Ivanov, an old university friend of Mr Putin's. Another key Putin associate, Nikolai Patrushev, now heads the FSB. He joined the KGB in Leningrad in 1975.

Mr Ivanov yesterday signalled that the security council was considering placing curbs on the Russian media.

webTitle: Home office censors report from anti-torture group

fields.headline: Home office censors report from anti-torture group
fields.standfirst: Deaths in custody: special report
fields.trailText: A report today from the European watchdog on torture and degrading treatment which highlights failures in tackling police brutality in England and Wales has been censored by the government.
fields.body:
A report today from the European watchdog on torture and degrading treatment which highlights failures in tackling police brutality in England and Wales has been censored by the government.

Blank spaces appear on four pages where the European committee for the prevention of torture and inhuman and degrading treatment sets out details of four cases in which the Metropolitan police paid damages for injuries to suspects in police custody.

The report, the first to have had passages removed, covers a visit by the committee in September 1997, prompted by concerns that police were escaping accountability for brutality or misconduct.

The committee, which had access to internal Met police documents, was particularly concerned that disciplinary or criminal proceedings rarely followed even large compensation payouts. The excised paragraphs set out advice from the Met's solicitors to the director of the Met complaints and investigation branch, who is responsible for recommending disciplinary proceedings.

The Strasbourg-based committee enforces the European convention for the prevention of torture and inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, ratified by Britain in 1988, which binds 40 of the 41 member states of the Council of Europe. Its remit is to safeguard the rights of prisoners, immigration detainees and those in police custody.

The committee calls for an independent review of all civil claims for assault by police officers in the past two years which have resulted in compensation of £10,000 or more, to reconsider whether criminal or disciplinary proceedings should be taken.

The cases in the report included one where a police dog was allowed to maul a man's leg, leaving him unable to walk properly, which was settled out of court for £40,000.

In none of the four cases were criminal proceedings taken. Only the dog-handler's case resulted in disciplinary charges. But that was not re-opened when the police account of events was discredited in the civil case.

The committee met Barbara Mills, then director of public prosecutions, three home office ministers at the time - Alun Michael, Lord Williams , and Joyce Quin - judge Gerald Butler, who had been appointed to look into crown prosecution service decisions whether to prosecute over deaths in police custody, and representatives of the police complaints authority, the Association of Chief Police Officers and the Police Federation.

The report notes that the information gathered "raises serious questions about the independence and impartiality of the procedures used to process complaints about police misconduct. The delegation's findings also cast doubt upon the efficacy of criminal and/or disciplinary proceedings as legal remedies for police misconduct."

From the beginning of the complaints process, "the police retain a substantial degree of influence over whether criminal and/or disciplinary proceedings are brought against officers who have been the subject of a complaint."

Even when a case got as far as the CPS it had to depend on evidence gathered by an investigating police officer. Only one Met officer in 1996-97 was convicted of a criminal offence as a result of an investigation arising out of a complaint, the report notes. In that year, more than 2,000 complaints involved allegations of assault.

The home office is expected to publish its response to the report in a few weeks.

webTitle: Content is crucial in the net century

fields.headline: Content is crucial in the net century
fields.standfirst:
AOL -Time Warner merger means 'old' media must adapt swiftly to stay in the e-game
Time Warner
America Online
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Think of this column as content. It meets the short-term news deadline of the financial pages - guillotined by press operating times and the space above unit trust prices - but it is increasingly likely to multiply its value through re-use on mobile phone screens, digital television networks, palmtops and (why be humble?) as a film option and a game concept.
fields.body:
Think of this column as content. It meets the short-term news deadline of the financial pages - guillotined by press operating times and the space above unit trust prices - but it is increasingly likely to multiply its value through re-use on mobile phone screens, digital television networks, palmtops and (why be humble?) as a film option and a game concept.

The AOL-Time Warner merger means one thing for traditional editorial and entertainment industries such as ours: in the early years of this "internet century", trusted content will have a value far beyond its initial costs.

Tina Brown knew that as she launched Talk magazine as a vehicle for originating Miramax film projects, and Lonely Planet realised that when it developed its travel book brand as a potentially lucrative source of online travel advice.

It may be e-commerce business plans that are dominating the in-trays and weighing down venture capitalists' desks, but what used to be called "editorial" is going to be an increasingly important means of making those websites attract, retain and gain the confidence of paying e-customers.

What makes Time Warner such a perfect partner for the world's most successful internet service provider is its series of editorial and entertainment "brands", from Friends and People magazine to Eyes Wide Shut and Tori Amos, that can be exploited via new delivery channels.

Alone, these new channels - from websites and entertainment downloads to pay-TV stations and whatever else is next month's new idea - may attract consumers' interest, but will struggle to retain their loyalty.

Certainly the best programmers and technical experts will continue to earn premium salaries for creating the smooth-running systems and clever utilities that add value to internet sites. But it is good quality content that will allow the winners to build loyalty.

This does not mean that traditional media corporations can simply repackage the journalism or moving images that have allowed them to dominate their sectors. It is the failure of some of the biggest to realise this that has allowed upstart start-ups to make those multi-billion internet land grabs.

Old and new

"Old" media must adapt quickly to provide what consumers of "new" media demand: the opportunity to interact with websites and with like-minded consumers; the option to personalise the services they receive and to choose the particular content that they want (even if it is not what editors or producers have traditionally chosen to give them) and when they want (even if this means replacing conventional deadlines with instant fulfilment); and the freedom to do so without handing over money in a conventional manner.

But if they understand the opportunities created by the online revolution, and can access the delivery channel that an AOL platform or WAP mobile phone allows, then content providers will be among the internet's winners.

Nor will consumers pay for services according to the conventional subscription model. Time Warner or Sky may be able to debit a credit card each time a film is downloaded or concert viewed in real time, and an online Wall Street Journal may entice paying customers who believe the knowledge gained might improve their own finances, but as Slate, Microsoft's own online magazine, soon learned, in general you cannot charge a monthly fee for content without limiting your growth to a suicidal extent.

What you can do is create partnerships - the travel trade venture that needs trusted travel content to boost its web traffic, the Freeserve that covets the young families market and so spends a few million acquiring the Babyworld e-zine - and other means of exploiting the same material.

Commission a magazine piece that your film subsidiary can option, followed by your book subsidiary and your e-commerce site, and then promote the final product on your interactive TV channel and then in interviews in your magazine. It's called synergy. Content providers do not necessarily need to own the channels of distribution in order to prosper.

A recent internet trend has been the rise of the "aggregator" - a trusted source of other people's content.

American website iSyndicate.com sells content to 160,000 websites, under a promise that it comprises content from more than 600 web providers: "With fresh syndicated content, your customers will visit more often, stay longer and have a better experience on your site."

Making headlines

Moreover.com makes available news headlines in a number of specialist categories that you can add to your website at no cost; your site's users must click through to Moreover's site to read the full stories.

A significant proportion of visitors to the Guardian Unlimited network come through our own content distribution service, which offers our headlines to other people's sites again at no charge.

There is plenty of mediocre content on the web that demands filtering. That is why a trusted editorial service will always have a value - whether a billion-dollar publishing empire, or a shoestring "web-log" service that tips off users about the gems its editors have uncovered.

And when users discover, and bookmark, the content that they find rewarding - a Time Warner product, perhaps, or a Guardian Unlimited site - they will add to it the value that represents the internet's holy grail: loyalty, whether expressed as "eyeballs" or "stickiness".

What happens next neither you, Bill Gates nor I can predict with certainty. But for the moment, content is key.

 David Rowan is editor of Guardian Unlimited

webTitle: Sage buys out US software firm

fields.headline: Sage buys out US software firm
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Sage
Best Software
fields.trailText: Sage shrugged aside its defeat earlier this week in the takeover battle for software provider Pegasus by unveiling a $445m (£272m) agreed offer yesterday for American company Best Software.
fields.body:
Sage shrugged aside its defeat earlier this week in the takeover battle for software provider Pegasus by unveiling a $445m (£272m) agreed offer yesterday for American company Best Software.

Sage, which specialises in accountancy software, is offering $35 in cash for each share in Best, a 24% premium on the value of the shares on Monday night. The offer is to be financed by the placing of 43.7m new Sage shares, 3.6% of the company's current share capital. The shares were placed at 680p a share last night.

The market responded positively to the news, marking Sage shares up by 27p to 717.5p at close.

Best provides asset management software, specialising in budgeting, fixed assets and payroll software.

Sage said the deal would give it access to a much expanded market in the United States. Best has 49,000 licensed customers as well as a raft of consultancy, support and service agreements.

Sage will put its own brand on to Best products, and hopes to rescale Best's products to make them relevant to smaller businesses, rather than medium-sized as at present.

Paul Walker, Sage group chief executive, said: "Best's leading position in fixed assets, payroll and budgeting software complements Sage's existing strength in core accounting software." Mr Walker added that Best's internet technology, labelled Imperativ, would enable Sage to accelerate the launch of its web-based management and payroll applications in the US market.

Sage said last month that it was developing ways to offer its software online, in effect allowing companies to rent the software from a central server rather than paying a licence.

fields.standfirst:
Sports stars take on the net
E-finance: special report
Sports.com
fields.trailText: US sports stars Michael Jordan and Tiger Woods have joined the rush for a slice of Europe's fast-growing internet market, sinking more than $1m (£600,000) each into internet group Sports.com. The company said yesterday a second funding round had raised $52.5m - more than the original $49m it said it was seeking in December.
fields.body:
US sports stars Michael Jordan and Tiger Woods have joined the rush for a slice of Europe's fast-growing internet market, sinking more than $1m (£600,000) each into internet group Sports.com. The company said yesterday a second funding round had raised $52.5m - more than the original $49m it said it was seeking in December.

Sports.com, created in May last year, is the European majority-owned subsidiary of Nasdaq-listed SportsLine.com. Mr Jordan, Shaquille O'Neal and Mr Woods are all already shareholders in Sports-Line.com, which publishes their official websites.

Other investors in the issue of preferred stock include affiliates of Soros Private Equity Partners, private equity group Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, Chase Capital Partners, Aetna Life Insurance, Goldman Sachs and Wit Capital's Arista Capital Partners.

SportsLine's flagship internet sports service is CBS SportsLine, under an agreement with CBS Sports.

webTitle: C&W reinvents itself with European internet sweep

fields.headline: C&W reinvents itself with European internet sweep
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
C & W
Compaq
One2One
MCI
Optus
fields.trailText: Cable & Wireless is poised to announce a string of deals across mainland Europe sweeping up business-to-business internet service providers with a combined value of about £310m.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless is poised to announce a string of deals across mainland Europe sweeping up business-to-business internet service providers with a combined value of about £310m.

The acquisitions are an important part of the reinvention of C&W being wrought by chief executive Graham Wallace, refocusing it from consumer to higher growth corporate data and internet markets. One of the largest buys is understood to be in France and the deals could be announced today.

Shares in the company, which missed the telecoms boom, caught fire in mid-November at about 665p as investors began to take notice of Mr Wallace's strategy. They climbed more than 7% yesterday to close at 972.5p.

The company recently announced plans to invest £2bn building high bandwidth networks worldwide adding to the internet business and infrastructure it acquired from MCI in the US in 1998. But the defining deal will be the disposal of the group's 54% stake in Hong Kong Telecom expected this year. Part of the share price rise is the anticipation that this sale could turn C&W into a takeover target. The group is also expected to break up its Optus business in Australia before disposing of its consumer division.

fields.headline: Mandelson 'made dome third rate'
fields.standfirst:
Former design chief blames 'interfering' minister for missed opportunity
The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: The Millennium Dome might have been saved from becoming a "mad woman's breakfast" if Peter Mandelson had kept his nose out if it, its former design guru claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
The Millennium Dome might have been saved from becoming a "mad woman's breakfast" if Peter Mandelson had kept his nose out if it, its former design guru claimed yesterday.

Stephen Bayley, who has been barred from the Greenwich site since he resigned as the dome's creative director two-and-a-half years ago, said political interference and a mixture of "crassness and incompetence" had wasted the greatest opportunity of our age.

In his first interview since the dome opened he claimed basic mistakes had been made because experts were neither listened to nor given creative freedom.

His early warnings about the quality of the contents and the confusing muddle of zones were not heeded.

"I wanted the best brains, artists and architects in the world to work on this. They said: 'no, you can't have them'. Instead they got a lot people who usually do trade fairs in Harrogate," he said.

"It's not their fault. They were asked to design with no brief. Nobody had thought anything through."

The politicians, and particular Mr Mandelson, the former minister for the dome, who Mr Bayley described as a "paradigm of bad management", must take the lion's share of the blame.

"The real scandal was that they were told, not just by me, but by many others, how to put it right, and they ignored that advice," he claimed. "I hate to say I told you so, but I did and they did not listen. They could not bear to listen to anyone who knew what they were talking about."

Mr Bayley's comments come as several designers who worked on the dome, and who still feel gagged by confidentiality clauses in their contracts, expressed disappointment with the results.

Nigel Coates who designed the Body Zone, described the dome as a curate's egg. Fellow architect Zaha Hadid said it was not radical enough, with management assuming "every visitor is an idiot who can't understand complicated ideas".

Others bemoaned the lack of an overall design guru. That was the role Mr Bayley quit "when I realised they would not allow me to do my job".

Muddle

Nearly all the designers complained about a culture of secrecy at the New Millennium Experience Company, which kept them from communicating with each other. "It is any wonder that it is a muddle when designers were not allowed to talk to one another," said Mr Bayley.

Mr Bayley said he was so unhappy with the content when he took over three years ago that he asked to put a stop to everything for six months to figure out what the dome was supposed to be about.

"It was a risk. But it could have been saved then. Instead they went on and spent £750m and we still don't know what it is for."

He said his pleas to employ a masterplanner of the calibre of Sir Norman Foster to "make some sense of the mess" were not just ignored but energetically rejected by Mr Mandelson.

"The results are unfortunately there for all to see," he added.

Mr Bayley said his vision was for a "dome of the future" where Tesco would have paid architects like Frank Gehry, the man behind the Guggenheim museum in Bilbao, to design the shop of future complete with the foods of the future which people could buy. Guinness could have had the drinks of the future, and Ford the cars and transport of the future.

"People want voyeurism and surprise. Instead what we got was muddle and a lot of bad school projects," he said.

Mr Bayley, who founded the Design Museum, in London, said there was a nasty, secretive atmosphere inside the NMEC.

"There is no one in charge who knows what it is all for and about. That is why they are so glum and depressed and paranoid and afraid of any criticism, because they are confused in themselves."

But Mr Bayley reserved his greatest ire for the Litmus Group of the great and the good who vetted the quality of the content. "I don't so much blame Michael Grade, because he is just a businessman, but Alan Yentob [of the BBC], Christopher Frayling [of the Royal College of Art] and Neil Cossons of the Science Museum in London, are public servants who should have known better.

"They have betrayed the trust of the public and chosen to be placemen, who have suspended their artistic judgment for political preferment."

A NMEC spokesman said they never expected "people who walked away from us early on would come back into the dome with an open mind and say: 'It's great.'

"I understand also that Stephen Bayley would have strong views on the Litmus Group, since they effectively replaced him. They are all unpaid and have done some great work. They have all spent their ca reers in entertainment or education and we are grateful to them. Comments of this type are not helpful," he said.

"We found that after the experience of working with Stephen over six months, a single curatorial auteur was not going to work with a project of this complexity."

He denied that Peter Mandelson had a baleful influence on the company. "Peter did not set up the NMEC. He simply strengthened the management structures. It is a unique hybrid. There is a large dollop of the civil service and a large dollop of the private sector.

"Each side may find the other frustrating at times. We would have wanted an extra year but the lateness of the last election saw to that."

The spokesman insisted that the claims of excessive secrecy were unjust.

"A lot of people, including the designers have misunderstood this. The confidentiality applies to commercial matters only."

webTitle: Procrastinating Blair risks humiliation by his enemies

fields.headline: Procrastinating Blair risks humiliation by his enemies
fields.standfirst:
The prime minister shows weakness in his approach to the euro agenda

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The current issue on the euro is no longer whether Britain enters the single currency, but whether the prime minister remains in command of making that decision. The great controller may be losing control. It is a dismal spectacle, and not just for people who believe that, other things being equal, entry will soon become a vital national interest. Mr Blair's plight, which is quite largely self-inflicted, throws a startling light on the workings of modern democracy.
fields.body:
The current issue on the euro is no longer whether Britain enters the single currency, but whether the prime minister remains in command of making that decision. The great controller may be losing control. It is a dismal spectacle, and not just for people who believe that, other things being equal, entry will soon become a vital national interest. Mr Blair's plight, which is quite largely self-inflicted, throws a startling light on the workings of modern democracy.

Here is a leader who won a majority of 179 in elections to our national democratic forum. He's in a position of overwhelming political strength. He can look forward with more confidence than any leader before him to a repeat performance, albeit with the margin somewhat reduced, at the next election. Yet the ground is being prepared beneath him to destroy, without a democratic test, the project that forms a central part of his strategy, and he is doing almost nothing to stop such insidious pre-emption. He begins to approach the brink of an historic humiliation.

His ministers jostle to supply their nuances. For the referendum is the critical decision: to hold it in the next parliament, or not. The trade secretary notes that inward investors are telling him there's an urgent need for clarity and a lower exchange rate. The foreign secretary says every rational member of the public must want a referendum early in the next parliament. But every time a minister speaks like this, Downing Street rushes to say their words shouldn't be taken seriously. The most powerful of modern prime ministers resists the slightest deviance from safe neutrality, essentially because he is afraid. There hasn't been a more telling contradiction since the Baroness, while deeply integrating Britain with Europe via the single European act, was urging the Brits to loathe most things Europe stood for. Mr Blair begins to look like someone doing exactly the opposite

For there's no doubt he wants sterling to join the euro. He is a genuine European. He believes Europe is the future, and knows that his ambitions to be a leader there cannot be fulfilled from outside the euro-zone. So long as that decision remains in suspense, the rest of the EU will not treat the UK with complete fraternity. There will always be a contingent doubt. Once it became clear the referendum will not be held, reserve would turn to chilliness, and semi-intimacy to slow disintegration.

Understanding this more deeply than I do, Mr Blair is evidently wracked by worry. He knows what he should do, but is not willing to start contriving the circumstances in which he can do it. His anxieties may be sufficiently enveloping to survive another huge election victory, and the arguable achievement - arguable even now - of the flexible five economic conditions the government has long set as a precondition. Two forces move him, and are capable of continuing to do so.

The first is the press, to which he attaches even more significance than when he was merely leader of the opposition. Although his prime concern is to keep Murdoch and others on side for the election, the paranoia may well subsist after that. It is certain to do so if the electoral bargain has been conditional on exclusion of the euro from the campaign. If such an exclusion is agreed, there will not have been a more glaring example in recent history of a prime minister, least of all a very strong one, permitting his agenda to be set by his enemies. But that is what's in danger of happening: to keep the tycoon sweet, abandon into silence the issue that's supposed to matter most to your next administration.

Blair's answer to all this is that he is talking about Europe as ground-work for talking about the euro at some later point when the people are readier to listen. He has made some good speeches in this sense, and Robin Cook now weighs in too. But the studious distinction is cutting little ice. Nobody hears the generalised pro-Europe speeches, because they evade the issue everyone knows is the one that matters. Only the euro has the hard edge of reality. By elaborately avoiding it, the government is conceding its opponents' point, and encouraging the belief that perhaps Europe and the euro are indeed separable: that you might, after all, have one without the other.

The second force Mr Blair is watching out for is Gordon Brown. Mr Brown, like Mr Blair, remains a European. But he has other fish to fry. Though he's an architect of the idea that Europe should be addressed, while the euro is off-limits, somehow a major pro-Europe speech of even the loftiest kind is so far missing from the contemporary Brown canon.

What Brown is defending into the distant and uncertain future are our flexible friends, the five economic conditions. And what is beginning to dawn is that here he has a lock on Mr Blair. It is he rather than the prime minister who owns them, and will be the judge of them. In reality he has a veto on a decision Blair might want to make, but Blair has no equivalent override on a Brown objection. If Brown remained committed against a referendum - or, more to the point, if Blair believed that Brown's commitment was in danger of revealing a public split between them - it would, to say the least, add to his other inhibitions. These men may be brothers, but the gleam of personal ambition should not be underrated in the one, nor the fear of it in the other.

The reason such calculations become real, I agree, is that there's much evidence of the euro's unpopularity. The battle will be hard to win. Five years of unrebutted anti-euro propaganda, relentlessly pumped out by newspapers that matter, may not have succeeded in putting the currency question high among most voters' concerns. But it leaves the government shivering on the back foot, a contortion made more undignified by Blair's assertions that here is one pitch where he intended to take Britain further down the wicket than anyone since Ted Heath.

We are thus witness to a barely credible spectacle. A government committed to entering the euro declines to mobilise either political or economic management to achieve that purpose. It watches, mesmerised, while its enemies gather. A perverse new logic awaits apotheosis. This says that not holding the referendum may now be the "European" thing to do. Since defeat would not only damage Blair but be a hammer-blow against support for continuing EU membership, better not to risk it. For the sake of staying in the EU, don't even try for the euro.

Has it come to that? Not yet. But political timidity is capable of producing a catastrophe which would bestow on Tony Blair a shocking epitaph: Here lies the man who did less than Margaret Thatcher for the integration of Britain with Europe.

webTitle: Commons sketch: Home secretary frees Pinochet, to Straw's dismay

fields.headline: Commons sketch: Home secretary frees Pinochet, to Straw's dismay
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: One of the most prominent campaigners against General Pinochet made his sorrowful way to the Commons yesterday.
fields.body:
One of the most prominent campaigners against General Pinochet made his sorrowful way to the Commons yesterday.

You had to feel deep pity for the man. All those years of protest, the cold vigils outside the embassy, the visits to Chile, the clandestine meetings with activists risking their lives so that their passionate demands for justice might be heard - all dashed by a single announcement, smuggled out to the media late on Tuesday night, made by a rightwing home secretary who apparently cares nothing for the Chilean people who suffered under the rifles and jackboots of the Pinochet regime.

The fact that the activist and the home secretary, Jack Straw, are one and the same must have been scant consolation to him.

You kept feeling he would have been much happier standing outside the house with a banner, shouting: "Hey, Straw, what's that for? How about the innumerable innocent victims of Pinochet's secret war?" Or something snappy along those lines.

As it is, the home secretary was incredibly lucky. For much of Tuesday night and all of yesterday, Labour MPs were fuming about his decision to let the general go.

Given that most Tories support his decision, he must have expected a terrible roasting from his own side.

In the end he was barely touched, except by a few slight and glancing blows.

Ann Widdecombe wanted to know why he had not made his announcement first to the Commons, which is the opposition's default whinge when they haven't anything else to moan about. (She did talk about "bungling and incompetence", but that is routine boilerplate too.)

He had arrested "Senator" Pinochet ("Senator" is a meaningless courtesy title, rather like "Lord" Jeffrey Archer) while he lay in his bed - whereas, she implied, Nazi war criminals were leaving the country hourly on chartered 747s.

Mr Straw said vaguely that he had not personally felt the general's collar, and that was that.

Tam Dalyell, never someone with a ready kind word for the government, clearly felt the decision was right. The decision should be made not in Madrid, or London, but in Santiago.

Then up stood Bob Marshall-Andrews, the Labour rebels' rebel, a man who, with his uncontrollable hair and wild demeanour, looks like a particularly well-fed hermit.

Surely he would summon up all his powers of oratory and persuasion to denounce the home secretary's decision. He began very grandly: "May I offer what limited support I can for what has fallen from the home secretary _"

Fallen from him? Is Jack Straw coming to bits? Was he offering a jockstrap? Do they have to sweep up vital organs when he leaves the chamber?

Those who had made common cause with Mr Straw after the murder of Allende and the nightmare of Chile, he said, knew that he had nothing to prove to himself, to the house or to the international community.

As a lawyer, Mr Marshall-Andrews knows that you get paid by the yard, not by re sults. It looked as if the jury had another few hours to go before they could retire.

"This odious man has been effectively tried in an English court; his crimes and infamy have been revealed."

On and on he went. "It has been found, as a matter of law _" The Tories began to grumble. Where was his question? Westminster's shaggiest QC paused, but only to draw breath.

"My Lord," he addressed the speaker, and it was not only the Tories who collapsed in helpless laughter.

(As I came to work by tube, I noticed that anarchists had put up stickers saying: "Queen Mum: hurry up and die." I suspect Jack Straw feels much the same way about the general.)

webTitle: Watchdog urges new rights for accused MPs

fields.headline: Watchdog urges new rights for accused MPs
fields.standfirst:
Neill report: Committee urges limit on number of special advisers, more openness on sponsors, and curbs on task forces set up by Labour

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: MPs accused of serious misconduct should get legal aid from the taxpayer to be able to challenge the findings of an investigation of the parliamentary commissioner for standards, Lord Neill recommended yesterday.
fields.body:
MPs accused of serious misconduct should get legal aid from the taxpayer to be able to challenge the findings of an investigation of the parliamentary commissioner for standards, Lord Neill recommended yesterday.

The report recommends sweeping changes in the appeal procedures for MPs facing misconduct charges in the wake of the row over the "cash for questions" scandal. This case led to controversy after Sir Gordon Downey, the former parliamentary commissioner for standards, found "compelling" evidence that former minister, Neil Hamilton, had taken up to £25,000 in cash from Harrods owner, Mohamed Al Fayed, for asking questions in the Commons. Sir Gordon's verdict was endorsed by a libel court jury last month.

The report by the committee on standards in public life also recommends new limits on the number of special advisers; a new civil service act to enforce a code of conduct for political advisers; curbs on task forces set up by the Labour government; the recording of all formal meetings with lobbyists and ministers; and the disclosure of sponsorship of government events above £5,000.

MPs

Lord Neill's recommendations on reforming investigations into MPs echo the findings of Lord Nicholls, who chaired a joint Commons and Lords investigation into parliamentary privilege last year.

Both he and Lord Neill say that the bribery and corruption laws should be extended to MPs and those who bribe MPs. The home office says that Jack Straw is keen in principle to introduce a new law but is reviewing the details.

Lord Neill recommends that where MPs are accused of serious conduct which falls short of bribery they should be entitled to challenge the findings of the parliamentary commissioner. The appeal would initially be heard by a tribunal of two to four senior MPs chaired by a lawyer. The MP would get legal aid and the tribunal would re-assess the facts and decide whether the charges are proved. The MP could appeal on this decision to another body chaired by a former judge. Lord Neill recommends that the hearings should be held in public but not broadcast.

He said yesterday: "These cases are very grave cases where the result of being found guilty is in effect to lead to the end of the MP's career. We consider that in cases of that gravity the defendant should have access to public money."

He also recommends that the composition of the standards and privileges committee should be changed, with more senior MPs sitting on judgment of their peers. The chairman of the committee should be a member of the opposition rather than, as now, a senior government backbencher.

Advisers

The report recommends that Westminster follows the Scottish parliament and the Welsh assembly and limits the number of special advisers, and urges that their activities be subject to a code of conduct which could be backed by law through a new civil service act. This code will include spelling out relations between special advisers and their conduct with the media and civil servants . But Lord Neill dismissed suggestions that special advisers had necessarily broken Whitehall rules.

The number of special advisers appointed by the government is now 74 - up from 38 at the beginning of 1997. They are employed at a cost of £3.9 million to the taxpayer.

"The considerable increase in numbers, particularly at No 10 where influential roles are played by special advisers raises the question of whether their authority outweighs that of objective advisers," the report said. The report says a new code of conduct should make clear that special advisers had a specific duty to uphold the impartiality of the civil service as well as regulating their contacts with the media.

Lord Neill said that while the committee had not concluded that there had been a "politicisation" of the civil service, they believed that the time had now come to "take stock" of the situation.

He said that he would "deplore" any spin doctor who briefed journalists on behalf of their minister against rival members of the government.

Lobbyists

He rejects the need for the registration of lobbyists but accepts evidence from Observer journalist Greg Palast that records of meetings between lobbyists and ministers, civil servants and special advisers should be kept. But he provides a loophole for special advisers - by saying they should only record meetings where the lobbyist tries to influence people rather than seek information.

Lord Neill said that even the recorded information will remain secret for 30 years under the present freedom of information act because it will relates "to the formulation or development of policy".

Sponsors

The report accepts that government departments - notably the foreign office - have a right to get private company sponsorship for conferences and events. But Lord Neill introduces caveats, including putting the onus on ministers seeking sponsorship to ensure that this is in the public interest. He says departments must publish details of all deals exceeding £5,000.

Lord Neill's committee has much stronger views about the politicisation of the NHS. It warns that the present system - which has seen a huge increase in political appointments under Labour - has caused "considerable disquite" and welcomes the present inquiry being undertaken by Dame Rennie Fitch, the public appointments commisisoner, into its operation.

Patronage

Lord Neill also calls for restrictions on Labour's creation of 44 task forces from industry and research bodies to investigate problems from social exclusion to problems on housing estates.

He expresses concern that they could be a new form of political patronage under Labour and says they should only have a limited life to investigate particular problems. Any body lasting more than two years should be disbanded or become a properly accountable quango.

Main points

 MPs caught taking bribes to face criminal charges

 Legal aid for MPs accused of serious misconduct by the parliamentary commissioner

 Prime minister to investigate ministers accused of serious misconduct

 Ministers must record all meetings with lobbyists

 Disquiet about NHS trust and authority appointment system

 Sponsorship of government conferences and events above £5,000 must be declared

 Labour's new task force bodies must be disbanded within two years or be subject to strict rules on appointments

webTitle: Ministers escape scrutiny by independent watchdog

fields.headline: Ministers escape scrutiny by independent watchdog
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Lord Neill last night came under attack for "funking the issue" of misconduct and corruption at the top of government by ruling out the appointment of an ethics commissioner to investigate allegations against ministers in the wake of the Jonathan Aitken scandal.
fields.body:
Lord Neill last night came under attack for "funking the issue" of misconduct and corruption at the top of government by ruling out the appointment of an ethics commissioner to investigate allegations against ministers in the wake of the Jonathan Aitken scandal.

Academics and the Liberal Democrats attacked his wide-ranging report on reinforcing standards in public life for leaving Tony Blair and the cabinet secretary with sole responsibility to decide whether a minister accused of serious misconduct should quit.

Lord Neill also recommended limiting the number of special advisers appointed by the government and the introduction of a code of conduct to reign in some of their activities.

In a BBC radio interview he suggested that the limit could be as high as 100 - 26 more than are currently on the payroll.

Lord Neill took the decision to rule out appointing an independent investigator after receiving what one member of his committee called compelling evidence from Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, and Lord Butler, his predecessor.

In doing so he ignored evidence from Sir George Young, the shadow leader of the Commons; David Davis, Conservative chairman of the Commons public accounts committee; Peter Hennessy, professor of contemporary history at Queen Mary's College, London; Peter Preston, former editor of the Guardian; and the Times commentator Peter Riddell. All had called for an independent investigator or body to handle future inquiries after the Guardian libel case proved that Mr Aitken had lied to John Major and Lord Butler about his Ritz Hotel bill in Paris being paid by an arms dealer.

Sir Richard had argued that the cabinet secretary did not have the skills to undertake investigations, but permanent secretaries should be able to advise ministers accused of misconduct. Lord Butler argued that an independent commissioner would be used to score party political points.

Last night Stuart Weir, director of Democratic Audit, said: "Lord Neill has funked this issue. He still seems to believe that all ministers are trustworthy, honourable people and therefore one just leaves it to their own judgment. This is plainly wrong."

Alan Beith, deputy leader of the Liberal Democrats, said: "Lord Neill has left unfinished business and a gap in public accountability. We do need an independent person. It is quite obvious that the prime minister has got far too many other things to do than hold personal inquiries into his cabinet colleagues."

Mr Preston said: "This is an extremely disappointing and very feeble decision. It just makes a nonsense of the situation to say that there is a ministerial code of conduct which cannot be enforced by anybody outside."

Much of the rest of the report was welcomed by Conservatives and Liberal Democrats, provided the government implemented the proposals.

Mo Mowlam, the cabinet office minister, said the government would need time to study the report's detailed recommendations, but she strongly defended its use of special advisers.

Ms Mowlam said: "We have made no secret of the number of advisers, their cost or their work. Their role, to provide strong central support and political focus, is clearly defined. Cabinet ministers are required to obtain the prime minister's approval for all appointments of special advisers. The government is totally committed to maintaining a non-political service and has given a commitment to legislation for the civil service, as and when a suitable opportunity arises."

On the question of special advisers, the report recommends that Westminster follows the Scottish parliament and the Welsh assembly and limits their number, and urges that their activities be subject to a code of conduct to spell out relations between special advisers and their conduct with the media and civil servants.

The current government has appointed 74 such advistors - an increase from 38 at the beginning of 1997 - employed at a cost of £3.9m to the taxpayer.

Lord Neill added that he would "deplore" spin doctors briefing journalists on behalf of their minister against rival members of the government.

fields.headline: Right to Di
fields.trailText: There is only one case which the Diana memorial fund is pursuing against Franklin Mint (Diana fund faces £1m bill over memorabilia case, January 6). We shall only know which side faces bills for costs or damages when the trial takes place in June.
fields.body:
There is only one case which the Diana memorial fund is pursuing against Franklin Mint (Diana fund faces £1m bill over memorabilia case, January 6). We shall only know which side faces bills for costs or damages when the trial takes place in June.

One part of our case - relating to rights of publicity - was struck out in September 1998, but our legal advisers will ask the court to reinstate it on the basis of a tough new California statute. This refutes your claim that "the collector's plate does not violate Diana's rights" and your suggestion that more US firms will now cash in on the market of unauthorised Diana goods.
Dr Andrew Purkis
Diana Princess of Wales Memorial Fund

fields.headline: Perils of net shopping
fields.trailText: Gary Glitter isn't the only one from whom an apology should be forthcoming (Nervous Glitter apologises after leaving jail, January 12). A local Our Price had Gary Glitter CDs for sale at Christmas.
fields.body:
Gary Glitter isn't the only one from whom an apology should be forthcoming (Nervous Glitter apologises after leaving jail, January 12). A local Our Price had Gary Glitter CDs for sale at Christmas.

A spokesperson informed me that Our Price could see no reason to withdraw Glitter's material from sale. I am shocked by their their apparent indifference to the plight of sexually abused children.
P Murphy
Doncaster, S Yorks

You call for a cultural change in the MoD's dealings with the defence industry (Comment, January 12). The government has introduced the smart procurement initiative for precisely this reason and to deliver clear improvements in the way we supply our armed forces. It is a radical change which is already achieving results - not least with the Bowman project.
Baroness Symons
Minister of state for defence procurement

I have recently started using Tesco Internet to supply my home groceries. Sometimes they can't supply the requested items and send substitutes. My latest delivery should have included an 800g medium sliced organic wholemeal loaf. The substitute was a Durex Fetherlite pack of 18. My major concern is how do I spread my peanut butter whilst practising safe sex?
Richard Thompson
Weybridge, Surrey
thassoc@csi.com

If "the ticket office at Blackfriars was open as normal" (Report, January 11, 2000), it's no wonder Cherie Booth wasn't able to buy a ticket.
David Hunt
London
dhunt@uswebcks.com

"Poison pen is eating away Bach's manuscripts" (January 11). Presumably just decomposing.
R Epton
Brigg, N Lincs
raepton@hotmail.com

fields.headline: All G-ed up about Ali
fields.trailText: Since when were ignorance and pomposity off-limits to comedians (Comics find Ali G is an alibi for racism, G2, January 12)? Sacha Baron Cohen's Ali G is that rare thing, a work of comic genius that has caught the national imagination because it is both funny and true.
fields.body:
Since when were ignorance and pomposity off-limits to comedians (Comics find Ali G is an alibi for racism, G2, January 12)? Sacha Baron Cohen's Ali G is that rare thing, a work of comic genius that has caught the national imagination because it is both funny and true.

Are we saying black people are incapable of ignorance and pomposity? Or that, though they are capable of them, this should never be commented upon? Sounds like racism to me.
Tim Knapman
Weybridge, Surrey

The most offensive things are his disdain for the sensitivities of women and the manner in which he trivialises issues people have fought and suffered for. I assume the nub of the so-called humour is that many of those "interviewed" take themselves too seriously, in some cases to the point of appearing pompous. But if you happen to be a teacher, a supporter of the miners' strike, a socialist, a feminist, or someone who has lost loved ones in war, the repeated trivialisation by Ali G is offensive. Which issues would he consider too near the mark; child abuse, pornography, institutionalised racism?
David Roberts
Curry Rivel, Somerset
su3072@eclipse.co.uk

The aspect of his humour which is offensive is its ageism. All his interviewees are older people and the underpinning device is to make fun of their incomprehension of street language and culture. Its most distasteful manifestation was a scene in a nursing home where the residents played unwitting stooges. Satire based on lampooning aspects of black or white gangster cultures for their inarticulacy and misogyny may be defensible, but humour achieved simply by virtue of people being of a different generation is just cheap.
Hilary and Nick Gould
Norton St Philip, Somerset

It is the identity of Ali G's interviewees, rather than his own identity, which determines whether he is funny. When they are public or powerful figures I find it funny; when he plays the same game on an ordinary bloke trying to do his job, I cringe.
Jennifer Macwhinnie
London

To argue it might not be OK to laugh at Ali G becuse others may not "get" the right joke smacks of middle-class intellectual elitism.
Sue Rumfitt
Bedford
SueRumfitt@compuserve.com

If I can't laugh at Ali G, I don't think I have right to laugh at all. Respect and keep it real!
Kamal Mustapha
London
kmustapha@bgvpha.org.uk

fields.headline: Reassurance from Lloyd's of London
fields.trailText: Reading Godfrey Hodgson (Lloyd's on the rocks, January 11), one could almost be forgiven for thinking that the past eight years did not happen. The process called reconstruction and renewal secured the insurance market's future after the 1988-92 losses.
fields.body:
Reading Godfrey Hodgson (Lloyd's on the rocks, January 11), one could almost be forgiven for thinking that the past eight years did not happen. The process called reconstruction and renewal secured the insurance market's future after the 1988-92 losses.

Many of the allegations aired in Mr Hodgson's piece date from before this period. With proceedings pending, you will undoubtedly understand that Lloyd's is unable to comment on these in any detail.

But Mr Hodgson paints Lloyd's as a rather crusty British anachronism more suited to high tea than high finance. In reality, almost half of Lloyd's £10bn capital comes from international insurance companies who see the market as an integral part of their business strategies. Mr Hodgson also seems to suggest that Lloyd's is becoming irrelevant to the world of industry and commerce. Why then do over three-quarters of FTSE 100 companies and 80% of Dow Jones have policies at Lloyd's?

But most astounding is his suggestion that Lloyd's itself is on the rocks. This is a market backed by more than £15bn in assets and with a newly confirmed A+ financial security rating from the US rating agency, Standard & Poors. For a marketplace apparently on the verge of an historic crisis, our vital signs are looking surprisingly positive.
Andrew Duguid
Lloyd's
Andrew.A.Duguid@lloyds.com

We have had a marked increase in visits to our website www.truthaboutlloyds.com since you published Godfrey Hodgson's article. The cover-up of Lloyd's fraudulent activities is the great untold story of our time. Mr Hodgson rightly emphasises the fact that Lloyd's insiders failed to set aside adequate reserves and failed to disclose to investors, regulators and the world that billions in asbestos liabilities were known to exist in many Lloyd's syndicates by at least 1980. What is not mentioned is that these misdeeds were aided and abetted, wittingly or unwittingly, by UK government officials at the highest level. It is simply not believable that Lloyd's executives were so clever that they "put the slip" on everyone from politicians to regulators.
Jeffrey C Peterson
Executive director, American Names Association

fields.headline: Unhealthy blow to justice
fields.trailText: The medical grounds for Jack Straw to block extradition of Pinochet to Spain seem far from clear (Pinochet to be set free, January 12). Why is the medical report to remain confidential and would this normally be the case? If Mr Straw does not explain himself adequately, I hope it will be subject to judicial review.
fields.body:
The medical grounds for Jack Straw to block extradition of Pinochet to Spain seem far from clear (Pinochet to be set free, January 12). Why is the medical report to remain confidential and would this normally be the case? If Mr Straw does not explain himself adequately, I hope it will be subject to judicial review.

Sufficient grounds would be constituted by an inability to understand the nature of proceedings due to senility . Otherwise extradition should only be blocked if to proceed would be against the public interest, whereas it would appear that the vital principles of international law should have overriding weight. Depression can hardly be considered sufficient cause - it would be a strange defendant, whether innocent or guilty, who did not become depressed. The length of time Pinochet has spent under house arrest is, of course, due to his strenuous efforts to avoid extradition.
David Marshall
London

As the General was never up for trial in Britain, his fitness or competency to face trial was not relevant for Britain to decide. That was a decision for Spain when the trial proceedings began. All Jack Straw had to do was decide whether he should be extradited under international law.
Bill Morris
General secretary, TGWU

The dictator responsible for unspeakable crimes is to go unpunished because, like King Lear, he is "a very foolish fond old man, fourscore and upward", who may not be in his "perfect mind". Alas, despite the Earl of Kent's noble assertion at the end of Lear, it is not true in this case that "all friends shall taste the wages of their virtue, and all foes the cup of their deserving".

When Pinochet dies, his family will know where he is buried. So many of the victims of his regime have no known grave. Their families have no private place to lay their memorial flowers.
Hilary Lloyd Yewlett
Cardiff

What an excuse! Viral infection, diabetes, heart disease, effects of two mild strokes; this is only part of my medical condition. I'm 71 and I travel the world.
Albert Lowe
Manchester
aslowe@attglobal.net

If the medical results show he is unfit for a two hour journey to Madrid, it's my guess he'll be on a 17- hour flight to Santiago before you can say "disappeared".
Jeff Williams
Hengoed, Mid Glamorgan

I feel an Ernest Saunders coming on.
JW Spencer
Great Totham, Essex

If General Pinochet is so ill, then perhaps we could send him to a warmer climate where he can recuperate. I would suggest Spain.
Rob Manwaring
London
RManwaring@tavi-port.org

It is the middle of winter and half the country is down with flu. Can't we wait until spring to see if he perks up?
Nick Martin-Clark
London
nandl@mn-ck.freeserve.co.uk

Did the doctors who examined Pinochet declare all their interests? Are we sure that none of these doctors belonged to any humane organisations? If any of them did, then I believe that this man should be examined again by doctors who do not subscribe to such a set up.
J Prajapati
London
prajapati@lineone.net

The eponymous Straw. Who will he exonerate next?
Tony Abramson
Leeds
Tony_Abramson@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Democracy on the line
fields.trailText: Is AOL's merger with Time Warner (Leader, January 12) good for democracy? In terms of media policy, few politicians will challenge the commercial interests of these groups. Media groups invest huge sums lobbying and in political donations to defend their interests. Organisations and individuals who challenge corporate media power face a daunting prospect.
fields.body:
Is AOL's merger with Time Warner (Leader, January 12) good for democracy? In terms of media policy, few politicians will challenge the commercial interests of these groups. Media groups invest huge sums lobbying and in political donations to defend their interests. Organisations and individuals who challenge corporate media power face a daunting prospect.

All of the recent mega-mergers in the US, and our own Carlton/United News and Media deal, are about ensuring market dominance. The consumer is told that these business deals will benefit them, but the consequences are programming shaped by commercial considerations, with a dire impact on journalism.
Granville Williams
Campaign for Press Freedom

I decided to check whether our AOL company account had indeed been cancelled having found the service not to my liking (Why geeks hate AOL, G2, January 12). It had not. I called up AOL to bring this to their attention only to be put on hold for one hour and then cut off. They seemed very keen to know where I had read about these accounts not being closed, but not interested in cancelling my already cancelled account. I am still trying to sever my company from AOL and be refunded for the sum I have been charged.
Martin Lewsley
London

Being denied access to AOL irked residents of Scunthorpe. How did Penistone fare?
Ian Bates
High Wycombe, Bucks

fields.headline: Star wars
fields.trailText: Your Confederate flag (January 11) is not the Stars and Bars, but the Battle Flag (or Southern Cross). The Stars and Bars, the original flag of the Confederate states, consisted of three horizontal bars (red-white-red) and a blue canton in the hoist bearing seven stars in a circle.
fields.body:
Your Confederate flag (January 11) is not the Stars and Bars, but the Battle Flag (or Southern Cross). The Stars and Bars, the original flag of the Confederate states, consisted of three horizontal bars (red-white-red) and a blue canton in the hoist bearing seven stars in a circle.

It was soon found (eg Bull Run.) that it was easily confused with the national flag (Stars and Stripes), especially when there wasn't much wind; this compounded the confusion caused as many of the rebel troops wore blue uniforms and many of the national troops wore grey. The rebels soon introduced the Battle Flag (blue saltire with 13 white stars, red ground) to remove the confusion.
Ivor Williams
Royston, Herts

fields.headline: Saved by his sickness
fields.standfirst:
Even Pinochet deserves to be treated fairly
Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Many thousands of people here, in Spain, and above all in Chile, will feel bitterly cheated now that General Pinochet may not after all be brought to account for the tortures, the murders, the "disappearances" over which he presided in Chile. The home secretary, in the careful archaic formula used on such occasions, is "minded" to rule that the old dictator is too ill to stand trial and should therefore be free to go home to Chile.
fields.body:
Many thousands of people here, in Spain, and above all in Chile, will feel bitterly cheated now that General Pinochet may not after all be brought to account for the tortures, the murders, the "disappearances" over which he presided in Chile. The home secretary, in the careful archaic formula used on such occasions, is "minded" to rule that the old dictator is too ill to stand trial and should therefore be free to go home to Chile.

Objectors have been given a week to challenge that, but to do so, they will need to do more than rage at a patent injustice. They will have to show that in drawing the conclusion he has from what, by general consent, is authoritative and impartial medical evidence, Mr Straw has been guilty of some dereliction of duty. On the basis of the defence he has made so far, it is hard to see such a charge being made to stick. Since - unlike Pinochet's Chile - this country believes in the rule of law, that consideration transcends all others.

Unlike Pinochet's Chile, Britain subscribes to the view that even those we consider the worst have rights. Unlike Pinochet's Chile, we seek to apply the rules as fairly to political opponents and those we despise as to everyone else. Unlike Pinochet's Chile, we aim to offer protections which ought to be available to all too weak to defend themselves even to people with records as foul as the general's. Mr Straw is no pushover. Through all the threats and wheedlings of the general's friends, he stuck to a course which seemed likely to end in Pinochet facing trial. It is not his fault, though it is an issue he and his colleagues need urgently to address, that in the absence of any agreed world system, we rely on an extradition law far slower and far more cumbersome than almost anyone else's. This whole business should have been concluded well before now.

The home secretary is also attacked for withholding the medical details. They would have been better published immediately, not least to reassure people in Chile that Britain has nothing to hide. But standard obligations designed to protect a patient's privacy have been observed in this case, because undertakings were given that this would be so. It is probably too late to go back on them now. Nor should we even be swayed by revulsion at the joy the decision has brought to the little clique of right-wingers who have been the general's champions, from Lady Thatcher, who staged a rally on behalf of her friend, and Lord Lamont, his dewy-eyed mouthpiece, downwards. Though they sanctimoniously insist that they would, of course, never condone murder and torture, their actions argue otherwise. Only think, they implore, how Chile stood by us during the Falklands war... In other words, he may be a brutal dictator, but he's our brutal dictator. Their record is shameful, but they will not face persecution here for expressing unacceptable views: this is not Pinochet's Chile.

Remember, too, how much has been achieved already. General Pinochet looks like escaping the fate he deserves, though if the doctors are right, he may not live long to enjoy his reprieve. But a point of lasting importance has been established. People who run their countries in the way the Pinochet gang, having stolen their power, ran Chile, can no longer expect safe havens wherever they choose to travel. The House of Lords, in a ruling in November 1998 which echoed across the world, has destroyed that immunity. Pinochet may get away free, but because of him, others will not. And as long as it is remembered, his name will remain an emblem across the world of the evils which come with dictatorship.

fields.headline: Missing the big picture
fields.standfirst:
The Neill report is sadly incomplete
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Like a steeplechaser at Becher's Brook, Lord Neill runs at the high fences of our political life - ministers, their advisers, House of Commons procedure - but never quite makes a convincing leap. He covers the ground well enough. Applying bribery law to MPs; a code of conduct for special advisers; a civil service act: there is room on the bandwagon for his committee on standards in public life. In his capacity as man with bucket and spade at the rear of the circus parade, Neill flourishes his brush to clear up the parliamentary muck left by the Hamilton case. He makes a set of complicated if consistent recommendations about the Commons' standards commissioner and committee; they should meet both the demands of natural justice and the incipient critique in the human rights act of such "club" procedures.
fields.body:
Like a steeplechaser at Becher's Brook, Lord Neill runs at the high fences of our political life - ministers, their advisers, House of Commons procedure - but never quite makes a convincing leap. He covers the ground well enough. Applying bribery law to MPs; a code of conduct for special advisers; a civil service act: there is room on the bandwagon for his committee on standards in public life. In his capacity as man with bucket and spade at the rear of the circus parade, Neill flourishes his brush to clear up the parliamentary muck left by the Hamilton case. He makes a set of complicated if consistent recommendations about the Commons' standards commissioner and committee; they should meet both the demands of natural justice and the incipient critique in the human rights act of such "club" procedures.

But the jump Lord Neill refuses is called the British constitution. By failing to address some "big" questions to do with the distribution of power within the state, Neill is left paddling in the shallows. What, he asks, if our legislature cannot now regulate itself: must we invite executive appointees in, in the shape of judges? What if the need to control ministers now demands fundamental reform, including perhaps an elected second chamber and more devolution? But that hurdle is too high for Neill. Dealing with enforcement of the ministerial code - the only rules we have on how the supreme possessors of executive power should behave - he leaves it to the prime minister alone to decide how his cabinet should be investigated and judged. Neill considers a statutory ethics commissioner, Canadian-style, but concludes this would cramp the potentates' discretion. (They, by the way, include the cabinet secretary. To judge by the almost flippant observations made to Neill by Lord Butler, "investigator" of Jonathan Aitken, occupants of that key post may be part of the problem.)

Neill makes sensible recommendations that usefully quieten fuss over the number and cost of Labour's special advisers. His new codes and tinkering would increase transparency - but reduce partisanship. Thereby he leaves one great question unanswered. Nolan and Neill have been about securing public confidence in our democracy. For that, don't we need more, not less, partisan politics - more dissent from within the governing party, as well as a higher strike rate from the opposition?
