webTitle: Milosevic's rivals try to bury feuds

fields.headline: Milosevic's rivals try to bury feuds
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The Serbian opposition will be celebrating Orthodox new year tonight in a greater state of harmony than at any stage since the end of the Nato bombing campaign.
fields.body:
The Serbian opposition will be celebrating Orthodox new year tonight in a greater state of harmony than at any stage since the end of the Nato bombing campaign.

Rival opposition parties are encouraging their supporters to come together at an open-air New Year's Eve party organised by the students' resistance movement in Republic Square in Belgrade, the scene of ultimately doomed protests last year against the rule of President Slobodan Milosevic.

The hitherto feuding opposition is congratulating itself on the signing of a "historic agreement" earlier this week in which 15 political parties adopted a joint strategy aimed at securing early presidential, parliamentary and local elections in Serbia.

At their festivities the students are to name their men and women of 1999, and more than a few opposition leaders will doubtless be hoping to find their names on the list.

"We, the leaders of the democratic opposition, decided to once again demand from Milosevic and both Yugoslav and Serbian parliaments to agree to call early elections by the end of April." said a spokesman for the controversial and charismatic opposition leader, Vuk Draskovic.

The demand for elections was accompanied by a threat of renewed anti-government protests starting in March.

The action plan was the initiative of Mr Draskovic, who is trying to assume the role of overall leader of the Serbian opposition. He appears to believe that his moment has come after the failure of his rival, Zoran Djindjic, to galvanise public support during a countrywide protest campaign last summer.

The decision by all the main opposition parties to support the strategy indicates a new pragmatism and a tacit admission that opposition disunity has alienated the people of Serbia.

Beyond the demand for elections, Mr Draskovic's blueprint outlines a strategy for rehabilitating Serbia internationally. It contains proposals for the lifting of sanctions against Belgrade once the authorities agree to elections and for the readmission of Serbia into the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe.

To avoid accusations of selling out to the west, the opposition also calls for Serbian troops to be allowed to return to Kosovo.

Mr Draskovic is adopting a softly softly approach to political change rather than the top-to-bottom shake-out advocated by some of his younger opposition rivals. Notably absent from his blueprint is the demand for the immediate removal of President Milosevic.

Mr Draskovic is meanwhile courting disaffected members of Mr Milosevic's ruling Socialist party of Serbia, who are alarmed at the growing influence in government of the president's wife, Mira Markovic, and her associates.

Serbian sceptics argue that Mr Draskovic is not interested in reforming a system which benefits the ruling elite, but merely in changing who is at the top. Political analysts believe he may be seeking an exit strategy for Mr Milosevic which would allow the Serbian leader to retreat from power without facing prosecution on war crimes charges by the international criminal tribunal in the Hague.

Mr Milosevic, however, shows no signs of wanting a way out.

"Sloba and Mira have learnt that it is possible to rule without popular support," said Bratislav Grubacic, a Belgrade-based political analyst.

The authorities have made it clear that presidential and parliamentary elections are not on the table.

"There is no parliamentary crisis in Serbia to give a reason for calling early elections," said Ivica Dacic, the Socialist party spokesman, adding that elections were needed only at the local level, in towns and cities where opposition parties controlled local councils.

The government is widely expected to call local elections in the spring, capitalising on recent changes to the voting system which should favour the Socialists and their allies.

In a sign that the display of opposition unity is rustling government feathers, the authorities have started a campaign to discredit Mr Draskovic. The federal information minister, Goran Matic, showed journalists a videotape in which an alleged spy claimed to have put Mr Draskovic in contact with the French secret services.

Mr Draskovic, who already claims to have been the victim of a state-sponsored assassination plot, has rejected these allegations.

fields.headline: Anatomy of a fighter
fields.standfirst: Why was this match ever sanctioned?
fields.trailText: Back in 1988, when Mike Tyson was world heavyweight boxing champion and his marriage to actress Robin Givens had just broken up, he was asked by his biographer to describe his best-ever punch. "Man, I'll never forget that," he said. "It was when I fought with Robin. She really offended me and I went 'Bam'. She flew backward hitting every wall in the apartment. That was the best punch I've ever thrown in my life."
fields.body:
Back in 1988, when Mike Tyson was world heavyweight boxing champion and his marriage to actress Robin Givens had just broken up, he was asked by his biographer to describe his best-ever punch. "Man, I'll never forget that," he said. "It was when I fought with Robin. She really offended me and I went 'Bam'. She flew backward hitting every wall in the apartment. That was the best punch I've ever thrown in my life."

If that sounds unbelievably sick, then it is as well to remember that unrestrained violence is Tyson's illness as well as his income. For him, it is a way of life. From his childhood days as a Brooklyn pickpocket and mugger to his 1998 road rage assault conviction, his story has been mostly blood, sweat, and other people's tears. In the ring, his behaviour is increasingly manic, some say psychotic. In 1997 he bit a chunk out of Evander Holyfield's ear and was subsequently disqualified. During one of his comeback fights, he admitted trying to break his opponent's arm. Outside the ring, "Mad Mike" is fighting everybody from his former promoter, Don King, to animal lovers who accuse him of abusing a pet ferret. This is nothing new. webTitle: UN prosecutor to review Nato's bombing of Yugoslavia

fields.headline: UN prosecutor to review Nato's bombing of Yugoslavia
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The chief prosecutor at the UN war crimes tribunal, Carla del Ponte, will visit Nato next week when she is expected to discuss allegations that the alliance violated international law during its bombing of Yugoslavia, her spokesman said yesterday.
fields.body:
The chief prosecutor at the UN war crimes tribunal, Carla del Ponte, will visit Nato next week when she is expected to discuss allegations that the alliance violated international law during its bombing of Yugoslavia, her spokesman said yesterday.

During her visit to Brussels next Wednesday, she will meet the Nato secretary general, Lord Robertson, and take questions from the North Atlantic Council, the alliance's policy-making body, her spokesman, Paul Risley, said.

Her staff are studying a dossier of claims made by an international group of lawyers, though she recently insisted that no formal investigation of Nato's actions was under way.

Ms del Ponte has also said she will press Nato to step up its efforts to arrest more suspects wanted by the tribunal. Key among them are the former Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, and his military commander, Ratko Mladic.

The tribunal was handed a dossier last year by a group of international lawyers led by Michael Mandel, a law professor at York university in Toronto. It accused Nato of "grave violations of international humanitarian law", including "wilful killing".

The dossier referred to the civilian deaths from Nato's bombing raids, including the mistaken attack on a hospital in Nis, in central Serbia.

"This is a historic opportunity to demonstrate the even-handedness of international justice," Professor Mandel said after delivering the dossier last year.

Other international lawyers argued that such statements could be counter-productive and place the tribunal in an untenable position.

"The even-handedness we expect of the chief prosecutor does not mean treating allegations equally," Diane Orentlicher, director of the war crimes research office at the American university in Washington, said last week.

fields.headline: Blairite gains top Strasbourg job
fields.standfirst: The European Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The Labour leadership yesterday secured its grip on the party's Strasbourg delegation when its group of MEPs elected the Blairite Simon Murphy as their leader in the European parliament.
fields.body:
The Labour leadership yesterday secured its grip on the party's Strasbourg delegation when its group of MEPs elected the Blairite Simon Murphy as their leader in the European parliament.

Mr Murphy, 37, the group's chief whip, beat Stephen Hughes, a less New Labour candidate, by 18 votes to 10, to succeed Alan Donnelly, who unexpectedly resigned as an MEP in December.

Mr Donnelly had complained about the pressure of travelling between Strasbourg and EU headquarters in Brussels.

He plans to take a private sector job or set up as a European consultant in Newcastle.

Mr Murphy is seen as more emollient than his former leader. A friend described Mr Murphy as "a clean-living non-smoker, who will be more consensual".

Yesterday Mr Murphy pledged himself to help place Britain "at the heart of Europe, and not at its throat". But he also loyally backed Mr Donnelly's complaint.

"The shuttling of the parliament between Strasbourg and Brussels has to stop. It wastes millions of taxpayers' money and undermines the work Labour MEPs do," he said.

Labour lost half of its 62 seats in the June European elections and blamed the new proportional representation system which required voters to back a party list, not individual candidates.

The backlash makes it less likely that Tony Blair will rush to implement his promise of a PR referendum after the next election, though he will not drop it either.

fields.headline: Paying the price
fields.standfirst:
MoD says £400m Kosovo bill omits bombs

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The Kosovo war cost the ministry of defence an additonal £400m in excess of what it would normally spend on the armed forces, it was disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
The Kosovo war cost the ministry of defence an additonal £400m in excess of what it would normally spend on the armed forces, it was disclosed yesterday.

The figure, the first official estimate, was given by Colin Balmer, the MoD's principal finance officer in evidence to the Commons defence committee.

He said the sum, which will be funded by the treasury's contingency reserve fund, did not include the cost of replacing weapons dropped on Serbia during the 78-day bombing campaign.

RAF planes such as the Harrier, based at Gioia del Colle base in Italy, dropped 1,011 bombs during the conflict, according to ministry figures. They included 242 Paveway precision-guided bombs which cost between £29,000 and £49,000 each.

MoD officials admitted there was a shortage of personnel in all three armed services. The RAF's problems in retaining skilled pilots - described in an unpublished report to the defence committee - was described by Julian Brazier, Conservative MP for Canterbury, as "appalling".

fields.headline: Stars in our eyes
fields.standfirst: What makes a tabloid newspaper pay its astrologer a million pounds? Horoscopes are serious business these days and their biggest fans are female.  Anita  Chaudhuri  asks what the attraction is
fields.trailText: The American writer Thornton Wilder once observed that "the future is the most expensive luxury in the world". Executives at the Daily Mail discovered this to their cost last week when their star astrologer, Jonathan Cainer, announced that he is turning down their £1 million a year and defecting to the Express.
fields.body:
The American writer Thornton Wilder once observed that "the future is the most expensive luxury in the world". Executives at the Daily Mail discovered this to their cost last week when their star astrologer, Jonathan Cainer, announced that he is turning down their £1 million a year and defecting to the Express.

Blame it on millennial hysteria or a decline in secular devotion, but the predictions industry is booming like never before and women appear to be its most ardent consumers. According to Robert Currey who runs The Astrology Shop in Central London, around 70% of his clients are women - and he has 100,000 customers on his books. "Women are more in touch with their intuitive side and more willing to accept phenomena for which there is no empirical proof. Men are more sceptical."

This may be true but it doesn't fully explain why women should be more interested than men in having the future foretold. Does this mean that we are more gullible, or merely more scared and insecure? Astrologer Fiona Graham has a more positive interpretation: as women's roles become more diverse and unconventional in society, we have a greater need for guidance in our personal growth. "Astrology is really about how best to fulfil our potential, how to find those parts of ourselves that we are not experiencing fully. A good reading can sanction a person's individuality and give them the confidence to break the rules."

Maybe this is why so many of us love to read our stars in newspapers and magazines every day. Certainly horoscopes offer a certain feel-good factor. If my own stars for this month are to be believed, then the future looks so bright that it is positively radioactive. Take Red magazine. "Aries: You will bomb around all over the place, your career rockets and your love life fizzles." Or this from Cosmopolitan: "Get ready for a rollercoaster relationship - your romance gains so much speed that you won't be able to, or want to, stop it." I can hardly wait. Or how about Vogue: "The eclipsed full moon on the 21st indicates far-reaching changes. Decisions about your work and lifestyle must be made swiftly."

The key thing about horoscopes is that they always make you feel as though you are on the cusp of some truly momentous event - always something positive and intriguing enough to have you reaching for the premium rate phone lines. Stubbornly, I persist in believing that all these fabulous opportunities are only a heartbeat away.

Alas, Christine Skinner, an astrologer who advises city brokers, advises me to calm down. "Sun sign columns in the media have only very limited accuracy. There are way too many variables in an individual chart." In her experience, women turn to astrology to confront life's imponderables: love, relationships and, increasingly, the timing of having children. "It all used to be relatively simple. You'd calculate a chart and see clearly when a marriage or a birth was likely to occur. Now people are choosing to live together, and fertility treatment and contraception make it very difficult for us to talk about children with any degree of certainty."

Skinner reveals that it is a tough life being an astrologer, having to live up to the Whoopi Goldberg cliché of the female psychic. "People can react very oddly when they find out what I do for a living - it is like I am supposed to know everything about them immediately. Psychic ability is made far more mysterious than it actually is. Intuitive understanding is available to us all if we learn to tune into it. Yet many women, through low self-esteem or social conditioning, ignore their own sixth sense and turn instead to those mystical gurus who claim to know better."

Peta High, chair of the Astrological Association, says she is often amazed by the responsibility people lay at her door. "They will come along and ask 'Should I leave my husband?' or 'Should I sell my house?' or 'Should I pack in my really good, well-paid job and if so, what should I do instead?' We have to be careful what we say. A lot of people come to us when they are very vulnerable."

To this end High, like a growing number of astrologers, has trained as a counsellor. "Issues of childhood abuse or domestic violence can often surface during a consultation. You have to know how to deal with that."

Perhaps one of the reasons women have a greater interest than men in this subject is that they are more willing to be swept away by the concept of romantic destiny. Certainly it is comforting to believe that you are part of a cosmic grand plan. Not surprisingly, the lonely and desperate can often arrive with overly high expectations. "They all want to be told they are going to win the lottery and marry a film star," High admits. "But if I don't see that, I can't tell them that, can I? There is a big shortage of tall, dark, handsome strangers out there."

Despite the fact that women follow their horoscopes so enthusiastically, there are relatively few female stars in the astrological firmament. "Women did not achieve fame and notoriety as astrologers in previous centuries for the usual restricting social factors," Fiona Graham says. Throughout history, there has been a tendency for female mystics to be viewed with fear and suspicion. The Salem witches dabbled in astrology and were much feared; the dark art was legitimised only by psychologist Carl Jung when he examined astrological archetype late in his career.

Shelley Von Strunkel, one of the world's most famous astrologers, finds it ironic that there are so few female stars. "Traditionally, men have found status from the material world and women have been drawn to the metaphysical arena. It is women who are more likely to think deeply about the relationship between destiny and free will which is at the root of astrology. And yet the big stars still seem to be men."

Von Strunkel believes that there is a general need for the public to become more knowledgeable about metaphysical, intuitive subjects and that their expectations are often unrealistic. "People know more about how to assess a car mechanic than an astrologer. That is why so many people are in danger of falling for gurus selling snake oil."

Richard Wiseman, a psychologist at the University of Hertfordshire, doesn't accept this. According to his own research, although 60% of the population regularly read their horoscopes, only 6% have ever acted on the advice they have been given. Personally, I am waiting to read my February stars before making any big decisions.

webTitle: Clinton presses Adams on IRA decommissioning

fields.headline: Clinton presses Adams on IRA decommissioning
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Sinn Fein leader, Gerry Adams, met President Clinton at the White House last night for their first face to face discussions on Northern Ireland since the creation of the power-sharing executive last year.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Washington and  John Mullin
fields.body:
The Sinn Fein leader, Gerry Adams, met President Clinton at the White House last night for their first face to face discussions on Northern Ireland since the creation of the power-sharing executive last year.

The long-arranged meeting took place with little of the media razzmatazz that attended earlier visits to Washington by Northern Ireland republican leaders. But it comes as tension is mounting over whether the IRA will begin to decommission before next month's scheduled meeting of the Ulster Unionist council.

The unionist leader, David Trimble, who now heads the Northern Ireland executive, has threatened to resign if the IRA fails to meet a February deadline.

Clinton administration sources made clear that the president would press Mr Adams at last night's meeting over decommissioning. British sources said that Sinn Fein had "nowhere left to hide" on decommissioning, but said that the administration did not want to push Mr Adams into a corner.

Mr Clinton is keen to visit Northern Ireland, but is unlikely to come until decommissioning has been settled.

Unionists now doubt that the IRA will make a move on arms this month.

The security forces have no intelligence predicting an imminent development, and there is little sign republicans have been conditioned for decommissioning.

Mr Trimble, who will meet Tony Blair at Downing Street today, said in November he believed Sinn Fein would suffer worldwide condemnation if the IRA refused to begin decommissioning by next month.

But the reality is that he instead will be the focus of criticism if he walks away from the so-far-successful executive over the issue.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, told the Commons yesterday that he expected an imminent start to decommissioning. But he introduced a new definition, using the term "permanently inaccessible". That is a reference to sealed arms dumps, the least unpalatable option for the IRA. But General John de Chastelain's mandate is to ensure weapons are destroyed. To adopt a policy of sealing arms dumps would require legislation.

Mr Mandelson said he would shortly announce his decision on reform of the RUC. The Police Federation yesterday handed in a petition at Downing Street containing the signatures of 300,000 people opposed to a changes in the name or badge of the force.

webTitle: It's no tall story that women go for height

fields.headline: It's no tall story that women go for height
fields.standfirst: Scientists claim data shows that shorter men are not only less attractive to the opposite sex but are not so likely to father children
fields.trailText: It's official: women really do want a man they can look up to. Scientists report today that taller men have greater reproductive success.
fields.body:
It's official: women really do want a man they can look up to. Scientists report today that taller men have greater reproductive success.

In unscientific language, they are more likely to get the girls, and then get them pregnant.

Robin Dunbar, an evolutionary psychologist at the university of Liverpool, and two Polish collaborators, report in the science journal Nature that they analysed data for 4,419 healthy men aged 25 to 60 who had compulsory medical examinations between 1983 and 1989 in Wroclaw, Poland.

They matched height against progeny and found that childless men were about 3cm shorter than men who had at least one child.

In all age groups except one, men with children were significantly taller. The exception was the group born in the 1930s. Just after the second world war, men were in short supply and at a premium.

"We were doing this stuff on lonely hearts ads and one of the things that popped out was the tendency for males not to declare their height," said Professor Dunbar.

"They would say if they were tall, but never '5ft 2in, Danny DeVito lookalike'.

"We started to wonder if this was of consequence, because it is clear that people are very sensitive, they do know what the opposite sex is looking for."

One of his collaborators returned to Poland, and mentioned the matter to an anthropologist, who pointed to a set of data which included height and family history.

The three scientists think they may have demonstrated a universal truth: when it comes to selecting a mate, women have high ambitions.

"They are not selecting tall men because they are tall," said Prof Dunbar, who is 5ft 11in, and a father of three. "They are selecting tall men because tallness is a cue for, or index of, something else. Studies in Germany, of lawyers, nurses, carpenters and middle managers, have shown that successful ones are between 2cm and 6cm taller than less successful ones.

"One is conscious of the fact that heads of department tend to be taller than the average," he said. "I would say that professors are taller. They do have to do something other than just be tall. But one is conscious that more successful people in most domains are taller."

webTitle: Alarm at gunboat demand for plutonium's return trip

fields.headline: Alarm at gunboat demand for plutonium's return trip
fields.trailText: Japan's biggest nuclear power company yesterday demanded that Britain send two gunboats on a 40,000 mile round trip to pick up a shipment of British-produced plutonium   which it refuses to load into its reactors on safety grounds.
fields.body:
Japan's biggest nuclear power company yesterday demanded that Britain send two gunboats on a 40,000 mile round trip to pick up a shipment of British-produced plutonium which it refuses to load into its reactors on safety grounds.

The British government is so alarmed at having to spend millions on sending the ships that it is dispatching a delegation to plead with Japanese ministers to veto the plan.

The demand, by Kansai Electric Power, that British Nuclear Fuels collect the fuel it shipped to Japan with false safety documents, is the latest blow to the troubled nuclear company.

It needed Japanese orders to justify opening a £300m plant to make plutonium-based mixed oxide fuel, but now seems doomed not to get any.

The mixed oxide plant, mothballed for 18 months, was on the verge of gaining permission to operate last autumn when the documents scandal came to light.

At the time BNFL denied that any of the fuel it had sent to Japan was involved, but before Christmas the Nuclear Installation Inspectorate revealed that the company was not being honest.

BNFL was forced into an abject apology to the Japanese and the energy minister, Helen Liddell, called in the BNFL chairman, Hugh Collum, and its chief executive, John Taylor, for a reprimand.

She talked of the government's "very grave concerns" about the falsification of quality control data.

Yesterday ministers ordered Anna Walker, the director general of energy at the DTI, and Lawrence Williams, chief inspector of the NII, to go to Japan to talk the government out of sending the fuel back.

Both governments fear censure if the fuel, from which plutonium could be extracted to make weapons, was shipped around the world again.

Under nuclear proliferation safeguards, plutonium shipments have to be accompanied by armed vessels. BNFL armed two transport ships and trained crews to fight terrorists to deliver the fuel in the first place.

Yesterday the DTI, which sees its plans to privatise 49% of BNFL and raise £1.5bn for the taxpayer fading fast, confirmed that it was anxious to avoid shipping the fuel back .

A spokeswoman said the fuel should be dealt with in Japan. Surprisingly the DTI found itself on the same side as Greenpeace which said it was mad to risk sending the fuel back.

Pete Roche, the nuclear campaigner, said "Both countries have more plutonium than they can ever use. It's mad to ship it round the world, needlessly risking terrorist attack or environmental problems."

webTitle: Stubborn trapdoor adds to opera woes

fields.headline: Stubborn trapdoor adds to opera woes
fields.trailText: Just as the Royal Opera House was displaying signs of competence, another comic book disaster has ruined the opening night of its first big show of the new year.
fields.body:
Just as the Royal Opera House was displaying signs of competence, another comic book disaster has ruined the opening night of its first big show of the new year.

In a scene that might have come from the Marx Brothers' caper A Night at the Opera, the bass John Tomlinson's dramatic entrance on Tuesday night as the Green Knight in Gawain backfired when a trapdoor broke.

Just as the composer Sir Harrison Birtwistle had intended, the big moment was presaged by the thunder of horses' hooves and a heavy rap on the door of Camelot. Nothing happened. There was another rap on the door. Again nothing happened.

Then a sheepish stage manager emerged to explain that the trapdoor cable had snapped, and it would take half an hour to repair it.

The production's scheduled opening night last Friday had to be cancelled after rehearsals were disrupted when the orchestra walked out claiming that the pit of the rebuilt £218m auditorium was a "death trap". They agreed to return only when the fire doors were repositioned to open outwards. At one stage, according to sources close to Birtwistle, the production was on the brink of being called off.

The troubles with Gawain follow the scrapping of Le Grand Macabre and technical nightmares with the Royal Opera's first big new production, Falstaff, starring Bryn Terfel. One matinee had to be delayed nearly two hours when the main stage lift broke down.

And management has had to review ticketing policy after a revolt by regular opera goers, who claimed that the big price cuts promised by the new regime benefited only the rich and those sitting in the worst seats, while so-called ordinary fans were having to pay more.

But a Royal Opera spokesman yesterday denied that the trapdoor breakdown would engulf it in yet another crisis. "Nothing quite like this has happened before. It was a problem with a basic piece of technology that could have happened in any theatre. Indeed I have sat through many shows elsewhere where this has happened and no fuss has been made. The great thing was that, after that, everything went seamlessly and the company were terrific."

Indeed Gawain, like Falstaff, was last night judged a success. The Guardian's opera critic, Tim Ashley, described it as a "triumph over adversity", and other critics were equally generous.

The later and much more complex Turn of the Seasons sequence, which involves a revolving stage and many lifts and pulleys, went perfectly.

Peter Ainsworth, shadow culture secretary, said a trap cable snapping could happen to anyone, "though a disturbing pattern is building up at the opera house... The box office has not been working quite as well as it should. Like the dome, you get the feeling the opera house was opened without everything working the way it should."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Man found dead in X-ray cubicle
fields.body:
Man found dead in X-ray cubicle

A West Yorkshire hospital apologised to the family of a pensioner yesterday after his body lay undiscovered in an outpatient X-ray cubicle for almost five hours.

The man, 78, is thought to have had a heart attack after a radiographer at Pinderfields hospital, Wakefield, told him he could dress and go home. Martin Wainwright

DJ's final plea in abuse case

Chris Denning, the former Radio 1 DJ on trial in the Czech republic charged with sexual abuse of boys, yesterday made a final bid to clear his name.

Denning, 58, told the court in Prague he had provided the boys with a "father figure" and made life for them "significantly better". Kate Connolly

Three agree to pay hospital

A Labour councillor, Ron Morrissey, has agreed to pay £45,000 to Christ's hospital for elderly people near Durham, in a high court settlement after legal action by the Charity Commission. He resigned as the hospital's chairman of governors seven years ago.

Its former director, the Rev Graham Pattison, dismissed in 1993, has agreed to pay the charity £44,000 and 85% of the value of the pension of his wife, Valerie, its former head of care, who was sacked at the same time. The three deny mis-spending charity funds on private cars and pensions. Martin Wainwright

Tesco recalls lasagne packs

Tesco has recalled three lasagne brands as a "precaution", because they could be contaminated with metal shavings found in a plant.

Packs of Tesco Lasagne 350g, 700g and 990g, Tesco Mega Value Lasagne 600g or Tesco Healthy Eating Lasagne 350g with use-by dates of January 16, 17 and 18 should be returned for a refund.

fields.headline: Food standards chief 'odd choice'
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Food campaigners yesterday criticised the appointment of a leading scientist to head the new food standards agency.
fields.byline: James Meikle and Ian Black in Brussels
fields.body:
Food campaigners yesterday criticised the appointment of a leading scientist to head the new food standards agency.

They said Oxford professor Sir John Krebs, who will be paid £96,000 a year for the four-day-a-week job, did not have a track record in food or consumer policy. But he insisted that he wanted the agency to be "a beacon of openness and a model for the best use of science."

Sir John, who is former head of the national environment research council, and whose study of badgers helped to bring about a government cull to see whether the animals spread TB to cattle, said he wanted to strengthen "already high standards" of food safety, to ensure that "everyone can have confidence that public health is being properly protected".

His deputy, Suzi Leather, is a consumer campaigner whose appointment to the £30,000 a year, two-day-a-week, job was widely welcomed. The chief executive, to be paid up to £90,000 a year, will be a civil servant, Geoffrey Podger.

The Consumers' Association expressed disappointment that the government had not appointed "a strong, credible, consumer chair" for the agency, which will have a budget of £130m in its first year. Tim Lang, professor of food policy at Thames Valley university suggested Sir John's appointment was "bizarre".

Professor Lang said the agency would have to establish a strong voice at international level.

The European commission in Brussels meanwhile unveiled plans to restore confidence in food after the BSE crisis and scandals over dioxins and sewage in animal feed. But a new European food authority - originally billed by the president, Romano Prodi, as being modelled on the US food and drugs administration - will now have no regulatory powers.

Legislative powers will remain with the commission and national parliaments. The authority will provide scientific advice, assess all food health risks, and provide a "rapid alerts" system to speed up EU response to animal feed problems.

David Byrne, the food safety commissioner, promised a high profile chief executive to help the new body acquire "a dependable reputation".

fields.headline: National roundup
fields.trailText: Photocard 'passport' planned
fields.body:
Photocard 'passport' planned

The Passport Agency is developing a credit-card sized photocard which could be used in conjunction with current passports.

The card will contain all of the information stored on the last page of the current passport - including name, place and date of birth, sex, and a photograph.

The Home Office confirmed that the Passport Agency was examining the feasibility of a new travel document but said that it was in the early stages.

"The photocard passport would be a condensed form of the current passport," the home office said. "It would be additional to and would not replace the current passport."

The passport agency, which is said to have set the end of 2002 as a possible date for the card's introduction, has drawn up a business plan of 30 priorities with the photocard coming eighth on the list.

Data on the new card would be embedded into the plastic rather than superimposed on a page, making it more difficult to tamper with or forge.

While there would be no technical barriers to the production of the card - photographs are already scanned onto many passports - its introduction would require ministerial and European Union approval.

Bradford honours Hockney

One of Britain's most cautious cities is to give its highest honour to a flamboyant gay artist who used to cart his easel and brushes round its streets in a pram.

The freedom of Bradford, issued to only 20 individuals since 1898, and with a reluctance born of a suspicion of local lads who make good, will be conferred on David Hockney this summer.

The honour, announced to day, will allow him to process through the city's streets with the only other living freemen - the Prince of Wales's West Yorkshire regiment, the Black Dyke Mills Band and the politician Barbara Castle.

Both parties to the award took a down-to-earth view of its practicalities yesterday.

"Will I be able to travel on the buses for free?" Hockney, 53, asked his brother Paul, a former lord mayor of Bradford when he broke the news.

Bradford, meanwhile, has let it slip that honouring the painter will not harm its bid to become the European city of culture in 2008.

The son of a Bradford accountant, Hockney long ago moved to California but has kept in touch with his roots in the city.

He has often applied the vivid colours of his adopted home to Bradford's landscape of mills and trams, notably on the cover of the city's phone directory, which has become a collector's item.

Hockney said yesterday that he was "very, very proud" to join the Bradford writer JB Priestley and the composer Frederick Delius in being granted the honour.

Martin Wainwright

Brady files complaint over photo

The moors murderer Ian Brady has complained to the press complaints commission of intrusion into his privacy after the Mirror newspaper published a picture of him during a trip to hospital for a check-up.

Brady also lodged protests against the Liverpool Echo and Daily Record yesterday.

The picture, headlined "Brady: the fat hunger striker", on the Mirror's front page yesterday is the first to be seen of him in four years.

Its editor, Piers Morgan, said the paper was the subject of a second complaint to the PCC yesterday about a picture of Peter Sutcliffe, the Yorkshire ripper, published last year.

"We stand charged by two of the most murderous mass killers in British history of invading their privacy, and we stand proud," Mr Morgan said. "We look forward to defending ourselves.

"I do not believe the PCC was devised to resolve invasions of privacy into the lives of serial killers, but I remain to be advised by [PCC chairman] Lord Wakeham."

Janine Gibson

Council fraud case questioned

The town hall corruption inquiry in Doncaster faces a challenge today at a meeting called to consider a judge's comment that some expenses fraud charges are "scraping the barrel".

Detectives in charge of Operation Danum, which has seen 29 arrests and nine council officers or Labour councillors so far jailed or fined, will meet lawyers from the crown prosecution service to consider Judge Jonathan Crabtree's remarks.

He asked for his views to be passed to the CPS and other "appropriate authorities" at an initial hearing of expenses fraud claims against Doncaster's former Labour leader Malcolm Glover, who denies nine charges of claiming first class rail fares when travelling standard class.

The judge said at Doncaster crown court: "Here we are, down to squabbling about whether he travelled first class or second class. It is scraping the barrel a little bit, is it not?"

South Yorkshire police will strongly defend the two-year inquiry, which has led to a further seven councillors and council officers being bailed and involves 3,283 inquiries into allegations of expenses fiddles and planning fraud. Although convictions so far have involved relatively minor sums, the Danum team is working on claims of large-scale planning fraud.

Detective Superintendent Graham Johnson, head of the operation, said yesterday: "We will be giving careful consideration to the judge's comments, after which we will take a decision, but I can't pre-judge the outcome of the meeting."

Martin Wainwright

Donkeys pollution suspects

Blackpool's famous donkeys could be partly to blame for the pollution of the resort's beaches.

Research is being carried out to discover whether donkeys and seagulls can be blamed and so avoid Britain being fined by the European commission for failing to clean up Blackpool and Southport beaches 16 years after first being taken to court for the same offence.

Since then North West Water has been forced to spend £350m to try to cure the problem but has failed to do so. Yesterday the company and the department of the environment claimed that seagulls and donkeys might be to blame for excess bacteria in the sea.

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, admitted yesterday that Britain had been slow to react to the 1993 judgment made in the European court of justice of a "chronic failure" to meet quality standards. The department has two months to make a reasoned defence to the charge that it has failed to clean up the beaches in order to stave off a fine.

Paul Brown

Suspect 'was due to strike again'

Police who arrested the man suspected of killing British student Isabel Peake and two young French women said yesterday they were afraid he would have struck again today, the 13th of the month, if he had not been caught.

"Two of his presumed victims died on the 13th, one in October and the other in December," a police source in Paris said. "He was born on May 13. There's nearly always a pattern with serial killings."

Sid Ahmed Rezala, who was detained on Tuesday by French and Portuguese police in a working class suburb of Lisbon, is due to appear in court today to be formally charged with murder and remanded in custody pending arrival of extradition papers from France.

The state prosecutor in Amiens, Dominique Lebras, said Rezala should be extradited within a fortnight. He added that the 20-year-old Algerian-born suspect could be held for 40 days in Portugal and that "the top priority is to avoid any technical error in the relevant paperwork."

The state prosecutor in Chateauroux, near the small disused station where the body of Ms Peake was found, said yesterday that he would be "putting some very precise questions to Mr Rezala as soon as he is back in France".

A reconstruction of her death will be staged on Saturday to test the theory that she was pushed to her death from a train door or window, said the prosecutor, Christian Ponsard.

Jon Henley

Wife 'hired hitman to kill husband'

A woman hired a hitman to kill her husband so she could secure more than £100,000 in life insurance, Stafford crown court heard yesterday.

But the plan to kill Clifford Jones, 35, fell apart when the would-be killer, Matthew Lee, attacked him as he slept at the couple's home in Beckdale, Uttoxeter, Staffordshire, on last February.

The jury heard that Lee, 57, hit Mr Jones with a 24inch metal crowbar. The blow woke him up and he managed to fend off the attack and escape to safety.

Bernard Thorogood, prosecuting, said Sandra Jones, 38, had discussed murdering her husband of 12 years with her best friend, Julie Harvey. Jones pleaded guilty to conspiring to murder her husband at an earlier hearing.

Lee, of Uttoxeter, denies conspiring to murder Mr Jones. He claims he was elsewhere when the attack occurred.

The case continues.

Nick Hopkins

"We stand charged by two of the most murderous mass killers in British history of invading their privacy, and we stand proud," Mr Morgan said. "We look forward to defending ourselves. "I do not believe the PCC was devised to resolve invasions of privacy into the lives of serial killers, but I remain to be advised by [PCC chairman] Lord Wakeham." Janine Gibson Council fraud case questioned The town hall corruption inquiry in Doncaster faces a challenge today at a meeting called to consider a judge's comment that some expenses fraud charges are "scraping the barrel". Detectives in charge of Operation Danum, which has seen 29 arrests and nine council officers or Labour councillors so far jailed or fined, will meet lawyers from the crown prosecution service to consider Judge Jonathan Crabtree's remarks. He asked for his views to be passed to the CPS and other "appropriate authorities" at an initial hearing of expenses fraud claims against Doncaster's former Labour leader Malcolm Glover, who denies nine charges of claiming first class rail fares when travelling standard class. The judge said at Doncaster crown court: "Here we are, down to squabbling about whether he travelled first class or second class. It is scraping the barrel a little bit, is it not?" South Yorkshire police will strongly defend the two-year inquiry, which has led to a further seven councillors and council officers being bailed and involves 3,283 inquiries into allegations of expenses fiddles and planning fraud. Although convictions so far have involved relatively minor sums, the Danum team is working on claims of large-scale planning fraud. Detective Superintendent Graham Johnson, head of the operation, said yesterday: "We will be giving careful consideration to the judge's comments, after which we will take a decision, but I can't pre-judge the outcome of the meeting." Martin Wainwright Donkeys pollution suspects Blackpool's famous donkeys could be partly to blame for the pollution of the resort's beaches. Research is being carried out to discover whether donkeys and seagulls can be blamed and so avoid Britain being fined by the European commission for failing to clean up Blackpool and Southport beaches 16 years after first being taken to court for the same offence. Since then North West Water has been forced to spend £350m to try to cure the problem but has failed to do so. Yesterday the company and the department of the environment claimed that seagulls and donkeys might be to blame for excess bacteria in the sea. Michael Meacher, the environment minister, admitted yesterday that Britain had been slow to react to the 1993 judgment made in the European court of justice of a "chronic failure" to meet quality standards. The department has two months to make a reasoned defence to the charge that it has failed to clean up the beaches in order to stave off a fine. "Two of his presumed victims died on the 13th, one in October and the other in December," a police source in Paris said. "He was born on May 13. There's nearly always a pattern with serial killings." Sid Ahmed Rezala, who was detained on Tuesday by French and Portuguese police in a working class suburb of Lisbon, is due to appear in court today to be formally charged with murder and remanded in custody pending arrival of extradition papers from France. The state prosecutor in Amiens, Dominique Lebras, said Rezala should be extradited within a fortnight. He added that the 20-year-old Algerian-born suspect could be held for 40 days in Portugal and that "the top priority is to avoid any technical error in the relevant paperwork." The state prosecutor in Chateauroux, near the small disused station where the body of Ms Peake was found, said yesterday that he would be "putting some very precise questions to Mr Rezala as soon as he is back in France". A reconstruction of her death will be staged on Saturday to test the theory that she was pushed to her death from a train door or window, said the prosecutor, Christian Ponsard. But the plan to kill Clifford Jones, 35, fell apart when the would-be killer, Matthew Lee, attacked him as he slept at the couple's home in Beckdale, Uttoxeter, Staffordshire, on last February. The jury heard that Lee, 57, hit Mr Jones with a 24inch metal crowbar. The blow woke him up and he managed to fend off the attack and escape to safety. Bernard Thorogood, prosecuting, said Sandra Jones, 38, had discussed murdering her husband of 12 years with her best friend, Julie Harvey. Jones pleaded guilty to conspiring to murder her husband at an earlier hearing. Lee, of Uttoxeter, denies conspiring to murder Mr Jones. He claims he was elsewhere when the attack occurred. The case continues. Nick Hopkins

fields.headline: Decision leaves Labour divided
fields.standfirst:
Pinochet on trial: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour MPs were divided yesterday over Jack Straw's decision to allow Augusto Pinochet to return home; some condemning the move as "monstrous" and others praising the home secretary for playing a straight bat.
fields.body:
Labour MPs were divided yesterday over Jack Straw's decision to allow Augusto Pinochet to return home; some condemning the move as "monstrous" and others praising the home secretary for playing a straight bat.

Leftwingers, who were delighted by Mr Straw's handling of the Pinochet case until Tuesday night, were dismayed the home secretary had bowed to pressure from Chile to free him on medical grounds.

However, many Labour MPs, including leftwingers such as the outspoken George Galloway, felt Mr Straw had no other choice after an independent medical panel found unambiguous evidence of a deterioration in Pinochet's medical condition.

The human rights campaigner Ann Clywd led the charge against Mr Straw when she expressed "deep dismay" at his decision, saying he should release the medical report. Ms Clywd, who is angry that Mr Straw is respecting Pinochet's medical confidentiality, said groups such as Amnesty International would be unable to challenge his decision without access to the report.

"When it is a question of whether somebody is fit enough to stand trial for allegedly the most serious human rights abuses, there can be no doubt the public interest would be served by allowing access to all relevant medical details," the MP for Cynon Valley said. "After all, nobody is suggesting that Pinochet isn't fit enough to travel the long journey home to Chile."

Her opposition to Mr Straw was supported, in blunter language, by Tony Benn, who accused Mr Straw of double standards. Speaking in the commons, the veteran MP said: "Last year Britain fought two wars against brutal dictators and many innocent people died, and that was justified on humanitarian grounds. Here is a brutal torturer of people and now you are minded to release him on humanitarian grounds - if [you] release him it will undermine the ethical foreign policy."

The general mood among Labour MPs was one of quiet disappointment that they are unlikely ever to see Pinochet - the hate figure of their generation - stand trial for torture. Most MPs, who were delighted when the home secretary initially gave his approval for Pinochet's extradition, accepted that Mr Straw had little choice.

Even Mr Galloway, a passionate critic of Britain's bombing of Iraq, voiced support. "I am not surprised. Much as I regard Pinochet as a blood-soaked tyrant, if the doctors say he is unfit to stand trial then he is unfit to stand trial. It would be reducing ourselves to Pinochet's level if we pursued the matter vindictively in the teeth of medical evidence."

A powerful opponent of the military operation in Kosovo stood by the home secretary, saying that he still did not doubt Mr Straw's hatred of Pinochet. Robert Marshall-Andrews, a leading QC and the MP for Medway, said that much had been achieved since Pinochet was arrested in hospital in October 1998.

"This odious man has been effectively tried in an English court," the MP said. "The crimes and the infamy that he committed have been revealed in that court [which] has found that he has the clearest possible case to answer."

Mr Marshall-Andrew added that the Pinochet affair had revealed a "very dark side" to the Tories after the likes of Margaret Thatcher led a campaign to free the former dictator.

His remarks showed that any divisions among Labour MPs will be outweighed by their unanimous opposition to the Tories' support for Pinochet. The senior Labour backbencher Donald Anderson, who raised objections to Mr Straw's decision, voiced the thoughts of many Labour MPs when he chided Ann Widdecombe in the commons for failing to express any concern about the victims of Pinochet's regime.

fields.headline: Body found in trunk
fields.trailText: A murder hunt was launched yesterday after the body of a young woman was found in a clothes trunk which had been dumped on a track in countryside near Andover, Hampshire. The discovery was made by a rambler who saw the black case partly hidden in undergrowth.
fields.body:
A murder hunt was launched yesterday after the body of a young woman was found in a clothes trunk which had been dumped on a track in countryside near Andover, Hampshire. The discovery was made by a rambler who saw the black case partly hidden in undergrowth.

Police said the woman was probably in her late teens or early 20s but did not expect to formally identify her before today. The cause of death was unclear and a home office pathologist was due to perform a post mortem last night.

A team of 30 officers led by Detective Superintendent Mike Lane sealed off the area and began a finger-tip search of the surrounding woodland and fields. The road between the villages of Enham Alamein and Hurstbourne Hill was closed.

The area being searched was near the A343 between Andover and Newbury. "A lot of commuters use it, so it is more than likely that somebody from far away came to dump the body," said one resident.

webTitle: Tea for two and a way out for Straw

fields.headline: Tea for two and a way out for Straw
fields.standfirst:
A ploy by the Chileans resolved the affair without loss of face
Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The route to freedom for General Augusto Pinochet started in a tiny room at the United Nations last September. Over a cup of tea, looking out on New York's East river, Chile's foreign minister, Juan Gabriel Valdes, outlined to the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, a new approach to the Pinochet saga.
fields.body:
The route to freedom for General Augusto Pinochet started in a tiny room at the United Nations last September. Over a cup of tea, looking out on New York's East river, Chile's foreign minister, Juan Gabriel Valdes, outlined to the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, a new approach to the Pinochet saga.

Until that point, the emphasis of the Chilean argument for the return of their former president had been on the damage the case was causing to relations between the two countries, and that it was an infringement of Chilean sovereignty. Far down the list of arguments had been that the former dictator was an old man, with failing health.

But, to the surprise of the British government, Mr Valdes turned the list round, and for the first time made his appeal on humanitarian grounds. He promised to submit evidence of the general's ill health to the British government. This medical argument seems to have provided the way out of the dilemma faced by the home secretary, Jack Straw, since Gen Pinochet's arrival in London in 1998.

Throughout, Mr Straw has presented himself as a prisoner of the law, and insisted that all his decisions have been taken in his semi-judicial capacity, free of political influence. He claimed he had ignored the demonstrators from left and right, the former wanting justice for the human rights abuses that followed Gen Pinochet's 1973 military coup, and the latter parading him not only as Britain's staunch ally during the Falklands war but the scourge of Marxism.

The home secretary's aides are adamant that Mr Straw, despite his own background as a student leftwinger at the time of the coup, had stood above it all, not even consulting his cabinet colleagues. He had looked only at the legal arguments.

Outside influences

But no one, even a judge, is immune to influences from the outside world, and there was tremendous pressure from the Chilean government. Mr Straw conceded in the Commons yesterday that a factor had been the Chilean government's representation on health grounds.

Following the UN meeting, the Chilean government submitted its medical evidence on October 14. The Chilean ambassador, Pablo Cabrera, only recently arrived in London, passed the information to the foreign office, which, acting as a postbox, in turn gave it to Mr Straw.

Mr Cabrera, a former junior defence minister, yesterday welcomed the imminent release of Gen Pinochet, 84. "As soon as I arrived in September, I went to see senator Pinochet," he said. "If the Chilean government was to make a representation on humanitarian grounds, we had to verify his health condition. He is an old man, carrying all the problems of an old man. He suffered his main illnesses between September and November."

Mr Cabrera asked four doctors to look at Gen Pinochet, two British and two Chileans who were flown in from Santiago. They concluded that he suffered from 12 separate ailments, including diabetes, cardiac problems and depression. That formed the basis of the report submitted to Mr Straw on October 14.

"The danger of Pinochet dying is permanent," Mr Cabrera said. "I have looked often at the Guardian obituaries page and 70% of the people in it are between 70 and 85 years-old. I have studied that figure. The situation of Pinochet and his health condition was very likely to deteriorate, having in mind he is 84."

It was this that mattered to Mr Straw, not the protests from the general's friends such as Baroness Thatcher and the former chancellor, Lord Lamont. The campaign for his release was well-funded, reaching a culmination at the Tory party conference in October, when Lady Thatcher described him as Britain's sole political prisoner.

But such a gathering of old right-wingers was counterproductive, rather than helpful. The personalities involved were hardly likely to win much sympathy from Mr Straw.

The left too was beginning to waver. Despite the outbursts yesterday from left-wing MPs involved in the campaign, some said privately that Gen Pinochet had been humiliated enough, and that there was little to be gained from pursuing the extradition case. There was a fear that he might die in Britain and become a rightwing martyr.

In Chile too, the issue was far from clear-cut. Early predictions of intense damage to relations between the two countries failed to materialise. One Chilean diplomat insisted yesterday that relations had been damaged, but even he admitted that it had only been to a limited extent. The foreign office too does not believe the damage is serious.

After considering the medical report submitted by the Chilean government, Mr Straw ordered his own team of doctors to check out the general. He received their report last Thursday evening. Although Lord Lamont had confusingly reported Gen Pinochet as being in good form, the doctors concurred with the verdict of the earlier team, that he was seriously ill.

Mr Straw has refused to make public the medical grounds, but in the Commons yesterday he hinted that the general was senile. He said he had to take into account whether Gen Pinochet was fit enough to follow court proceedings and was able to give a coherent statement. The home secretary concluded that he was not.

Mr Straw has not convinced critics that he was entirely impartial. "It is bound to look like a political decision, and up until now he [Straw] has been very careful not to interfere in the case," said Geoffrey Bindman, a lawyer for the human rights organisation Amnesty International.

"My feeling is that it should be a matter for the Spanish authorities whether he is fit to stand trial or not. There's no suggestion that he is not fit to at least travel to Spain," Mr Bindman said.

Disrupted plans

Mr Straw had planned to make the decision public yesterday in a parliamentary written statement, but the Chilean government even disrupted those plans.

The home secretary informed Mr Cook about his decision on Monday. On Tuesday afternoon, Mr Cook telephoned the Chilean foreign minister, telling him that a statement was imminent but not its contents. But the Chilean government is extremely leaky and it was soon clear that the news would not keep overnight.

Faced with the prospect of the British public learning about his decision via Santiago, Mr Straw rushed out his statement late on Tuesday night.

Gen Pinochet now looks set to be on his way home. The saga has been full of unexpected twists and a late legal challenge is still possible, but unlikely.

One British government source warned against reading too much into the role of Chilean diplomats, saying: "The medical evidence could have gone either way." Maybe, but it was still a good ploy by the Chileans, with at worst, a 50-50 chance of success.

The Chilean government, careful not to celebrate too soon, privately warned yesterday that while British-Chile relations can recover from this episode, there will be an explosion if there is further delay.

Only when Gen Pinochet's plane is in the air will Chilean diplomats begin to pat themselves on the back for a smart piece of diplomacy that finally helped to resolve Mr Straw's dilemma.

Chronology

September 3 1999: New Chilean ambassador to Britain, Pablo Cabrera, arrives and sees Gen Pinochet as a matter of priority.

September 21: Chilean foreign minister, Juan Gabriel Valdes, makes new approach to foreign secretary, Robin Cook, in New York.

October 14: Chile formally submits recommendation to Britain for general's release on humanitarian grounds, and includes its own medical report.

November 5: Home secretary, Jack Straw, asks for British team of doctors to examine Pinochet.

January 5 2000: Pinochet has seven hours of tests in north London hospital.

January 6: Straw receives the doctors' report.

January 11: Straw rushes out late-night statement saying he is "minded" to let him go on medical grounds.

webTitle: The specialists who did the tests

fields.headline: The specialists who did the tests
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The four independent doctors who decided the fate of General Augusto Pinochet were yesterday described by Jack Straw as of outstanding national and international reputation. During six hours of medical tests last week it was their job to find out whether the former dictator was fit to stand trial.
fields.body:
The four independent doctors who decided the fate of General Augusto Pinochet were yesterday described by Jack Straw as of outstanding national and international reputation. During six hours of medical tests last week it was their job to find out whether the former dictator was fit to stand trial.

Sir John Grimley Evans is professor of clinical geratology at Oxford university. He is considered a world expert in the health of elderly people and has nearly 40 years' medical experience. Gerontology emerged as a key field of study in the 20th century, as increased average life expectancy in developed countries swelled the numbers of the elderly in the population.

Michael Denham is consultant physician in geriatric medicine at Northwick Park hospital in London, where Gen Pinochet had the medical tests. He has published numerous papers on the care of the elderly and has accumulated a wealth of experience since qualifying in 1961.

Andrew Lees is professor of neurology at the National Hospital for Neurology and Neurosurgery in London. He is a fluent Spanish speaker - the tests were conducted in General Pinochet's native tongue - and is a medical adviser to the British Boxing Board of Control. He specialises in the effects of strokes, Parkinson's disease and other movement disorders. Prof Lees co-authored a book with one of his patients, the ex-England footballer Ray Kennedy, who developed Parkinson's aged 35.

Maria Wyke is a consultant, a fluent Spanish-speaker and a neuropsychologist who specialises in studying brain behaviour relationships. Neuropsychologists have extensive training in the anatomy, physiology, and pathology of the nervous system, mapping out the areas of the brain that may have been injured. Dr Wyke specialises in evaluating and treating people thought to have something wrong with their nervous system.

fields.headline: Extradition refused as 'unjust and oppressive'
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw took his decision not to extradite General Pinochet to Spain under a section of the 1989 Extradition act which requires him not to extradite an alleged offender if he believes it would be "unjust or oppressive" to do so.
fields.body:
Jack Straw took his decision not to extradite General Pinochet to Spain under a section of the 1989 Extradition act which requires him not to extradite an alleged offender if he believes it would be "unjust or oppressive" to do so.

The move was last used in March 1998, when Mr Straw decided not to extradite Roisin McAliskey to Germany to face charges in connection with an IRA bomb attack on a British army base.

In both cases the decision was taken on medical grounds, although it may be done on others, such as that the offence was trivial or the accusations were not made in good faith, or because of the passage of time since the alleged offences.

The home secretary's discretion not to surrender someone after the magistrate has committed them for extradition is wide. He is required to consider the personal circumstances of the alleged offender and any new evidence since the committal.

In the McAliskey case, Mr Straw faced allegations that he was acting on political rather than medical grounds, to appease Sinn Fein. Gen Pinochet's supporters have accused Mr Straw of acting politically in not freeing the ailing ex-dictator sooner.

In fact, Mr Straw has strictly followed the letter of the law. Lawyers believe the general would have had a good chance of being freed on "unjust or oppressive" grounds during his forthcoming application for habeas corpus. Mr Straw may simply have accelerated the process.

Lawyers expected him to argue that it would be unjust or oppressive to surrender him to Spain because of the passage of time; that witnesses had died or memories had faded. A second likely argument was that he had been allowed to enter Britain freely and return to Chile several times, lulling him into a false sense of security. Gen Pinochet is also entitled to the normal doctor-patient confidentiality unless he chooses to waive it, which he has declined to do.

Campaigners for his extradition complained yesterday that without access to the medical reports, it would be difficult to mount a high court challenge to Mr Straw's decision. With "unequivocal and unanimous" reports from four distinguished doctors that Gen Pinochet is unfit to stand trial, success is unlikely.

Given the specialties of the doctors asked to examine the general, it may be that the ageing process and his strokes have impaired his ability to follow court proceedings and instruct his lawyers, making it difficult for him to have a fair trial. A trial could result in a breach of the European Convention on Human Rights.

In criminal cases tried in Britain, it is not unusual for prosecutions to be avoided or discontinued if the accused is in poor health, or old and frail.

webTitle: Traffic mars London in quality of life poll

fields.headline: Traffic mars London in quality of life poll
fields.standfirst: Glasgow and Birmingham feature in list of top world cities
fields.trailText: London ranks 34th in the world for quality of living, ahead of New York but behind Berlin, Paris and Tokyo.
fields.body:
London ranks 34th in the world for quality of living, ahead of New York but behind Berlin, Paris and Tokyo.

The survey, conducted by William M Mercer, one of the world's largest human resources consultancies, judged the cities according to a set of 10 criteria each marked out of 10. These ranged from political, economic and social environment, through healthcare and educational provision to recreation and transport infrastructure.

Each city was scored with New York used as the base city with a score of 100 which put it in 50th place. Overall US cities suffered on the grounds of high crime rates and unfavourable personal security issues. The highest ranked US city was Honolulu with 104 points.

London was marginally ahead of New York with 101.5. The report cited factors such as the city's good international relations and the ceasefire with the IRA as positive aspects in the political and social environment.

It also scored maximum points for the personal freedom allowed its residents and freedom from "troublesome and destructive animals and insects". Its poorest scores - six out 10 - were awarded for its climate and traffic congestion.

Ken Livingstone, Labour candidate as mayor of London, last night said it was unfair to compare large international cities with small cities since the smaller ones were far easier to run.

"You have to look at cities of 5m people plus. On that basis we're a damn sight better than Tokyo and New York." said Mr Livingstone.

"In terms of the great world cities I would probably put us joint first with Paris where their main advantages are the quality of the transport system and the fact that there are people living in its central business district. I do think that within a few years London could establish a lead if it could just improve its transport."

Behind London were Glasgow, with 99 points, and Birmingham, with 98, ranked 55th and 60th respectively.

Alex Mosson, the lord provost of Glasgow, was delighted with the result for a city that in the 1960s and 1970s was perceived as a home for gang warfare and deprivation.

He said: "This survey confirms what we have believed all along that Glasgow is a leading international city."

Albert Bore, leader of Birmingham city council, was equally pleased with his city's performance. He said: "We were particularly pleased to compare so well with modern vibrant cities like Chicago, New York, Barcelona and Madrid."

The only other city in the British Isles to be included in the survey was Dublin which was awarded 101 points and ranked 40th in the world.

In joint first place were Vancouver, Berne, Vienna and Zurich while Sydney, Geneva, Auckland and Copenhagen tied for second. Swiss cities occupied three of the top 10 slots making it the single most successful country of all those surveyed.

Brazzaville, the capital of Congo in Africa, with a score of 23 was the bottom of the table with the lowest quality of living. Mercer's attributed this to the continuing civil war in the region.

webTitle: Forces ban on gays is lifted

fields.headline: Forces ban on gays is lifted
fields.trailText: The long-standing ban on homosexuals in the armed forces was finally lifted yesterday in a historic move forced on the government by the European court of human rights. The move was hailed by gay campaigners, and accepted by military chiefs through gritted teeth.
fields.body:
The long-standing ban on homosexuals in the armed forces was finally lifted yesterday in a historic move forced on the government by the European court of human rights. The move was hailed by gay campaigners, and accepted by military chiefs through gritted teeth.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, announced a new code of service conduct covering all personal relationships - heterosexual and homosexual. He told the Commons the ban on gays was no longer legally sustainable following the court's judgment in September that sexual orientation was a private matter.

The new code will apply regardless of rank, gender, or sexual orientation. At its heart will be what the ministry of defence calls the "service test" set out in the form of a question: "Have the actions or behaviour of an individual adversely impacted on or are they likely to impact on the efficiency or operational effectiveness of the service?"

The code, which will be applied at the discretion of individual commanders, is based on the principle of non-discrimination and the recognition that different standards of public behaviour, on flouting sexuality for example, are needed for the armed forces.

It states: "The overriding operational imperative to sustain team cohesion and to maintain trust and loyalty between commanders and those they command imposes a need for standards of social behaviour which are more demanding than those required by society at large."

As examples of behaviour which could undermine such trust and cohesion, it cites "unwelcome sexual attention in the form of physical or verbal conduct" and "displays of affection which might cause offence to others.

"It is important to acknowl edge in the tightly-knit military community a need for mutual respect ... each case will be judged on its merits."

Stonewall, which campaigns for gay and lesbian equality, welcomed the new code which, it said, should provide protection against sexual harassment, discrimination, and bullying. Angela Mason, its executive director, described it as "absolutely sensible". The ban on homosexuality in the armed forces had been "a great symbol of inequality".

Steve Johnston, chairman of Rank Outsiders, set up to support those dismissed from the services for being gay, said: "We will closely watch the implementation of the ruling and we are keen to work closely with the MoD to ensure equality and fairness for all."

But Peter Tatchell, of Outrage!, the gay pressure group, said that "deeply entrenched homophobic attitudes will continue to force many gay people out of the services, unless the military authorities take tough new action to combat the victimisation of homosexual personnel".

Acknowledging resistance in the services against lifting the ban, Mr Hoon said: "There will be those who would have preferred to continue to exclude homosexuals but the law is the law.

"We cannot pick and choose the decisions we implement. The status quo is simply not an option."

Navy commanders are likely to be most concerned - they have argued forcefully in favour of maintaining the ban.

Iain Duncan Smith, the shadow defence spokesman, attacked the decision. "I believe and have always believed, as the previous government did, that we should follow the advice of the armed forces which has always been that lifting the ban would adversely affect operational effectiveness."

Women will still be barred from some front-line duties.

webTitle: A tragedy waiting to happen for defenceless trawlermen

fields.headline: A tragedy waiting to happen for defenceless trawlermen
fields.trailText: Inspectors charged with investigating accidents at sea last night began a potentially lengthy inquiry into why the 21.3m (70ft) modern vessel foundered during a night of wild weather off the Isle of Man.
fields.body:
Inspectors charged with investigating accidents at sea last night began a potentially lengthy inquiry into why the 21.3m (70ft) modern vessel foundered during a night of wild weather off the Isle of Man.

The inspectors belong to the Southampton-based Marine Accident Investigation branch, set up in 1989 as an independent arm of the department of the environment, transport and the regions.

Their job is to establish why the accident happened, and to make recommendations to prevent similar accidents in the future.

But Dr Ian Duncan, the secretary of the Aberdeen-based Scottish Fishermen's Association, said fishing was a most dangerous job and that the cause of some accidents could be attributed only to the peril of the sea.

"An accident such as this makes all of us aware that, whatever precautions we take and however safe we try to be, we are dealing with nature and nature can surprise you.

"If you look at the circumstances of this tragedy, you have a young crew out in a boat in weather which suddenly goes from a five to six gale to a force nine. That can mean waves 100ft high. With the best boat, the most experienced seamen and the finest equipment, all you can do is look at waves like that and hope that you will come through it.

"This is a tragedy because I suspect it wasn't preventable. They were in the wrong place at the wrong time. The sea is treacherous and unpredictable. There is not one fisherman who cannot give you one example of when they thought, 'This is it'. Some have been working for 30 or 40 years and are still surprised by the sea."

The MAIB can launch three kinds of investigation. The loss of the Solway Harvester has prompted an inspector's inquiry, the most rigorous of the three.

fields.headline: Broadcaster to sue police
fields.standfirst: Accident victim McDonald angry at not guilty verdict
fields.trailText: Sheena McDonald is to sue the Metropolitan police for "substantial damages" after the officer who was at the wheel of a van which knocked her down was cleared of reckless driving yesterday.
fields.body:
Sheena McDonald is to sue the Metropolitan police for "substantial damages" after the officer who was at the wheel of a van which knocked her down was cleared of reckless driving yesterday.

The broadcaster, who suffered brain injuries as a result of the accident, said she was shocked at the magistrates' decision, and would be able to demonstrate that she was "entirely blameless".

At Horseferry Road magistrates' court in London yesterday, Glenn Whiteley was cleared of driving without due care and attention. The magistrate, Eleri Rees, ruled that the prosecution had failed to prove that his standard of driving had fallen so low as to be incompetent.

PC Whiteley, 27, who denied the charge, said in evidence that he was driving to the "best of his ability" on the night. The officer, who was answering an emergency call, had found his path blocked by stationary traffic, so crossed on to the other side of the two-way road. Ms McDonald stepped out in front of the van, was knocked down and became trapped under the vehicle.

Ms McDonald, 44, said yesterday: "I am disappointed by this decision and genuinely shocked. There are different burdens of proof in the civil courts and I have absolutely no doubt that I will succeed in showing that the police officer drove recklessly and that I was entirely blameless.

"As I will be able to demonstrate, the state of the van being driven by the officer defies belief, being unroadworthy under British law. It seems to be incredible that it could have passed its MoT. It certainly would not have done so had it been owned by anyone other than the police."

Her solicitors said that a civil action for substantial compensation would be launched at the high court in London soon. Evidence has already been gathered; her lawyers have been awaiting the outcome of the criminal trial.

It is thought that the broadcaster could seek a six-figure sum - she has not worked for most of the past year. Previously, she was a high-earning freelance broadcaster and often presented Channel 4 News.

The collision on February 27 last year happened near Ms McDonald's home in Islington, north London. She had been attending a Bafta function where she had two glasses of wine, but insisted that she was not drunk.

PC Whiteley said he had slowed down when he saw her at the side of the road, but claimed he made eye contact with her and assumed she had seen the van: its lights were flashing and siren blazing. "She stepped out, no warning at all," he told the court.

Ms McDonald was in a coma for 72 hours and had major facial surgery during which a titanium staple was inserted into her head.

She was in intensive care for two weeks and required treatment for a further two months. Her recovery has been slow, and she has only recently resumed working.

At the end of the two-day hearing, the magistrate said she had dismissed the case after hearing evidence that any reasonable person could be ex pected to have spotted the van, with its blue lights flashing and sirens sounding. PC Whiteley had not acted irresponsibly. "It was reasonable for him to proceed as he did at the moderate speed of 20mph or less and to expect that Ms McDonald would not be in danger," Mrs Rees said.

After the verdict, the Met said: "Metropolitan police service drivers respond to thousands of emergency calls every year and the number of incidents which result in injury to members of the public or police officers are relatively few.

"In 1999, Metropolitan police drivers responded to nearly 1.5m emergency calls, most attended by more than one police vehicle. During the same period there were 243 collisions resulting in injuries to members of the public. Of that number, 229 suffered slight injuries such as shock, with 14 resulting in serious injury."
