webTitle: Scottish fishing village mourns seven dead

fields.headline: Scottish fishing village mourns seven dead
fields.standfirst: Twenty-hour search off the Isle of Man called off after trawler found on ocean floor, devastating a community that 'exists for the sea'
fields.trailText: They knew that one day such a tragedy would come. Those who take their living from the sea know death is always a risk. But, as hopes yesterday finally faded after the discovery of the Solway Harvester's second uninflated lifeboat, that knowledge did not make reality any easier to bear.
fields.byline: Gerard Seenan in Isle of Whithorn
fields.body:
They knew that one day such a tragedy would come. Those who take their living from the sea know death is always a risk. But, as hopes yesterday finally faded after the discovery of the Solway Harvester's second uninflated lifeboat, that knowledge did not make reality any easier to bear.

Seven men had gone down with the trawler on Tuesday night, including two brothers and their cousin. An all-night sea and air search was scaled down yesterday afternoon after the boat was found on the seabed south of the Isle of Man, close to where it had put out a distress call 20 hours earlier.

Isle of Whithorn, where several of the men lived, is a picture-postcard village in south-west Scotland. It is the sort of place where everyone knows everyone. And, yesterday, everyone was grieving.

Overnight there had been hope. It had been many hours since, at 5.40pm, the Solway Harvester had signalled its sister ship, the Tobrach-N, to say it was looking for shelter. That was the last anyone heard from the scallop dredger.

In the morning, the names of the seven were made public. The skipper, Craig Mills, 29, his brother, Robin Mills, 33, their cousin David Mills, 18, and the rest of the crew: John Murphy, 22, David Lyons, 17, Martin Milligan, 26, and Wesley Jolly, 17.

After the names were released, their stories began to unfold.

The skipper, Craig Mills, was an experienced fisherman, a local man who worked his way up from boatboy to lead his own boat. The sea was his life: his work and hobby. His partner, Jane Galloway, and their daughter Rachel, five, had been waiting for him to return home.

"The village exists for the sea. It is the sea that created the village, everybody here has some connection with the sea," said a local hotelier, Jim Scoular. "These young men were known to everybody here, particularly the skipper Craig."

There were also the ironies of tragedy. Robin Mills was never meant to have been on the boat. He ran his own painting and decorating business from the nearby village of Whithorn, and had only joined the crew as a favour to his brother, who was short-handed because of flu.

At the harbourside in Kircudbright, where the boat had been due to dock at 2am, the man Robin Mills replaced sat in tears. James Gorman, 26, was too upset to speak. He just sat and waited until there was no more hope.

Everyone at the harbourside felt his pain. Alistair Murray, a local skipper, said: "It is like a knot in the pit of your stomach. I know that one skipper went and threw up when he heard."

In Whithorn, Robin Mills's wife, Karen, waited for news of her husband with her daughter Sarah, two. She is expecting their second child in the summer.

"People are devastated beyond approach," said Eddie McGuire, 75, a local man who still goes to sea. "They were all friendly, just a bunch of fishermen. They would do anything for you."

Not all of the seven had chosen careers on the sea. David Mills, like his cousin, only agreed to go on the dredger to help out the skipper. He had been to sea a few times but he was no fisherman.

At the local high school, which all seven men had, at some stage, attended, the headteacher said the four youngest crewmen had looked forward to working on ships. Jim Douglas said it was all they had wanted to do. "They were lively and fun and all four were enthusiastic about their chosen career in fishing and were looking forward to life," he said.

The Solway Harvester went down in high seas. Bob McLaughlin of the Workington lifeboat, part of the search effort, said: "The wind was blowing force nine and the conditions were atrocious, absolutely atrocious. We took a hammering and the boat came down from 17 knots to three knots. Crew members were thrown about and bruised."

Steve Buttery, deputy launching officer of the Douglas lifeboat, said: "We found a liferaft during the night with name of the missing boat on it. It was still in its container and had never been deployed. Con ditions were bloody awful, with a really big sea."

South of Isle of Whithorn, cliff rescue teams on the Isle of Man spent Tuesday night on the highest points along a 30-mile stretch of the island's east coast, their volunteers scouring the sea for red distress flares - "and any signs of life", according to Erica Kermode of the island's coastguard. Small bays on the rugged north coast were searched in the hope that the men had got to shore. "In situations like this, you are working with 'just maybes'," she said.

Six lifeboats, three helicopters, a light aircraft, a navy tanker, an Isle of Man passenger ferry and several fishing boats joined the search, covering an area of more than 800 square miles.

John King, of fish wholesaler West Coast Sea Products, said the boat's disappearance was a "total mystery" and the fact that the crew had not been able to reach the liferafts suggested it had sunk fast.

"The vessel is fit for any weather we get here," he said. Something serious has happened - a collision or something, but something sudden has happened."

By mid-afternoon in Isle of Whithorn, the streets were deserted. The villagers, thrust into the limelight of unfortunate fame, retreated indoors.

In the pub the talk was of only one thing: the deaths and how such a tragedy could possibly have happened. The boat was modern, the weather only hours before contact was lost was rough but not terrible. No manual mayday was launched.

But in a community where so many lives are intertwined, it was the scale of the loss which was so marked. "All the men came here for a drink, Craig's partner was my chef, Wesley had been a pot boy here," said Mr Scoular at the Steam Packet Inn, overlooking the bay.

"People think the Irish Sea is calm, but it can be rough. And cruel: it has been cruel today."

But, as hopes yesterday finally faded after the discovery of the Solway Harvester's second uninflated lifeboat, that knowledge did not make reality any easier to bear. Seven men had gone down with the trawler on Tuesday night, including two brothers and their cousin. An all-night sea and air search was scaled down yesterday afternoon after the boat was found on the seabed south of the Isle of Man, close to where it had put out a distress call 20 hours earlier. Isle of Whithorn, where several of the men lived, is a picture-postcard village in south-west Scotland. It is the sort of place where everyone knows everyone. And, yesterday, everyone was grieving. Overnight there had been hope. It had been many hours since, at 5.40pm, the Solway Harvester had signalled its sister ship, the Tobrach-N, to say it was looking for shelter. That was the last anyone heard from the scallop dredger. In the morning, the names of the seven were made public. The skipper, Craig Mills, 29, his brother, Robin Mills, 33, their cousin David Mills, 18, and the rest of the crew: John Murphy, 22, David Lyons, 17, Martin Milligan, 26, and Wesley Jolly, 17. After the names were released, their stories began to unfold. The skipper, Craig Mills, was an experienced fisherman, a local man who worked his way up from boatboy to lead his own boat. The sea was his life: his work and hobby. His partner, Jane Galloway, and their daughter Rachel, five, had been waiting for him to return home. "The village exists for the sea. It is the sea that created the village, everybody here has some connection with the sea," said a local hotelier, Jim Scoular. "These young men were known to everybody here, particularly the skipper Craig." There were also the ironies of tragedy. Robin Mills was never meant to have been on the boat. He ran his own painting and decorating business from the nearby village of Whithorn, and had only joined the crew as a favour to his brother, who was short-handed because of flu. At the harbourside in Kircudbright, where the boat had been due to dock at 2am, the man Robin Mills replaced sat in tears. James Gorman, 26, was too upset to speak. He just sat and waited until there was no more hope. Everyone at the harbourside felt his pain. Alistair Murray, a local skipper, said: "It is like a knot in the pit of your stomach. I know that one skipper went and threw up when he heard." In Whithorn, Robin Mills's wife, Karen, waited for news of her husband with her daughter Sarah, two. She is expecting their second child in the summer. "People are devastated beyond approach," said Eddie McGuire, 75, a local man who still goes to sea. "They were all friendly, just a bunch of fishermen. They would do anything for you." Not all of the seven had chosen careers on the sea. David Mills, like his cousin, only agreed to go on the dredger to help out the skipper. He had been to sea a few times but he was no fisherman. At the local high school, which all seven men had, at some stage, attended, the headteacher said the four youngest crewmen had looked forward to working on ships. Jim Douglas said it was all they had wanted to do. "They were lively and fun and all four were enthusiastic about their chosen career in fishing and were looking forward to life," he said. The Solway Harvester went down in high seas. Bob McLaughlin of the Workington lifeboat, part of the search effort, said: "The wind was blowing force nine and the conditions were atrocious, absolutely atrocious. We took a hammering and the boat came down from 17 knots to three knots. Crew members were thrown about and bruised." Steve Buttery, deputy launching officer of the Douglas lifeboat, said: "We found a liferaft during the night with name of the missing boat on it. It was still in its container and had never been deployed. Con ditions were bloody awful, with a really big sea." South of Isle of Whithorn, cliff rescue teams on the Isle of Man spent Tuesday night on the highest points along a 30-mile stretch of the island's east coast, their volunteers scouring the sea for red distress flares - "and any signs of life", according to Erica Kermode of the island's coastguard. Small bays on the rugged north coast were searched in the hope that the men had got to shore. "In situations like this, you are working with 'just maybes'," she said. Six lifeboats, three helicopters, a light aircraft, a navy tanker, an Isle of Man passenger ferry and several fishing boats joined the search, covering an area of more than 800 square miles. John King, of fish wholesaler West Coast Sea Products, said the boat's disappearance was a "total mystery" and the fact that the crew had not been able to reach the liferafts suggested it had sunk fast. "The vessel is fit for any weather we get here," he said. Something serious has happened - a collision or something, but something sudden has happened." By mid-afternoon in Isle of Whithorn, the streets were deserted. The villagers, thrust into the limelight of unfortunate fame, retreated indoors. In the pub the talk was of only one thing: the deaths and how such a tragedy could possibly have happened. The boat was modern, the weather only hours before contact was lost was rough but not terrible. No manual mayday was launched. But in a community where so many lives are intertwined, it was the scale of the loss which was so marked. "All the men came here for a drink, Craig's partner was my chef, Wesley had been a pot boy here," said Mr Scoular at the Steam Packet Inn, overlooking the bay. "People think the Irish Sea is calm, but it can be rough. And cruel: it has been cruel today."

fields.headline: Tyson on list of UK 'undesirables'
fields.trailText: Mike Tyson was placed on a list of undesirable visitors who should not be allowed automatic entry to Britain soon after his 1992 conviction for rape, the home office confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
Mike Tyson was placed on a list of undesirable visitors who should not be allowed automatic entry to Britain soon after his 1992 conviction for rape, the home office confirmed yesterday.

Officials said the US boxer's name was one of about half a million on the "suspects index", which gives immigration officers the right to refuse entry to Britain unless it is justified on compassionate grounds. Most on the list have been convicted of serious criminal offences. Around 20 people are refused entry on such grounds each year.

Tyson is due to fight the British boxer Julius Francis in Manchester on January 29. Last night his management in New York confirmed that he was booked on Concorde to fly to Heathrow on Sunday.

A spokesman said: "He's booked on the flight, there's no change to that. We will not comment further until we have heard formally from the home office."

The future of the sell-out clash, Tyson's first fight outside America, has been thrown into doubt because of rules which state that entry into the country should be refused to anyone who has committed a crime that would carry a 12-month jail term or more in Britain.

Tyson was jailed for six years in 1992 for rape and last year was sentenced to 12 months for attacking two motorists.

Tyson faces the ignominy of arriving at Heathrow and being detained until immigration officals make their decision. If they refuse, he could be returned on the next flight to America.

The fight is being promoted by the Sports Network company, owned by Frank Warren, who could lose millions of pounds if it is cancelled.

Julia Onslow-Cole, a lawyer who specialises in such cases, said: "There are no strong compassionate grounds for Tyson's entry. A number of high-profile people have been refused entry to Britain on similar grounds and very few cases are won on compassionate grounds."

fields.headline: Brown attack 'unfounded'
fields.standfirst:
Angry Labour seeks apology after row over flat purchase
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour last night demanded an apology from the Tories over what were described as "completely unfounded" attacks on Gordon Brown over his purchase of a London flat.
fields.body:
Labour last night demanded an apology from the Tories over what were described as "completely unfounded" attacks on Gordon Brown over his purchase of a London flat.

Last weekend the Sunday Times accused the chancellor of getting the property at a bargain price from the receivers of a Robert Maxwell company that had gone into receivership, and suggested he might have been tipped off about the flat - implicitly by the former treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson.

The Sunday Times stated: "A search of local newspapers and estate agents found no evidence that the flat was advertised on the open market."

Last night Giles Radice, chairman of the all-party Commons treasury select committee, said: "It is clear that he bought it on the open market through an estate agent and took out a mortgage like anyone else. The estate agent has made clear it was a routine sale."

Embarrassingly for the Sunday Times, it emerged that its Insight investigative team missed a three-line advertisement in their own paper on May 10 1992, advertising the same flat.

The Tuckerman agency, which placed the ad for £57.28, also announced that details had been displayed in its office at 40 Great Smith Street, next door to Mr Brown's apartment. Because of a clerical error it initially denied being the firm that made the £130,000 sale.

The chancellor's mortgage is believed to be double the "just over £30,000" claimed by the paper as it questioned how he was able to put down £100,000. Mr Brown has said he paid £5,000 more than the valuation put on the property by his own surveyor during the recession.

Mr Radice said that the Conservative spokesman David Heathcoat-Amory, who led the attack on the chancellor, owed Mr Brown a personal apology at the very least.

The Tories responded in a carefully worded statement last night in which their trade spokesperson, Angela Browning, laid out a string of unanswered complaints about companies run by Mr Robinson, and drew attention to the "close connection" between the government and the receivers involved in the flat sale, Arthur Andersen.

Tory MPs remain convinced that there are too many links between key players in the drama - not least Andersens, the firm of consultants and accountants that handled what the Tories describe as "several spectacular business failures" involving Mr Robinson.

fields.headline: Pinochet failed senility test
fields.standfirst:
Straw left with 'no choice' after team of doctors declared former dictator mentally incapable
Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw gave his personal approval for Augusto Pinochet to be allowed to return home after the former Chilean dictator showed signs of senility to an independent panel of doctors earlier this month.
fields.body:
Jack Straw gave his personal approval for Augusto Pinochet to be allowed to return home after the former Chilean dictator showed signs of senility to an independent panel of doctors earlier this month.

As human rights campaigners drew up plans to challenge the home secretary through the courts, Mr Straw insisted yesterday that he had no choice in the matter after it became clear that Gen Pinochet was mentally incapable of standing trial in Spain on charges of torture.

The Chilean ambassador in London, Pablo Cabrera, underlined the decline in Gen Pinochet's medical condition when he said: "The danger of Pinochet dying is permanent, not imminent."

Mr Straw, who delighted Lady Thatcher on Tuesday night when he announced that he was "minded" to allow the former dictator to return to Chile next week, initially refused to give any details of the medical examination of Gen Pinochet.

But under fierce questioning from the Tories in the House of Commons yesterday, the home secretary made clear that the mental condition of the 84-year-old former dictator had seriously deteriorated towards the end of last year.

Mr Straw stopped short of using the word senility - to have done so would have broken the rules on medical con fidentiality - but his message was clear.

He told MPs: "Among the criteria which I took into account were whether the senator would be in a position to follow the proceedings, whether he could give intelligible instructions to those representing him, whether he could give a coherent statement of his own case and of recollection."

His remarks were echoed by Mr Cabrera: "The situation of Pinochet and his health condition was very likely to deteriorate having in mind he is an 84-year-old man."

Mr Straw decided to appoint a four-strong panel of independent doctors to examine Gen Pinochet on January 5.

Human rights campaigners, who remained unmoved by the descriptions of Gen Pinochet's state, demanded the release of his medical records to allow them to mount an effective challenge. Mr Straw rejected their calls, insisting that he had to respect Gen Pinochet's medical confidentiality.

But Pro-Pinochet Chilean sources said the home office had insisted that the report remain confidential. "It suggested the conditions, including that the report be kept confidential."

Amnesty International and other human rights groups were talking with lawyers last night about whether to mount a legal challenge. A judicial review could centre around the decision to send Gen Pinochet home and Mr Straw's refusal to disclose the medical records.

Before they finalise their legal plans, the human rights groups have seven days to make submissions to Mr Straw in an attempt to persuade him to change his mind.

Geoffrey Bindman, the human rights lawyer who has been advising Amnesty and others on the Pinochet case, said that he did not hold out much hope of a successful legal challenge.

Mr Bindman said a judicial review application was possible, but was unlikely to succeed because the home secretary had wide discretion in extradition cases.

However, he echoed the views of human rights groups around the world that the Pinochet case had been an important landmark in international justice.

"It is fortuitous that Pinochet might be able to cheat justice through ill health, but that does not detract from the importance of the principle that has now been established that former heads of state cannot claim immunity."

The hopes of Gen Pinochet's supporters were also raised when the Spanish government, which has done little to mask its discomfort about being caught in the middle of the Pinochet saga, confirmed that it would not appeal against the decision to send him back to Chile.

Baltasar Garzon, the campaigning Spanish judge responsible for the general's arrest, began preparing his response to the ruling but conceded he had little room to manoeuvre.

"The process has been a success," said a source close to him. "Spanish justice has done what it had to do. If Pinochet returns to Chile it will be after the principle of extradition was granted."

A spokesman for the crown prosecution service, which is acting on behalf of Spain, said no decision had been taken on the next move. "We are waiting for instructions from them as to what stance they want to take. Discussions are going on between the CPS and the Spanish authorities."

Home office sources are bracing themselves for a flurry of activity next week when Mr Straw formally announces his decision.

Human rights activists will have to mount a legal challenge within minutes of Mr Straw's decision to prevent the general from fleeing the country.

Matters will move at a more steady pace if the director of public prosecutions, who has been given access to the medical report on Gen Pinochet, decides to bring either a state prosecution or allow a private prosecution.

However, this is unlikely because the previous DPP turned down an earlier request for a private prosecution.

In Santiago, human rights lawyers promised to ambush Gen Pinochet at the airport with a flurry of legal summons and petitions to strip the former dictator of his senatorial privilege and charge him with kidnapping, murder and torture.

webTitle: City firm unfairly sacked female boss

fields.headline: City firm unfairly sacked female boss
fields.standfirst: Tribunal rules JP Morgan was wrong to dismiss pregnant executive who offered to work from home so she could spend time with children
fields.trailText: A top City banker who regularly worked 14-hour days and at weekends said yesterday she had been forced to committ "professional suicide" in order to spend time with her children, after winning an unfair dismissal case against JP Morgan.
fields.body:
A top City banker who regularly worked 14-hour days and at weekends said yesterday she had been forced to committ "professional suicide" in order to spend time with her children, after winning an unfair dismissal case against JP Morgan.

Aisling Sykes, vice president of the transaction execution group at JP Morgan's London office, said that she had been sacked when she became pregnant for a fourth time and had asked to be allowed to work from home in the evenings in order to spend more time with her children.

A London industrial tribunal heard that Mrs Sykes, 39, had been told by her employers that her request was similar to someone asking to take time off to play squash.

Despite offering to work from home in Kensington, west London, in the evenings, she was still sacked because having more than two children was "viewed as somehow irresponsible".

She told the tribunal how her manager's attitude changed towards her after she gave birth to a daughter Charlotte in June 1994.

She had asked for a computer to be installed at her home to enable her to continue her work but her boss had considered this to be an irritation so she met with her and her personnel manager Elaine Cole to try to come to a compromise.

She said: "During the course of this meeting Elaine Cole inferred that my interest in seeing my child was equivalent to someone wishing to play squash."

The tribunal ruled yesterday that she had been unfairly dis missed, but found that she had not suffered unlawful indirect sex discrimination.

Mrs Sykes said: "My life in the city is shattered - what I've been forced to do is professional suicide.

"We're pleased about the unfair dismissal. We knew from day one that is what it was, but I'm very annoyed that we've had to go to the lengths we have done to get it proved.

"As regards unlawful indirect sexual discrimination, it is regrettable that the tribunal's decision will perpetuate the system where women with children are precluded from combining responsible jobs with actually seeing their children."

She added: "No amount of nannies will compensate a mother's need to spend at least a few minutes out of a 14-hour working day with her children, whatever her salary.

"The manner in which my dismissal was effected was publically humiliating and deeply distressing. It made me feel I had committed some serious act of gross misconduct."

She had told the tribunal that she had consistently worked long hours and on one occasion had even telephoned her boss, Mary Hustings, four hours after giving birth to her third child.

"I went into hospital six weeks early to give birth prematurely to my son, Patrick. Four hours after the birth I rang her up about work.

"Mary Hustings did not enquire once of my health or that of my baby. She knew very well what the situation was."

Mrs Sykes, who took JP Morgan to a county court to get her redundancy money last year, thanked hundreds of other mothers in City jobs who had sent her letters of support.

webTitle: New singer, old song  Charlotte fires her manager

fields.headline: New singer, old song  Charlotte fires her manager
fields.trailText: Charlotte Church, whose voice has earned her £6m and worldwide fame, may be only 13 - but last night showed she is learning the tricks of her trade at a remarkable speed by sacking the manager who made her famous.
fields.body:
Charlotte Church, whose voice has earned her £6m and worldwide fame, may be only 13 - but last night showed she is learning the tricks of her trade at a remarkable speed by sacking the manager who made her famous.

Jonathan Shalit, who discovered Miss Church in 1997, learned of his sacking from solicitors acting on her behalf.

The sudden removal of Mr Shalit, who made her one of the UK's highest earning musical stars, is reminiscent of many musicians who fire their managers once they find fame.

Miss Church fronted a worldwide campaign for Ford last year in a deal thought to be worth £500,000. She has performed for the Queen, the Pope and President Clinton.

A statement by her solicitor, P Russell & Co, last night said: "No decisions have been made about future management, or need to be made just yet, as Charlotte is now back in school for a few weeks."

fields.headline: Wonder women
fields.standfirst: Big hair, lip gloss and hot pants: if only making a feminist statement was as easy today as it was in the 70s. But if television girl power really was that preposterous, why are Channel 4 trying to tell us otherwise?
fields.trailText: Big hair, lip gloss and hot pants: if only making a feminist statement was as easy today as it was in the 70s. But if television girl power really was that preposterous, why are Channel 4 trying to tell us otherwise?
fields.body:
Channel Four have been putting on some increasingly bizarre themed evenings of late, but surely Saturday's Charlie's Angels Night takes the biscuit.

Intended, according to its press blurb, as a homage to this "early shining example of girl power", the night features a profile of Aaron Spelling, creator of the original shebang, a look behind the scenes at the forthcoming film version starring Cameron Diaz, Lucy Liu and Drew Barrymore, an insight into the thoughts of such notable feminist thinkers as Helena Gurley Brown, Jo Whiley, Saffron and Sarah Cracknell as they "look back on their 70s role models" - and the pièce de resistance, a make-up lesson showing us girls how to achieve that "fabulous Farrah Fawcett look".

According to Four, Charlie's Angels provided "an inspiration to a whole generation of girls who saw that they could be as cool, tough and sexy as the boys in all the other cop shows". Um, right.

OK, it's a tricky business for frazzled TV execs desperately wondering what the person on the Clapham omnibus is into, but that they expect them to give a flying flick about Fawcett et al - let alone find Charlie's Angels empowering and inspirational - is as bizarre as Aaron Spelling trying to pass it off as empowering and inspirational to 70s women.

Like the Blaxploitation movies of the same period, Charlie's Angels was ostensibly designed to appeal to a section of society sick of seeing themselves portrayed stereotypically on screen, in the case of women as housewives and mothers. However, like the pimps and hustlers which quickly came to dominate and depoliticise Blaxploitation movies, Charlie's Angels merely provided yet another stereotype, that of the woman who was capable of beating up muscle-bound men twice the size of her as long as she did it in a slinky outfit with hair and lip gloss intact. Like Emma Peel and Won derwoman, Charlie's Angels was really designed with a male audience in mind.

You might have thought that Channel Four would have learned its lesson after such thinly disguised exploitation as The Girlie Show, but no, where The Girlie Show was a bad idea but at least a bad idea of its time, Channel Four have managed to be over five years late with Saturday's turkey.

Had it been scheduled sometime in the early 90s, during the brief vogue for donning Charlie's Angels T-shirts and taking water pistols out clubbing in order to strike appropriate poses on the dancefloor, Charlie's Angels Night would perhaps have been appropriately ironic, in line with the comedy, advertising and culture of the time.

As it stands, however, the only irony about Charlie's Angels night is that, in a time when even Loaded magazine has decided to drop the scantily clad babes which previously dominated its front covers, because, as its publisher Adrian Pettit stated, "With respect to her, who's ever laughed at a comedy or read a book by Caprice?", we find Jo Whiley and co celebrating (as, supposedly, feminists), the act of being little more than alluringly attired. Thanks girls.

Had you told a 70s feminist that 25 years down the line Charlie's Angels would be held up as icons for women themselves, they would have assumed you were joking. Had you told them that applying lip gloss would become a feminist act they'd have laughed in your face.

While it would be silly to ignore the changes feminism has undergone over the past 25 years, it would be sillier to assume that when post-feminists complained about old-style sisters putting restrictions on how they should experience their sexual identities, they were saying that feminism should deal with with the freedom to flick your hair, don a pair of hot pants, and strike a pose with a big gun.

Yet Charlies Angel's Night is an example of the unfortunate deadlocks of post-feminism, where even the most obvious sexist jokes can be reappropriated as "empowering" - in this case by lazy TV execs looking for an excuse to put out some titillating Saturday night telly.

Naff, dated and insulting, Charlie's Angels night is at best a chance to listen to Jo Whiley expounding fuzzy feminist thinking in her uniquely strangled, uptight way, and at worst a worrying indication of where feminism is at. If you're not planning to go out and do something less boring instead, take my advice and rent out some old episodes of Cagney and Lacey.

fields.headline: Ocalan execution stayed
fields.trailText: The leaders of Turkey's governing coalition agreed last night to put the execution of the Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan on hold until the European court of human rights has issued a ruling on the case.
fields.body:
The leaders of Turkey's governing coalition agreed last night to put the execution of the Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan on hold until the European court of human rights has issued a ruling on the case.

Ocalan was sentenced to death last year and has lost his final appeal in the Turkish legal system.

After a long meeting at the prime minister's office in Ankara, the government reached a compromise on an issue that had strained relations between the coalition partners. In so doing, they have avoided a damaging dispute with the European Union, which accepted Turkey as a candidate for membership last month.

The prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, said the Ocalan case would not be put to a vote in parliament until the European court had had its say. But he stressed that Turkey would not accept an indefinite delay, and he warned Ocalan's Kurdistan Workers' Party not to try to use the government's announcement to its own advantage.

"If the rebel movement and its supporters attempt to manipulate this decision against the high interests of the state then the delay will come to an end and the process of execution will begin immediately," he said.

His tough words seem to be a sop towards his coalition partners, the Nationalist Movement party, which has been under intense pressure from its grassroots supporters to push for execution as soon as possible.

Mr Ecevit himself opposes the death penalty on principle, and he has argued that Turkey has a legal obligation to agree to the European court's request for a delay in the execution process. Mr Ecevit has now bought himself time to win other politicians around.

"Abdullah Ocalan cannot hurt us now," he said last week. "But I fear his death could damage us at home and abroad."

Many members of the political and foreign policy elite agree, but a majority in parliament has yet to be convinced. They are still listening to the voices of their constituents, many of whom want Ocalan to go to the gallows.

There was fresh evidence yesterday that feelings against Ocalan are still running high. Supporters of the death penalty gathered at the funerals in Ankara of soldiers who were killed in a clash with rebels on Sunday. They booed President Suleyman Demirel and called him a traitor for supporting a delay in the execution process.

In the end, it will still be up to the Turkish parliament to make the final decision. A vote in favour of execution could be vetoed by the president, but a second parliamentary vote would bring the process to an abrupt end.

webTitle: Work in progress: Dom Joly, media terrorist

fields.headline: Work in progress: Dom Joly, media terrorist
fields.trailText: I'm well aware that people might see Trigger Happy TV and think it looks easy, like you just take a camera out on the streets and do it. To which I can only say that I'm not claiming it's Apocalypse Now... but it certainly felt like it.
fields.body:
I'm well aware that people might see Trigger Happy TV and think it looks easy, like you just take a camera out on the streets and do it. To which I can only say that I'm not claiming it's Apocalypse Now... but it certainly felt like it.

The show's starting at the end of the week, and the ad campaign is up and running, which is pretty exciting. It's a strange feeling seeing pictures of yourself all over London, especially when all they say is "This Man Is A Liar" (I'm sure my Dad's really proud). We've worked really closely with Channel 4 for the promotional stuff, and between us we've got fly-posters, blipverts, even the occasional e-vert. I suppose in a sad way we're trying to keep it underground. Because that's what we are: sad and underground.

Talking of which, we've hidden an 80s pop star somewhere in one of the shows - there's a joke involved, I assure you - and if anyone can work out who it is they can be in our next series (which we've already started filming, so it's not just an empty promise).

The only worry with this type of show - which relies on the element of surprise and no one knowing who you actually are - is that if you get recognised, you're never sure if you can carry on. But, having said that, the top-rated show on Channel 4 gets five million people, which I don't think we'll be anywhere near, and that still leaves us another 60 million to get through. Anyway, I've already told everyone I can that I'm a liar and not to trust me through the ads - so I think it's fair enough to go ahead.

Trigger Happy TV starts on Channel Four, tomorrow night, 9.30pm.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Fierce Creatures | Shoot The Pianist | Glory
fields.body:
Fierce Creatures

(Robert Young, Fred Schepisi, 1997)

8pm, Sky Premier

Disappointing reunion of the Fish Called Wanda crowd: it didn't bode well that Schepisi was brought in to reshoot large chunks of the Young version. This has brash tycoon Kevin Kline buying a zoo and putting John Cleese (pictured) in charge, with orders to stock only fierce creatures. The keepers - including Michael Palin, Robert Lindsay, Carey Lowell - attempt to present even the cutest of their charges as lords of the jungle.More like a Carry On than its fishy forebear.

Shoot The Pianist

(François Truffaut, 1960)

10pm, UK Arena

Truffaut's second feature, shot in an austere monochrome, is a loving homage to American film noir. Smooth French singer Charles Aznavour proves a bit of a Frank Sinatra as an actor; he's excellent as the melancholy barroom piano player haunted by the past, while his brothers are stalked by gangsters. Marie Dubois is the waitress fatally drawn to him.

Glory

(Edward Zwick, 1989)

11pm, Bravo

A powerful and historically accurate account of the first black regiment to fight in the American civil war, and the stirrings of black consciousness it prompted. It's a sombre and harrowing tale that marches bravely against racism on all sides. Matthew Broderick plays the novice Union Colonel Shaw who leads the fighting 54th; Morgan Freeman and Oscar-winning Denzel Washington are among those called up. Cinematographer Freddie Francis also won an Oscar, mainly for the superb battle scenes: Gettysburg and Fort Wagner are stunning.

fields.headline: Return of the prodigal
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: David Jackson, "the Boy David", was rescued from a children's hospital in Lima, where a flesh-eating cancer had destroyed the centre of his face. Twenty years, over 100 surgical procedures and five Desmond Wilcox documentaries down the line, David is a robust young man living in Detroit, studying art and hanging out with his friends; his face, reconstructed by surgeon (and adoptive father) Ian Jackson, is skew-whiff rather than deformed. He worries these days that his nose is asymmetrical and he can't grow a moustache.
fields.body:
David Jackson, "the Boy David", was rescued from a children's hospital in Lima, where a flesh-eating cancer had destroyed the centre of his face. Twenty years, over 100 surgical procedures and five Desmond Wilcox documentaries down the line, David is a robust young man living in Detroit, studying art and hanging out with his friends; his face, reconstructed by surgeon (and adoptive father) Ian Jackson, is skew-whiff rather than deformed. He worries these days that his nose is asymmetrical and he can't grow a moustache.

The Boy David - The Return (BBC1) took him back to the scene of his infancy - to the Hospital del Niños in Lima, where he was abandoned in the corner of a ward for the best part of five years - and onward to the Amazon jungle where he was born. The trip was under taken with a good deal of trepidation: increasingly interested in discovering his roots, David nonetheless felt unready to meet his natural parents, and braced himself for an emotional upheaval. It wasn't long in coming. The reunion with Martine Schopfer, the charity worker who discovered the infant David, kidnapped him from the hospital and smuggled him to Glasgow for surgery, left both participants (and anyone watching at home) crying like babies. Thenceforth David went through his homecoming in a daze of mixed feelings. Returning to his native village, he was told that his Campa Indian parents were still alive, that all he had to do was walk into a hut and meet them. "I thought I could handle it", said a shaken David, who declined the invitation and travelled home, uncertain if he regretted his decision.

Desmond Wilcox's film-making style has calmed down a good deal over the years, and he no longer plays so heavily on the heartstrings; as a result the latest instalment was the most watchable of the series, which has been running since 1983. David's is a strange kind of fame: TV has played such an important part in who he is and how he deals with his situation, and he would certainly never have undertaken this latest voyage of discovery without the backing of a production company. All David wants now is to marry, have children and work as an artist. His therapist in Detroit suggested that "David has closure" - and maybe this is the time to leave him to an adult life without follow-ups.

There can barely be a wall in the Western world that doesn't have a fly on it these days, but that doesn't stop the channels from churning out yet more "observational" documentaries. Channel 5's Hollywood's Airport tried to show what a fun, exciting place Los Angeles International Airport can be - after all, this is where the stars touch down - but the biggest celeb they could muster was Eddie, the dog from Frasier. Eddie, admittedly, was more glamorous than a visiting President Clinton, who shook a few hands on the tarmac and zoomed off in a limousine, wisely avoiding a gaggle of second-rate reporters (and Channel 5 fly-on-the-wall documentary film-makers) who were cordoned off on the other side of the runway. "I think he saw me!" boomed LA newshound Wendy Birch, a woman with preternaturally white teeth. President May Have Seen Blonde. It's not exactly headline stuff. The trailers for next week's show ("Carmen calls in the cops") gave a sinking feeling.

The law of diminishing returns has sapped the docusoap to such an extent that Channel 4 wisely decided to come up with its own fictional spin on the format. The first episode of That Peter Kay Thing spoofed all those "aren't common people funny?" films of which we've seen so many in recent years. Stand-up star Kay played Brian Potter, owner of the Neptune Social Club, home to the finals of the Talent Trek 99 finals. He also played the doorman, a DJ, and singer Marc Park, who, with his partner Cheryl Avenue, won the day with a raunchy covers set. It's familiar territory to Steve Coogan fans, but Peter Kay does it exceptionally well. His next-week trailers, all completely bogus, nailed the banality of this type of TV with lethal accuracy, but not before we'd got to know a roster of talented hopefuls all desperate to be the next Jane "The Cruise" McDonald. "Talent night? Talent shite," spat the doorman, as Park Avenue romped to victory with a medley of Simply The Best and Horny Horny Horny.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Legacy of Division | Testbeds
fields.body:
It's tempting to spend a lot of Legacy Of Division (8.0pm, Radio 4) reading between the lines of the latest media excursion for Michael Portillo (pictured). It's the first of two programmes about the Spanish civil war, when the Tory MP's father supported the Republican government while the rest of his family backed Franco's rebellion. The victory of the extreme right certainly kept Spain out of the second world war - but then left it stultifying for three decades while the rest of Europe boomed.

One little-noticed drawback to Panama's control of its own canal is that it has become responsible for the vast modernisation programme needed to handle the rising traffic. As Alun Lewis discovers in Testbeds (9.0pm, Radio 4), the machinery operating the three giant locks dates from 1908, and the channel, built to handle something the size of the Titanic, now needs widening if it is to cope with the 30 per cent increase in daily transits.

fields.headline: Splitting the diatom
fields.standfirst: Unravelling the lacework shell of a tiny creature has proved far harder than opening the toughest oyster, reports  Michael Gross
fields.trailText: Diatoms are single-cell algae famous for the lace-like appearance of their silica shells. The need for a hard shell which still allows nutrients to enter the cell has led to a wide range of beautiful designs of sub-microscopic lacework, usually highly symmetrical.
fields.body:
Diatoms are single-cell algae famous for the lace-like appearance of their silica shells. The need for a hard shell which still allows nutrients to enter the cell has led to a wide range of beautiful designs of sub-microscopic lacework, usually highly symmetrical.

Although the basic architecture of these shells is always that of a box with a lid, the shape of the box and the design details are highly specific for each of the many thousands of diatom species that have populated lakes and oceans of our planet for millions of years. This suggests that their blueprint must be written in the genes.

To find out how the cell produces these marvellous structures all one had to do was break down the cell walls, pull out the proteins, and study them. But as Nils Kröger, Manfred Sumper, and their co-workers at the university of Regensburg in Southern Germany found out during their research into the mineralisation process of the diatom Cylindrotheca fusiformis, it wasnt quite that easy.

Proteins involved in biomineralisation are generally difficult to study. Those of the diatom cell walls required elaborate and lengthy detective work to reveal their secrets. The usual method of extracting protein - boiling the cell walls in a detergent SDS (sodium dodecyl sulphate) - yielded no result.

The researchers acted on their hunch that binding of calcium ions might have some role in the mineralised cell walls. So they tried EDTA, a chemical which can even pull the ion away from calcium binding proteins. This let them characterise the first ever protein component of diatom cell walls, a group of glycoproteins (proteins with starch-like molecular branches) which they called frustulins.

This novel group of proteins did not seem to interact with the shell's main component, silicic acid (from which various silicate and silicon dioxide minerals, such as quartz are formed).

Hoping that the most interesting proteins were still in the shell fragments even after the EDTA treatment, the researchers chose a more aggressive chemical which destroys even the chemical structure of silicate minerals: water-free hydrogen fluoride (HF).

This liberated a group of proteins which they called silaffins, as they displayed a remarkable affinity towards silicon compounds. Each of the three main components found in the extracts can make a homogenous solution of silicic acid produce small solid spheres of silica, less than one micron in diameter, within minutes.

Routine operations such as the one which cleaves off the amino acid building blocks one by one, so they can be identified and the linear sequence can be written out, failed in several places, suggesting the presence of amino acids with unknown modifications.

The researchers turned to molecular biology to find and sequence the genes responsible. They managed to find the complete gene and produce it in large amounts. The gene encoding the silaffins 1A and 1B is much longer than the actual proteins isolated from the HF extract. Apparently the original protein gets heavily edited after it is made.

The mysterious building blocks showed up as the amino acid lysine in the gene sequence. Combined evidence from advanced analytical methods along with some amount of sleuthing was required to identify the attachments, one of which turned out to be a chain molecule of a kind not seen in any other proteins before.

fields.headline: It's a bug's life
fields.standfirst: It's a bug's life:  Microbes will soon be taking a rocket ride to find out if they were the galaxy's first hitchhikers, says  Paul Davies
fields.trailText: At about the time that life began on Earth, the planet was being mercilessly pounded by giant asteroids and comets. But instead of wiping out the primitive life forms, could these meteorites have carried microscopic hitch-hikers from Mars where life had already begun?
fields.body:
At about the time that life began on Earth, the planet was being mercilessly pounded by giant asteroids and comets. But instead of wiping out the primitive life forms, could these meteorites have carried microscopic hitch-hikers from Mars where life had already begun? If so, we would all be descended from Martians.

When I proposed this scenario several years ago, it was greeted with scepticism and even ridicule. That changed in 1996 when Nasa announced evidence for fossil microbes inside a rock found in Antarctica. Tests showed that the rock had been blasted off Mars by an impacting body millions of years ago. After extensive follow-up research, Nasa's claim now looks shaky.

However, the episode did publicise the possibility of microbes travelling between planets inside ejected rocks. Now the theory is to be tested by Colin Pillinger of the Open University and Howell Edwards of the university of Bradford, who will send live bacteria aloft on a Russian Foton 12 rocket. The microbes will be incarcerated in the heat shield of a German-made space capsule, and subjected to the violence of re-entry in an attempt to mimic a ride aboard a meteorite.

Mars could be the cradle of life because, being smaller, it cooled faster than Earth. Scientists increasingly suspect that life began deep underground, where volcanic heat circulated nutrient-rich water through porous rock. Evidence comes from the study of heat-loving microbes that dwell deep in the Earth's crust; they seem to be the most primitive organisms on the tree of life. On Mars, the comfort zone for subsurface microbes would have extended deeper sooner, enabling the first organisms to shelter more effectively from the intense bombardment.

Bacteria could have thrived far beneath the Martian surface as long ago as 4.3 billion years, when Earth was still a searing hell. If microbes once inhabited the rocky Martian subsurface, it seems inevitable that many were hurled into space by large impacts. Some could have reached Earth this way, by hitching a ride in a rock.

About a dozen Martian rocks have been identified by meteorite hunters. During the early period of heavy bombardment, the traffic of material from Mars to Earth would have been prolific, raising the possibility that our planet was colonised by tiny Martians.

The initial scepticism hinged on the hazards for a space-faring organism. The shock of ejection from Mars, the intense cold and radiation of outer space, and the fierce heat of high-speed entry into the Earth's atmosphere all looked to be lethal. However, microbes can be very hardy, and on closer examination the obstacles were not so formidable. The greatest danger is the radiation, but cocooned in a chunk of rock, a micro-organism would be screened from the sun's ultra-violet emissions, and protected from all but the most energetic cosmic rays. Some terrestrial bacteria could readily survive space conditions for millions of years inside a rock a few metres across. This is certainly long enough to get here from Mars.

Jay Melosh of the university of Arizona, who independently suggested that life could journey between neighbouring planets, has estimated how many Mars rocks could have conveyed live bacteria to Earth. The number averages one every few years, but would have been much higher during the heavy bombardment period.

Melosh and I were not the first to flirt with the theory that life came to Earth in cosmic detritus. In 1871 Lord Kelvin envisaged a planetary collision scattering seed-bearing material through space. The Swedish chemist Svante Arrhenius suggested that individual bacteria might waft naked across the galaxy, propelled by the tiny pressure of starlight. Arrhenius's theory has been elaborated in recent years by Fred Hoyle and Chandra Wickramasinghe, but critics say that without the protection of enveloping material even the hardiest microbe would probably succumb to the rigours of space.

If the new experiment confirms that bacteria can survive high-speed entry into the Earth's atmosphere, it will re-open the debate about planetary protection. Nasa plans to send a probe to Mars to bring back rocks for study, provoking fears of a killer plague triggered by the release of exotic alien bugs. But if potentially microbe-laden Mars rocks have been coming here for billions of years, a few more won't matter.

Of course, the exchange of material works both ways. Rocks kicked off Earth by impacts will certainly have made their way to Mars, possibly taking live terrestrial organisms to the red planet.

We know that Mars was warm, wet and habitable when life had established itself on Earth, so maybe Mars was contaminated by Earth. So if future missions find evidence for life on Mars, it may not represent a second genesis, but simply a side-branch of familiar terrestrial life. And it could put paid to our best hope of answering the age-old question: are we alone in the universe?

Those who hope Mars might harbour a pointer to ET may have to wait until mankind can search farther afield.

Paul Davies is visiting professor in the Physics Department at Imperial College London, and author of The Fifth Miracle: The Search For The Origin Of Life.

webTitle: They called her Attila the Nun

fields.headline: They called her Attila the Nun
fields.standfirst: Heard the one about the feminist moderniser and the bishop?  Gerard Seenan  on an unholy row that has landed Britain's most senior woman priest in court
fields.trailText: Over the past 18 months the row surrounding Britain's most senior woman priest has escalated into a drama of boycotts, sackings, accusations of bribery, anonymous benefactors and court proceedings. Now it teeters on the verge of an unholy apex.
fields.body:
The hallowed walls of St Paul's cathedral, Dundee have surely never witnessed such ill-tempered vehemence. It started as a squabble - the traditional locking horns with the modern - but that was just the beginning. Over the past 18 months the row surrounding Britain's most senior woman priest has escalated into a drama of boycotts, sackings, accusations of bribery, anonymous benefactors and court proceedings. Now it teeters on the verge of an unholy apex.

The Very Rev Miriam Byrne has been suspended from her position as provost of the cathedral. The bishop of St Paul's, Neville Chamberlain, says she no longer enjoys his confidence. The members of what is left of her dwindled congregation and her vestry committee refuse to recognise the suspension. In the Scottish courts, Byrne and her vestry are pursuing the bishop for nearly £250,000. In the ecclesiastical courts, the bishop is preparing to pursue Byrne for her job.

Last Sunday, as her enemies caught a whiff of her possible demise, Byrne was forced to sit in the pews of St Paul's while another priest addressed her flock. Earlier, her vestry committee had been ordered to leave St Paul's by bishop Chamberlain, or face ejection by the police. Bishop Chamberlain then changed the locks.

After numerous attempts to oust her - and a church offer of £85,000 to go quietly - Byrne is finally facing the prospect of unemployment. An undisclosed accusation against her is being investigated by a committee of the Scottish Episcopal church. If it finds a case, she will stand trial under ecclesiastical law within months.

Byrne says she intends to mount a vigorous defence; even if found guilty she cannot be sacked unless she has committed a criminal act. But, as the pastoral battle juggernauts on, it is becoming clear that no one, least of all the church itself, is going to win.

"It was never a good idea to put a feminist moderniser in charge of an elderly and conservative congregation like St Paul's," says a senior church official. "This has put the cause of women priests back decades. You have to wonder if anyone here has heard of judgment or moderation."

Byrne, 53, came to St Paul's as it reeled from a major scandal in August 1998. Her predecessor, Michael Bunce, was forced to resign after embezzling £44,000 from a company he set up to help the unemployed. The Scottish tabloids thrilled to court evidence of the lavish lifestyle Bunce had enjoyed with his ill-gotten gains. Within weeks, however, a petition was circulated at St Paul's demanding his return.

Byrne was always going to be a controversial choice as the first woman priest in Britain to head an Anglican cathedral. She is a former Roman Catholic nun who left the convent before taking her final vows in order to marry a monk.

After 18 years, Byrne's marriage ended. She later married a university librarian and, with his encouragement, returned to the church - this time to Anglicanism.

By all accounts, Byrne's tenure at St Augustine's, her previous post in Dundee, was a success. Yet, for the traditionalists, her employment at St Paul's was unacceptable. When news of the new provost's identity - and, specifically, her sex - broke, George Greig, the cathedral's honorary chaplain for 13 years, resigned. He took around a dozen members of the congregation. It did not take long for further controversy to ignite. On her first Sunday in the pulpit, Byrne removed a 1970 prayer book from the aisles and replaced it with a version from 1982.

The conservatives were outraged. "It was the start of world war three. That's what the whole case against me was based on," Byrne told a local newspaper on the only occasion she has broken her silence on the subject.

Relations between Byrne and the conservative caucus of the congregation worsened when she sacked Anne Bissett-Johnson, the cathedral administrator.

Yet, as she was dubbed Attila the Nun and all 12 members of the original vestry called for her resignation, Bishop Chamberlain continued to offer his support. But it was obvious: something had to be done.

As increasingly venomous phrases issued from Christian mouths, Bruce Cameron, Bishop of Aberdeen and Orkney, was called in to mediate. He found no case against Byrne and, for a while, the cathedral's disputes carried on, albeit out of the public eye. Then, however, came the saga of the Aga.

A rectory house comes with the post of provost. Despite Byrne's predecessor's elaborate lifestyle, it was generally agreed that the house was dilapidated and Byrne was given clearance to upgrade it. However, she was accused of overspending by up to £19,000. Certain factions of the congregation said she had indulged her tastes in elaborate furnishings and an expensive Aga cooker. Those who detested her "happy-clappy" preaching style - particularly her decision to remove the phrase "god the father and son" from certain services - seized on the allegations. There was no peace to be found at St Paul's.

Over the months, icy relations froze further - with a particularly cold spell last July when Byrne sacked the organist. Yet Byrne had supporters, and an anonymous donation of £250,000 last May looked set to pay her stipend - and keep her in a job - for another five years.

However, in October, following a vote of no confidence in Byrne lodged by the cathedral chapter, Bishop Chamberlain said he would no longer perform diocesan functions at St Paul's. In short, he wanted nothing from Byrne but her resignation.

Byrne, though, was not prepared to go. A new vestry committee gave her full support - but Chamberlain had what he thought was an ace up his sleeve. The bishop refused to release the £250,000 donation to the vestry, and the committee was forced to reach into its own pockets to pay Byrne's wages.

Then, in December, the College of Bishops of the Episcopal Church said Byrne's ministry was no longer sustainable. Lawyers acting on behalf of Bishop Chamberlain offered her £85,000 to leave St Paul's. Byrne dismissed this as a bribe and countered with a writ from Dundee sheriff court asking for the return and payment of £224,000. On Friday, Byrne was finally forced from her post - albeit temporarily.

Byrne's supporters accuse Bishop Chamberlain of acting with high-handed disregard for their wishes. The bishop refuses to meet the vestry committee and his offer to speak to the congregation in twos and threes has been turned down.

Through statements issued via the vestry, Byrne insists the decision to suspend her has nothing to do with her theology or the way she practised her vocation. Bishop Chamberlain declines to comment - but the vestry committee demands that he does.

"Only God and Bishop Neville know for certain why things have reached this unfortunate level," says Bob Cummings, a lay vestry member who was ordered out of the cathedral by the bishop. "I fail to understand why we as Christians can get in to such a sorry state, but a bishop owes it to his flock to set an example."

As the investigation committee continues its inquiries into the allegations made against Byrne, only one thing seems to shine through the ecclesiastical cobwebs and bile. A row started by those who believe the role of provost to be an unsuitable job for a woman has made an unsuitable spectacle of a church.

webTitle: Lords revolt looms over mayor ruling

fields.headline: Lords revolt looms over mayor ruling
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Outraged opposition parties yesterday warned the government that it faces defeat over its plan to prevent London mayoral candidates from distributing a free leaflet to electors.
fields.body:
Outraged opposition parties yesterday warned the government that it faces defeat over its plan to prevent London mayoral candidates from distributing a free leaflet to electors.

The Conservatives, the Liberal Democrats and the Green party warned that they would stage a revolt in the upper house to preserve the historic right of candidates to send a leaflet to 5m voters in the capital.

It is widely suspected that the Labour machine's primary goal is to hobble an independent candidacy by Ken Livingstone if the Brent MP fails to win Labour's nomination in the coming month. The government can push the necessary order through the Commons, but may be unable to impose its will in the half-reformed Lords where it has no majority.

What has added insult to opposition injury is the government's decision to impose high £10,000 deposits on candidates while at the same time allowing them to spend up to £1m on the campaign - if they can.

Last night Mr Livingstone endorsed the opposition complaints.

"It's a disgrace," he said, warning that high spending ceilings would also force candidates to raise private funds. Glenda Jackson agrees, but Frank Dobson's campaign last night remained loyal to the official party line.

At yesterday's press conference Simon Hughes, the Lib Dem home affairs spokesman, Bernard Jenkin, the Tory spokesman on London, and the Green candidate for mayor, Darren Johnson, were outspoken about the funding formula.

"Everyone here hopes they will think again and they have every opportunity to do so. Otherwise it will look as though Labour are blatantly trying to rig the London ballot," said Mr Jenkin.

What gives their complaint muscle is that the new rules, announced by London minister, Keith Hill, need to pass both houses of parliament by way of a government order. Traditionally the Lords never voted against such orders, but now that all but 92 of the hereditary peers have left, all such bets are off. Voting will take place later this month.

At yesterday's press conference Simon Hughes, the Lib Dem home affairs spokesman, Bernard Jenkin, the Tory spokesman on London, and the Green candidate for mayor, Darren Johnson, were outspoken about the funding formula. "Everyone here hopes they will think again and they have every opportunity to do so. Otherwise it will look as though Labour are blatantly trying to rig the London ballot," said Mr Jenkin. What gives their complaint muscle is that the new rules, announced by London minister, Keith Hill, need to pass both houses of parliament by way of a government order. Traditionally the Lords never voted against such orders, but now that all but 92 of the hereditary peers have left, all such bets are off. Voting will take place later this month.

Petrol forecourts. Since 1996 1,200 of them have vanished, creating "virtual petrol deserts" , cross-party MPs led by Tory Caroline Spelman claimed. She blamed the demise of independent retailers on the big oil companies.

webTitle: Precedent set by Britain offers little comfort to world's tyrants

fields.headline: Precedent set by Britain offers little comfort to world's tyrants
fields.standfirst:
Immunity Courts will not ignore human rights crimes
Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: If tyrants past and present trembled when Augusto Pinochet was detained in Britain, some must be sighing with relief now that he seems certain to be sent home without facing trial.
fields.body:
If tyrants past and present trembled when Augusto Pinochet was detained in Britain, some must be sighing with relief now that he seems certain to be sent home without facing trial.

But few are likely to be planning carefree foreign holidays because the vital principle established by the case - that dictators cannot commit crimes and then enjoy cosy retirement with VIP treatment - will long outlast Gen Pinochet's return to Chile.

Health and British political considerations apart, it has been firmly established that former heads of state cannot shelter behind so-called "sovereign immunity" to avoid prosecution for human rights abuses.

"The precedent has been set that immunity does not attach to outrageous violations of the international constitutional order," said Marc Weller of Cambridge university.

Even the most militant anti-Pinochet campaigners, disappointed at the final twist, recognise that achievement.

"It is a shame that Pinochet may never have to stand trial, but the very fact that he was arrested and that his crimes were presented before a court has already changed the calculus of dictators all over the world," said Reed Brody of Human Rights Watch.

"We would have loved to see his victims get their day in court. But the principle that no one is above the law and that all countries have a duty to bring to justice those accused of the worst abuses has been established."

Considerable progress has been made since Pinochet was arrested. Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav president, and four senior aides have been indicted by the Hague war crimes tribunal.

Iraqi exiles, backed by the US, are seeking the trial of Saddam Hussein. Izzat Ibrahim, an Iraqi vice-president, fled Austria last autumn after hearing that he could face arrest. Tariq Aziz, the deputy prime minister, cancelled a visit to Italy for the same reason.

In the league of retired dictators, possible candidates for the Pinochet treatment include Idi Amin, the former Ugandan president, now living in Saudi Arabia, Indonesia's Suharto and "Baby Doc" Duvalier of Haiti, in exile in France.

Before Gen Pinochet, international law had made it clear that genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity could be tried in any court. But that was more a proposition, than one which governments were willing to act on.

More widely, the Pinochet case served to strengthen the willingness of democratic governments to leave human rights crimes to the courts.

"So if you were a retired dictator you would have to be pretty certain that the government of the country you wanted to visit had the judiciary under control before you went there. Safe havens are looking dodgier," said one diplomat.

webTitle: Chile and Spain greet news with relief

fields.headline: Chile and Spain greet news with relief
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: There was a common reaction yesterday to Jack Straw's decision in both the country where Augusto Pinochet was to have been tried and the nation where his crimes were allegedly committed: relief.
fields.byline: Adela Gooch  in Madrid and  Jonathan Franklin  in Santiago
fields.body:
There was a common reaction yesterday to Jack Straw's decision in both the country where Augusto Pinochet was to have been tried and the nation where his crimes were allegedly committed: relief.

The former dictator's imminent return to Santiago rescues the Spanish government from political embarrassment; in Chile the administration has hailed it as a political triumph.

In Madrid yesterday, human rights lawyers pushing for prosecution pledged to continue their efforts, but legal experts said the chances of success were small. The foreign minister, Abel Matutes, said it would not be appropriate to make any further legal representation unless new evidence emerged.

For the conservative prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, who processed the extradition but tried to distance himself from the case, the ruling comes as a huge relief, ahead of elections in March.

The investigating magistrate, Baltasar Garzon, whose extradition request against Gen Pinochet on charges of genocide and torture led to the former dictator's arrest, declared a moral victory.

"The process has been a success," said a source close to him. "Spanish justice has done what it had to do. If Pinochet returns to Chile it will be after the principle of extradition was granted. If he recovers as soon as he gets there and appears, riding crop in hand, reviewing troops, Straw will have made a fool of himself."

Families of some of those tortured or killed during the 17-year Pinochet regime protested against the ruling in Madrid's central Puerta del Sol plaza. Yet the turnout was smaller than at previous demonstrations and there was a sense that little could be done.

Nevertheless Joan Garces, a former aide to the Chilean president Salvador Allende, who died in the 1973 coup led by Gen Pinochet, urged all countries where charges are pending against Gen Pinochet to put up a united front. Belgium, Denmark and France have also issued extradition requests.

For Santiago's president, Eduardo Frei, facing a presidential election on Sunday, it is a triumph - he had repeatedly promised to bring Gen Pinochet home before the end of his term.

fields.headline: The torturer triumphs
fields.standfirst:
By letting General Pinochet off the hook Jack Straw has horrified human rights campaigners

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: So the home secretary has chosen to be hoodwinked and tells us he is minded to send Augusto Pinochet back to the scene of his crimes, unrepentant and scot-free. How the duplicitous old terrorist will be sniggering in his comfortable Surrey billet! Throughout his life he has prided himself on his foxiness. For years he successfully tried to be all things to all men.
fields.body:
So the home secretary has chosen to be hoodwinked and tells us he is minded to send Augusto Pinochet back to the scene of his crimes, unrepentant and scot-free. How the duplicitous old terrorist will be sniggering in his comfortable Surrey billet! Throughout his life he has prided himself on his foxiness. For years he successfully tried to be all things to all men.

For instance, he faithfully discharged the responsibility for the security of Fidel Castro during the Cuban leader's visit to Chile in 1971: he so completely fooled his president, Salvador Allende, that Allende trusted him totally until the very morning of the subsequent putsch.

Excommunicated from the Catholic church in 1980 for his direct responsibility for torture, he persuaded a willing Vatican to intercede with the British for his release in 1998.

Financing his secret police with the funds raised by large-scale smuggling of cocaine, as I set out in my own book*, he avoided any censure from a US government which in its weird and unwinnable "war on drugs" is happy to see its own young people jailed by the thousand for using marijuana. The man is a master of duplicity, the Ernest Saunders of the southern hemisphere.

Seldom was I happier to be a journalist and more content with a Labour government than when I wrote in this newspaper on October 15 1998 that the Chilean should be arrested as an international terrorist and murderer and found him taken into custody the very next day.

The arrest showed that a British government, which under Conservative and Labour had ignored its duty to arrest torturers under solemn conventions it had signed, was at last prepared to move against them even if it was only under the prodding of a brave Spanish judge and Interpol. Jack Straw's name went round the world and the attitude of the British judiciary was seen as exemplary in its thoroughness and impartiality.

Now, that immense world-wide store of admiration for a legal process well handled is going to drain away in a welter of secrecy and farce. The government, which had for months been telling its friends that it was keen to get rid of the hot Chilean potato, has finally given in to pressure.

Here the Conservative party has made common with its allies in the British media on the matter, as exemplified by Rupert Murdoch's exclusive deal to televise Margaret Thatcher's visit to Pinochet last year.

(One of the mysteries of the past 15 months is why not one serious and thoughtful Tory chose to criticise William Hague, Norman Lamont and Ann Widdecombe for their ill-informed partiality to a man who trained dogs to violate women. The Conservatives, who emphasise the aid Pinochet gave Britain in the Falklands war, choose to forget that the same man had Dr Sheila Cassidy, a British surgeon and daughter of an air vice-marshal, tortured to the borders of dementia in 1975.)

The home secretary has also been pressed by a conservative Spanish government, worried that Judge Garzón's case against him could harm Spain's investments in Chile, by a wobbly Chilean government and by a US establishment worried about its own skeletons in those roomy Central and South American cupboards.

Straw is trying to cover his retreat behind medical testimony gathered in the absence of any of the representatives of Judge Garzón, presented and considered in secret. The medical examination results, it seems, are not vouchsafed to those who are seeking justice. The case which, we were told for months, was being left to the courts, is suddenly resolved in a political way on the untested evidence which we must accept because a member of the government tells us to.

The saddest thing is that the British government's action is a disappointment for all those who felt that the lumbering and sleepy giant called international law was on the verge of being woken up by a British home secretary and a British judiciary.

People round the world cheered when it seemed that international lawyers might be made to do something more useful for humanity than protecting the profitable copyright for Mickey Mouse in Bangladesh, nurturing tax-evaders in Bermuda and ensuring that defenceless patients in sub-Saharan Africa had to pay over the odds for western pharmaceuticals. But it is not to be.

One must be grateful for small mercies. The Pinochet case has put the fear of God into some criminals in uniform. The Chilean government has warned many of Pinochet's active supporters not to venture abroad.

Judges in Argentina are charging their military monsters for the crime they committed during the Argentine dirty war. Generals and admirals are in the dock in Buenos Aires today, as the court considers how they seized the babies of political prisoners and sold them off for private profit. (The price was, understandably, higher for the more white-skinned ones.) But the principal criminal, the one from Chile, is getting away. Jack Straw has dropped the ball.

* Pinochet: The Politics of Torture by Hugh O'Shaughnessy, Latin-American Bureau, £8.99
