webTitle: Italian cities make Sunday a day of rest - for the car

fields.headline: Italian cities make Sunday a day of rest - for the car
fields.standfirst: A passion that causes 15,000 deaths a year is being curbed
fields.trailText: Fourteen Italian cities, including Rome, Florence and Milan, will from next month ban cars every Sunday in their boldest effort yet to banish the smog which kills thousands of people every year and destroys ancient monuments.
fields.body:
Fourteen Italian cities, including Rome, Florence and Milan, will from next month ban cars every Sunday in their boldest effort yet to banish the smog which kills thousands of people every year and destroys ancient monuments.

An army of volunteer traffic guards will seal off city centres and urge residents to walk, bike or use beefed-up public transport, according to a plan unveiled yesterday.

Environmental groups praised the initiative for daring to take on Italy's love affair with the car, which has produced one of the highest ownership ratios in the world: 32m cars for 57.5m people.

The scheme will officially start on February 6, but Milan and Como jumped the gun yesterday by allowing only cars with catalytic converters to enter the city centre between 8am and 8pm.

During a trial day without cars last September, eight cities recorded an average 35% drop in carbon monoxide levels.

More than 15,000 Italians die from smog-related illnesses each year, according to the World Health Organisation. The Europe-wide figure is 80,000. Italy is also estimated to lose 16m working days each year because of related illnesses, such as bronchitis and asthma attacks.

Edo Ronchi, the environment minister, and Leonardo Domenici, the mayor of Florence, promised that trams, buses and underground trains would run more frequently on Sundays. Residents would also be encouraged to try more ecological modes of transport, such as electric scooters or cars that run on methane gas.

The cities joined the experiment on a voluntary basis but the government has offered a £300m honeypot of aid to those that sign up, which includes Naples, Turin and Bologna.

Italy's leading environmental group, Legambiente, praised the initiative but said more should be done to reduce traffic during the week. It will go ahead with its planned one-day blockade to "liberate" 100 streets in April.

Car-free weekends have been mooted for many years but politicians hesitated for fear of angering one of the most car-addicted electorates in the world.

Formula One racing is a national passion, and many Italians are reluctant to walk even short distances. Despite the mayor's pleas for Romans to leave their cars at home on New Year's Eve, people converged on the capital's centre in a 12-mile (20km) traffic jam.

Rome has also banned tour buses from the centre to avert gridlock caused by the more than 20m pilgrims expected for the Vatican's holy year of 2000.

The last concerted attempt to ban vehicless from city centres was during the oil crisis of the early 70s when the government wanted to conserve petrol. It spawned a brief revival of horses and carts.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Pacemaker for Papon
fields.body:
Pacemaker for Papon

The convicted Nazi collaborator, Maurice Papon, seeking a presidential pardon because of ill health, is to have a heart pacemaker implanted today, according to his lawyer.

Lawyer Francis Vuillemin said Papon, 89, was taken to a hospital in the Paris suburb of Evry ahead of the surgery, and that sending him back to prison during convalescence would endanger his life and could amount to a crime of causing death through negligence.
Reuters, Paris

Opposition crackdown

In an apparent bid to stem the rising popularity of opposition figures, Malaysian police yesterday arrested one of the country's top politicians and the editor of the leading anti-government newspaper.

Karpal Singh, the deputy leader of the Democratic Action Party, was charged with sedition, as was Zulkifli Sulong, the editor of Harakah, the newspaper of the opposition Islamic fundamentalist party, which made substantial gains in the recent national election.
AP, Kuala Lumpur

Judge refuses to try Sharif

Protesting at the large number of intelligence agents in his courtroom, a Pakistani high court justice yesterday refused to hear a case of treason and hijacking against the deposed premier, Nawaz Sharif.

Instead, justice Shabir Ahmed ordered the arrest of several of the intelligence agents, while others fled the courtroom in panic, an eyewitness said.
AP, Karachi

webTitle: Three shot dead in racist bus attack in South Africa

fields.headline: Three shot dead in racist bus attack in South Africa
fields.trailText: A white man shot dead three black people and wounded four others on a rush-hour bus in Pretoria yesterday before escaping on a motorcycle. Police said that it was apparently a racially motivated attack.
fields.body:
A white man shot dead three black people and wounded four others on a rush-hour bus in Pretoria yesterday before escaping on a motorcycle. Police said that it was apparently a racially motivated attack.

The killer boarded at a bus stop with some of his victims. After the bus pulled away, he drew a pistol and murdered the driver before selecting black passengers as targets. As the vehicle careered out of control, he shot six more people, including two women who were killed.

Some of the 50 passengers jumped from the bus before it crashed into a pole. The gunman ran from the vehicle and sped away on a motorcycle parked nearby.

He was described as a middle-aged white man wearing a military-style shirt, black shorts and a wide-brimmed hat. He had a goatee beard.

The police said the killings had the hallmark of a well planned attack. The bus was on a route from Pretoria, through mostly white suburbs and on to the black township of Mamelodi.

A police spokesman, Captain Morne van Wyk, said the killer appeared to have deliberately selected black targets.

The manager of the transport company, Niel Groenewald, said it was the first time bus passengers had been the target of such an attack. "In the past there have been drive-by shootings of [minibus] taxis, but never anything on buses," he said.

Mbhazima Shilowa, the premier of Gauteng province which includes Pretoria, said he was shocked anddisgusted by the killings. "Such can only be an act of a brute that may only be motivated by hatred," he said.

The police commissioner, Jackie Selebi, visited the scene and pledged that the killer would be caught. "There is absolutely no way that terrorist activities of this kind are going to endure," he said.

Yesterday's killings were the largest racially motivated attack since a black army officer shot dead eight white colleagues at a Bloemfontein military base in September.

A bomb exploded outside a magistrate's court in Wynberg, in the Cape, yesterday where two members of the Islamic vigilante group People Against Gangsterism and Drugs were due to appear in connection with bomb blasts. The explosive, planted on a motorcycle, injured three people.

Police said the casualties would have been far higher if the bomb had gone off a few minutes later, when the court had been due to close. Court staff, lawyers and spectators would have emerged to face the full force of the blast.

webTitle: Halfway finds itself stuck in the middle of name-change row

fields.headline: Halfway finds itself stuck in the middle of name-change row
fields.trailText: There is no shortage of towns with weird names in the US - Boring, Needy and Truth or Consequences are all registered municipal monikers. But next Tuesday, the good people of Halfway, Oregon, will decide whether their town should become the first to be named after an internet company.
fields.body:
There is no shortage of towns with weird names in the US - Boring, Needy and Truth or Consequences are all registered municipal monikers. But next Tuesday, the good people of Halfway, Oregon, will decide whether their town should become the first to be named after an internet company.

The 345 inhabitants of the little town below the Wallowa Mountains on the Idaho state border will be voting on whether the name of their home should be changed from Halfway to Half.com - and nothing has caused this much of a stir in the town for years.

The idea for the name change came from a Philadelphia-based internet company, Half.com, which was looking for a publicity gimmick.

"We're still negotiating the final details," said Kristin Keyes, director of corporate communications at Half.com yesterday. "But what we're talking about is building a website for them, possibly seed money for new enterprises and other things."

The town's mayor, Dick Crow, said that at the last council meeting, 95 residents wanted to go ahead with the change, with three against. "I hope it creates jobs," he said.

But not everyone in Halfway is convinced that the change will be a good thing.

Opponents say that the move gives the impression that the town is on its last legs and will sell its soul for a mess of websites.

"To justify the plan, people have been saying we're a dying town, which is not the case," says David Baker, the bookkeeper at the local Hells Canyon Journal. Mr Baker says that ranching, forest services, the education board and nearby power dams all still offer employment opportunities. There are also a number of retired people who have moved to the town partly because it was quiet and secluded, he said.

In Halfway, the last council meeting attracted record numbers and a full house looks likely for next week when locals will brave four-foot high snow drifts to decide whether to become the millennium's first dot.com town.

fields.headline: Iran's banned cleric breaks silence
fields.standfirst:
In his first interview, according to his aides, Ayatollah Montazeri tells of his vision for the future

More about Iran
fields.trailText: The man behind profound change in Iran is the invisible resident of this holy Shi'ite Muslim city.
fields.body:
The man behind profound change in Iran is the invisible resident of this holy Shi'ite Muslim city.

He has been under house arrest for more than two years, exiled to his modest home on Riverbank Street. Few dare to mention his name in public. Newspapers which print his ideas are closed or taken to court. Fellow clerics who spread his opinions in public are imprisoned. And thousands of his disciples, the seminarians who read his banned books, do so clandestinely.

Now, Ayatollah Ali Hossein Montazeri is tired of being silenced. In his first interview ever, according to his aides, he told the Guardian of his vision for a new Iran.

"I have spent a lifetime fighting for the independence and honour of this country, defending the rights and freedoms of the people. I consider telling the truth my religious duty," he said in the interview.

The truth for Ayatollah Montazeri, the most powerful cleric in post-revolutionary Iran after the late Ayatollah Khomeini, is terrifying for Iran's conservative clerical establishment. He interprets the Iranian constitution as giving the people the right to elect all leaders in the government, including the supreme clerical leader, now appointed by a body of theologians.

"Although some of the clerics are of the opinion that the supreme leader derives his authority from divine appointment, such opinions are subject to dispute.

"From the Koran, the book of God, one can deduce that government is a public affair," he said in the 12-page interview, which was faxed to the Guardian from his home.

For many conservatives who believe in the current system whereby clerics have the power to screen candidates who run in elections, Ayatollah Montazeri's ideas threaten their political survival. His criticism of Iran's maltreatment of political prisoners forced him out of favour in 1989, after Ayatollah Khomeini had designated him as his successor.

In 1987, Ayatollah Khomeini was quoted as saying of Montazeri: "He is the fruit of my life. My essence is in him, not once or twice but several times."

Since his house arrest in November 1997, Ayatollah Montazeri lives under constant scrutiny by two guards posted in a separate house next to his own. Even his children are forbidden to venture out without permission from the guards. During the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, which ended last weekend, seminarians were allowed to visit his family, but the ayatollah was forced to remain secluded behind closed doors.

"The day I went to Montazeri's house, his son Ahmad had to get the guards' permission to go to the store to buy some yogurt," said one seminarian and admirer.

The restrictive conditions of his arrest have eliminated him physically from the scene. The theological school he ran was closed; and the state froze his assets, virtually impoverishing the elderly cleric, born in 1922.

But his shadowy existence has made him a figure larger than life in Iran.

"In the seminaries, it is forbidden to study Montazeri's writings. One student caught reading his books was sentenced to seven years in prison. But many smuggle in his writings, which are an inspiration to us all," said one seminarian.

Ayatollah Montazeri was placed under house arrest for criticising the powers granted to Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. He also said Ayatollah Khameini was unfit to make religious rulings.

In the Guardian interview, he reiterated his opinions. "The leader is equal to any other person before the law. He can never be above the law, and he cannot interfere in all affairs, particularly the affairs that fall outside his area of expertise, such as economics and international relations."

But in today's Iran, Ayatollah Khamenei regularly speaks out on relations with the west, particularly the United States. He advocates a general policy of isolationism.

Ayatollah Montazeri also criticised the clerical establishment for refusing to give more power to the president when a revision of the Iranian constitution was made in 1989, shortly after Ayatollah Khomeini's death. Indeed, the limitations on President Mohammad Khatami, who was elected in a landslide in 1997, have been a major obstacle to implementing his reform programme.

"How can the president implement the constitution when the military and security forces are not under his command? Whereas all social expectations are directed at the president, and he has to respond to almost everybody, all institutions of power are under the command of the supreme leader, a leader that according to some, is above the law and therefore cannot be held accountable."

When parliament amended the election law after Ayatollah Khomeini's death, giving the Guardian Council, a body of clerics, the right to supervise elections, Ayatollah Montazeri said this violated the constitution.

The Guardian Council this week announced that it had eliminated key pro-reform candidates who registered to run in parliamentary polls scheduled for February 18.

"The law [constitution] is explicit on the fact that the supervisory role of the Guardian Council pertains to 'supervision over the elections' and not 'supervision over the candidates'," Ayatollah Montazeri said.

Ayatollah Montazeri is sad, not about his arrest, but at the limitations of freedom of expression in Iran. "I am very sorry to see that in the present circumstances there is no tolerance in the Islamic society for hearing anything other than what is coming out of the ruling circles, a condition in which the children of the revolution are being sent to jail."

And he apologised for having to communicate his ideas by fax and not in person.

webTitle: East German drug doctor escapes jail

fields.headline: East German drug doctor escapes jail
fields.trailText: The former doctor of East Germany's swimming team was yesterday found guilty of causing bodily harm to those in his care and given the heaviest sentence so far of a string of trials for drug misuse under the communist regime.
fields.body:
The former doctor of East Germany's swimming team was yesterday found guilty of causing bodily harm to those in his care and given the heaviest sentence so far of a string of trials for drug misuse under the communist regime.

But although Lothar Kipke, 72, was fined 7,500 marks (£2,500) by the Berlin court, he will almost certainly not have to go to jail. While the judges agreed he should be given the 15-month sentence demanded by the prosecution, they decided it should be suspended.

A former team member said afterwards that she was disappointed with the outcome, because the court had refused to admit medical evidence that performance-enhancing drugs taken by Martina Gottschalt, 34, and other swimmers had led to deformities in their children.

"How can one be happy with that?" asked Ms Gottschalt, whose son, now aged 15, was born with a club foot. The former 100m and 200m champion was one of five women who were party to the case. They and others testified to being unaware at the time that they were taking the potentially dangerous steroids.

Their lawyer, Michael Lehner, lashed Kipke in his concluding address, describing him as a "non-doctor" and accusing him of perverting the ethics of his chosen profession. "How come a doctor was given charge of young girls to be used as guinea pigs?", he asked. It was a question that had yet to be thrashed out in the German courts.

Several cases have been brought to trial since March 1998, but so far most have been against low- and middle-ranking figures in the mighty sporting hierarchy of the former German Democratic Republic.

The most senior official to be tried has been Horst Röder, the former vice-president of the sports and gymnastics federation, who was given a one-year suspended sentence last October. But the political responsibility for the systematic administration of drugs that damaged the health of thousands of sportsmen and women has yet to be settled in the courts.

Kipke was found guilty on 54 counts of administering steroids. In sentencing him, the judge, Peter Faust, said Kipke had played a key role in the administration of drugs to talented young swimmers and that he had known of their harmful side-effects.

The doctor had earlier admitted to the charges, but he claimed that in the 1970s, when he began giving out the drugs, only their minor side-effects were known.

However, the policy of using steroids to give East Germans an unfair edge in competition persisted well into the 1980s, though the method of administering them changed. Injections were replaced with a tablet containing the steroid Turinabol, the court heard.

The prosecution gave evidence to the court that young women in the national team were put on the birth control pill so that they did not become pregnant, apparently because of fears that the steroids could result in deformities.

The court yesterday turned down a request from Mr Lehner to admit evidence about deformities in the children of two of the five women he represented.

The judges ruled that the evidence of a link with the drugs taken by the two swimmers was inconclusive.

webTitle: Where have all the woolly liberals gone?

fields.headline: Where have all the woolly liberals gone?
fields.standfirst: Jack Straw says opponents of his judicial policies are whingeing 'Hampstead liberals'. But does this aged political stereotype still mean anything?  Jon Snow, long-time north London resident, laments the demise of a singular species.
fields.trailText: Jack Straw says opponents of his judicial policies are whingeing 'Hampstead liberals'. But does this aged political stereotype still mean anything?  Jon Snow, long-time north London resident, laments the demise of a singular species.
fields.body:
It is 8.45am, the cram of four-wheel drive, bull-barred Jeeps, Mercs and Range Rovers sit or crawl carrying cargoes of precious little straw-hatted children to private primary schools. Older, stripe-jacketed boys and blue-uniformed girls crowd the pavements making for the equally private secondary schools. Welcome to Hampstead at the start of any weekday.

Weekends find expensively fashioned men and women drifting from Nicole Farhi to Häagen Dazs. Politics are barely in evidence. The only issues aired in the delis and parlours around Hampstead high street are the parking restrictions and the effect of internet stocks on financial markets.

It's a far cry from the nest of "woolly liberals" Jack Straw lambasts for criticising his judicial reforms. The "Hampstead liberal" is not quite extinct. A few of their book-lined homes are still sticking it out against the bonus-sporting bankers that deluge Benham & Reeves or John D Wood with requests for property "in excess of six figures please". Wily estate agents have cranked many of the region's wrecks up into the seven-figure bracket just to meet demand. But beyond pretty brick walls, wisteria-clad doorways, a Weldon, Bragg, Foot, Jay or O'Toole is still to be found. Their lovely beleaguered literary hollows are holding out in the new maze of one-way systems that Camden council has introduced to try to frustrate the school-going rat run.

Time was when the five-bedroomed houses of Hampstead were low-rental warrens of liberal activists and intellectuals - when a little writing went a long way. In the 60s, they even elected one of their own to parliament: Ben Whittaker, perhaps one of the most truly representative MPs of his time - humane, liberal, and an adornment at any Hampstead party.

But then the dark days of Thatcher dawned and nowhere felt the cold wind of greed and "me-firstness" more acutely than Willow Road, Flask Walk and the flats on the edge of the heath. A brief buffer state of incoming TV producers held out for a few years in the 70s and early 80s, but by the 90s the Barings boys, the HSBC high flyers and the Hong Kong "fly aways" came calling in such droves that even the liberals sold up in favour of a pad in Clerkenwell and the farm in Gloucestershire. Those few who do remain forever Hampstead and liberal are anyway quite well disposed towards New Labour. They have others to blame for the lowering of the intellectual tone that has swept the neighbourhood they love.

It would be difficult for huntsman Straw and his hounds to find his quarry in Hampstead now. With luck they might find a handful of very rich thirtysomething lawyers who have moved in and who have not allowed daddy's money to interfere with their liberal leanings - but they don't cause Jack much lost sleep.

No, the people he wants to pursue are marshalling in Tufnell Park, in Kentish Town and on the lower end of Belsize Park, and even then not in numbers you would notice. The real numbers are out in Hackney, in Brighton, on the better edges of Manchester, Leeds and Newcastle. These are today's equivalent of Hampstead liberals, people who live with the packed surgery, the just-about-viable state school, people who find New Labour's expenditure on the alleviation of the poverty they encounter daily inadequate.

These are the thinking liberals who voted Blair for change, who loathe the thought of tax cuts in April in the face of what they live across the road from. But even they are not organised: they tut tut, and they will vote Blair again, for they too are hav ing a pretty good time and present no threat to Straw.

In truth, one suspects the home secretary has had to erect a breed - a coalition of advocates for jury trial, better asylum-seeking circumstances, greater freedom of information. For beyond the good times that Gordon Brown's economy is spawning lies a ministerial unease about the lack of opposition. If it isn't there, it has to be invented. Offered the chance to break ranks with New Labour, even the Liberal Democrats have eschewed doing so, even over the future of the electoral system, for which they have fought so long. The Tories are too busy with each other. That leaves some other uneasy mass that exists in and out of New Labour - not in enough to be reliable, not out enough to be easily identified. Hence Straw's desperate search for the Hampstead liberals.

Alas, as a political force, they are no more. Dispersed as they have become across the land, could they still prove to be the dangerous beating conscience that explodes into life at a most awkward moment? Unless there is an unexpected down-turn in the economy, it is hard to see it happening. The good times just may be proving too good.

Of course, a serious collapse of internet stocks might do the trick: trash the property prices in Hampstead, force bankers to let rooms to aspiring liberal students. Is that what Straw fears? A new generation of Hampstead warrens sprouting cells of young intellectual firebrands? Too fanciful. The Hampstead liberal is too busy for any of this, too busy with the new economy, new wines and new trousers. Even a new mayor has ceased to be of interest. Amid the death of ideology there is no new bandwagon to fix their passions to. A rant at the Northern Line, or the health service and it's off to Pizza Express (appropriately housed in an old annexe of the North London Polytechnic) for supper. What a day. School tomorrow.

webTitle: Why I spared the Leaning Tower of Pisa

fields.headline: Why I spared the Leaning Tower of Pisa
fields.standfirst: As restoration work to stop Pisa's famous tower from toppling over nears completion, an ex-infantryman has revealed for the first time how he saved it from US artillery during the second world war.  Rory Carroll reports.
fields.trailText: They started the final phase of shoring up the Leaning Tower of Pisa on Tuesday morning, around the same time that Leon Weckstein, 6,000 miles away in California, ate one last piece of birthday cake and turned in for the night.
fields.body:
They started the final phase of shoring up the Leaning Tower of Pisa on Tuesday morning, around the same time that Leon Weckstein, 6,000 miles away in California, ate one last piece of birthday cake and turned in for the night.

Workmen clamped giant steel braces around the monument and adjusted the weights hanging from it. Gravity and soggy footings were making the tilt too sharp and threatening to collapse 150,000 tonnes of Renaissance stone on top of tourists. Disasters apart, in a few months Italy will declare one of the wonders of the world saved and open for business.

What the glitterati who assemble to celebrate will not realise is that if it was not for a terrified 23-year-old American soldier, it would not exist today at all.

Towards the end of the second world war, Weckstein was one of the GIs struggling through the marshy ground that surrounds Pisa, advancing on the stubborn Germans who still occupied the Tuscan town. Had he uttered just six short words -"This is Able George One. Fire" seconds later an infantry division with batteries of 155mm cannons and a destroyer moored offshore would have blasted the tower to dust. But two things conspired to stop him - his fear and the tower's beauty.

More than half a century after he lowered his telescope on that sweaty afternoon, Weckstein, now 79, has decided to tell his extraordinary story for the first time, in a book. Joseph Heller's Catch-22 it is not. Madness and death certainly play their part, but what ultimately triumphs, against all the odds, is the appreciation of beauty.

The omens were not good that night in July 1944 when a booming voice called out for Sergeant Weckstein across an olive grove criss-crossed by slit trenches full of exhausted GIs.

Every bend of road, every farmhouse and every escarpment seemed to be booby-trapped or occupied by groups of obstinate German defenders. Their orders were to delay the allies at all costs. Field Marshal Kesselring had introduced his new weapon, the Nebelwerfer: a multi-barrelled rocket launcher that hurled 20 or more missiles in rapid succession from an adapted truck. Screaming Mim, the Americans called it. The final two-and-a-half miles into Pisa had become a killing zone. As the number of American dead and wounded mounted in the mud the advance was in danger of stalling.

What their top brass could not figure out was how the Germans could be so accurate in such flat, coastal terrain. They had to have a vantage point but where was it? Intelligence units surveying the terrain ruled out every spot except one - a monument 185ft high the infantry "grunts" called the tiltin' Hilton.

So it was that Weckstein was roused from sleep and delivered to Colonel Woods, who gave him the most dangerous mission of his war: to take a radio man and get as close to the tower to find out if the Germans were inside.

Like many GIs, Beckstein, a young man from the suburbs of Los Angeles, had never heard of the leaning tower of Pisa. The generals had, but if enemy activity was detected they were not going to sacrifice men for a chunk of masonry, no matter how old. Only two months earlier allied bombs had obliterated the monastery at Monte Cassino which the Germans had made a fortress.

"If you see anything that looks at all suspicious, don't wait. Call down fire," ordered Woods. Waiting for the signal were inland gun batteries and the destroyer offshore.

This week, the laconic Californian voice at the end of the phone quickened at the memory: "There wasn't a single doubt in my mind that I really was about to do the deed, to direct sallies of doomsday fusillades."

What Woods and the rest of the 91st Infantry Division's top brass did not know was that they were entrusting one of the war's most fateful observation missions to a man rejected by the navy for being short-sighted. "In 1942 the navy had told me to go away and eat carrots for six months," says Weckstein. "Then the infantry took me - but they take anyone."

Excited and terrified, the young infrantryman ate a K-ration fruit bar, slurped strong, black coffee, and picked up his radio man, a taciturn Ohio guitar-player called Charles King. They smeared mud on their faces and headed out into the hot, muggy dawn.

"Our bodies bent low to the ground, we crouched and stumbled slowly along the perilous way towards our objective for what seemed like an eternity. King had begun to sweat conspicuously. He had that clumsy radio to lug around, and I felt sorry for him."

After an hour they reached an olive grove threequarters of a mile from their target. Trying to ignore his sweat, itching and fleas, Weckstein raised the telescope he had found in an abandoned house months before.

"I focused first on the highest point, the broad circular campanile of the tower. I could easily make out the shadowy silhouette of the old bells, quiet now, but nothing moved. I took my time training the 'scope ever so slowly up, down, and across each elaborately ornamented balustrade, attempting to discern anything that might be hidden within those black recesses and arches."

The grace and beauty hynoptised the former supplies clerk. He momentarily forgot the friends killed by shells almost certainly directed from the monument. He snapped out of it and again scanned, "hoping against hope for even the slightest sign of a possible target". Waves of heat suddenly turned the tower into a vibrating mass, "as if I were attempting to look through a bowl full of wiggling Jello".

Anger and fear swelled. "Finish the damn job! I yearned to blow it to smithereens, but as yet I had seen nothing move. Not a damn thing moved." He tried to will himself to do it. He imagined himself to be an evil, Nazi solider hiding in the sixth level, laughing at his victims. "The hell with orders, I thought. I'll just go ahead and fire."

He turned to the radio man and the words were on his lips but they would not come. Seconds turned to minutes and still he could not do it. The hypnotic spell had not been broken after all. The tower, the neighbouring cathedral and baptistry, were too beautiful.

Weckstein was still transfixed when German shells burst overhead. It was too late now to do anything except run. The two men raced back to their lines under heavy fire. The generals decided to spare the tower. To this day it has never been established whether the Germans were inside. Weckstein turns wistful. "You know something? I've had 50 years to think about it, and I'm pretty sure they were."

fields.headline: We are amused by Victoria
fields.standfirst: The critic panned Posh Spice's debut TV show. They missed the point entirely, says  Sam Wollaston
fields.trailText: She is "a woman who has all the self awareness of Ready Brek" said the witty critic in the Times. And "the mental alertness of a teabag." The Independent was equally scathing: "The hope that the programme might have some novel, ironic take on celebrity proved vain." The Telegraph was a little kinder, in spite of the show's "dumbness" and "sycophancy." This newspaper thought that neither she "nor her celebrity chums could think of a single interesting thing to tell the viewer."
fields.body:
She is "a woman who has all the self awareness of Ready Brek" said the witty critic in the Times. And "the mental alertness of a teabag." The Independent was equally scathing: "The hope that the programme might have some novel, ironic take on celebrity proved vain." The Telegraph was a little kinder, in spite of the show's "dumbness" and "sycophancy." This newspaper thought that neither she "nor her celebrity chums could think of a single interesting thing to tell the viewer."

She, of course, is Victoria Adams and these were reviews of her documentary, Victoria's Secrets: Mrs Beckham's Celebrity Odyssey, on Channel 4 on Tuesday.

So the clever critics didn't like Victoria or her show. But then that's not really surprising; she's an easy target and they went for her. It was a different story in the office the morning after; everyone was saying how brilliant it was. Wasn't Posh great? Cute, clever, bitchy, real, smart . . . And so much better than Geri in the documentary she did - none of that self-pitying nonsense.

And they are right - the people in the office, not the critics. Their problem is that they don't get it. She's a rubbish interviewer they say. And they're right; she admits it herself. She asks silly questions, doesn't follow them up, interrupts and says yes all the time. Right about that too. But to judge her and her show on her interviewing skills is a bit like saying Ali G doesn't make good television because he never asks sensible questions.

Being a rubbish interviewer can be a good thing, and be much more revealing. In one scene Posh and Elton John had a bit of a laugh over an experience that they share and few of us can imagine: what it's like to have 50,000 football supporters singing that they take it up the bum. Now that's not something you get on your average Parkinson.

Speaking of Parky, the bit where she interviewed him to get a few tips - don't sit behind a desk, build up a rapport, that sort of thing - was the most boring part of the show. Television has moved on I'm afraid Parky, and interviews don't necessarily mean asking the right questions. So last century.

So what about the woman herself? The Times says the more we learn about our heroes, the less we like them. "We can admire Saul Bellow and Salinger because we know little about their private lives," its critic says, cleverly. Well I'm sorry mister; as well as it being a bit dumb to compare a Spice Girl to a couple of literary giants, you're also wrong.

I wasn't sure about Posh before Tuesday night. The Spice Girls aren't my favourite band and Posh wasn't even my favourite Spice Girl - she looked a bit mean and moody, and what's with that permanent snarl? But she came out like . . . well, like the office straw poll revealed: cute, clever, bitchy, real.

Who else would tell Ruby Wax she was wearing a crap top (not Parky I suspect), and say that Naomi Campbell was a cow (ditto). I liked it when she told Vinnie Jones that her husband thought he was a big poof. And I liked the lack of false modesty - that she was pleased when Mirror editor Piers Morgan admitted that she and David had overtaken the royals in terms of selling papers, and that she was pleased when they started calling her house Beckingham Palace. And when Elton asked her if she liked Geri's solo music she didn't give it the "I think it's great and we're still really good friends" answer you'd expect. She kept her mouth shut. And no, they hadn't been in touch since Geri split.

At the end of Posh's show she interviewed her husband, an episode the Independent said was "a prolonged, three-way cringe - for her, for him, for us." True, it probably was the worst interview of the lot - they mostly just giggled bashfully at each other, sometimes managing to say something about clothes - but it was also the most revealing. This is what the most famous couple in the country are really like. And that's what we want to know, isn't it?

fields.headline: No: 1561 Blondes
fields.trailText: Appearance: Pale-haired, you cretin. Are you blonde or something?
fields.body:
Appearance: Pale-haired, you cretin. Are you blonde or something?

Age: Another stupid question - you must be blonde. In fact, today's most talked-about blonde is 50.

Chris Tarrant? No, Sigourney Weaver.

Don't be silly. Everyone knows Sigourney is bald. I think you'll find that was for her role in Alien 3. For her part in the sci-fi spoof Galaxy Quest, Weaver sports, along with a silicone-filled bra, a blonde wig.

Why? Perhaps the clothes were too big for her and her head was cold. Far be it from me to read too much into it, but generally in Hollywood, blonde + cleavage = love interest. In the film, Weaver plays Gwen DeMarco, star of a Star Trek-style TV series which is given a new lease of life when it turns out to have a cult following among the population of Klatu Nebula, who show up at a fans' convention in the US.

Cult spooky series? I get it! They had to make her blonde because if she had red hair the audience would think it was the X-Files! Something like that. But Weaver has ruffled the blonde beehive of Ivana Trump by telling US interviewers: "Once I put that wig on I didn't say an intelligent thing for four months. My voice went up. I walked differently. I'd ask incredibly stupid questions." The ever publicity-shy Trump leapt to the defence of blondes, offering the startling insight that "it's about your brain function, not your hair colour".

I'm not surprised Sigourney doesn't want to be blonde. It's not fashionable. Madonna, Gwyneth Paltrow and Cameron Diaz have gone brunette. True, although Diaz's hair colour change was necessitated by her role as the frumpy, tracksuit-wearing wife of John Cusack in the soon-to-be-released Being John Malkovich. The concept of a frumpy blonde was clearly too tricky for the casting directors to grasp. Anyway, despite her complaints, Sigourney seems quite attached to her new image - she wore the blonde wig to a recent 20th anniversary screening of Alien.

Do say: "See? Blondes really do have more fun."

Don't say: "How do you make a blonde laugh on Saturday? Tell her a joke on Wednesday."

fields.headline: Suits you, baby
fields.standfirst: Would you spend as much on a pushchair as on a second-hand car?  Luisa Dillner  reports on the new breed of parents who accessorise their child to within an inch of its life
fields.trailText: For celebrities a baby is no longer the ultimate fashion statement. It's the baby's accessories that really count. Liam Gallagher recently paraded his offspring in a papoose made by Bill Amberg, a vision of leather and sheepskin with a matching ludicrous price tag of £210. On Tuesday actress Emma Thompson spent two hours wheeling her five-week-old daughter through Regent's Park in a de rigueur three-wheel thick-tyred buggy. Forget cellular blankets, little Gaia Romilly (and why do they all have ridiculous names?) was snug in an insulated sleeping bag.
fields.body:
For celebrities a baby is no longer the ultimate fashion statement. It's the baby's accessories that really count. Liam Gallagher recently paraded his offspring in a papoose made by Bill Amberg, a vision of leather and sheepskin with a matching ludicrous price tag of £210. On Tuesday actress Emma Thompson spent two hours wheeling her five-week-old daughter through Regent's Park in a de rigueur three-wheel thick-tyred buggy. Forget cellular blankets, little Gaia Romilly (and why do they all have ridiculous names?) was snug in an insulated sleeping bag.

So how does this make the rest of us feel, wheeling our babies round in battered Maclaren pushchairs stained with the juices of previous toddlers, grateful for hand-me-downs from our friends' babies and not too posh to buy two babygros for £12 from Woolworths. Just as the jeweller looks at a man when he buys his girlfriend an engagement ring, with an obvious, "So this is how much you love her sir?" the buggy you buy, the cot you choose and how you decorate the nursery, measure parental love by the damage they do to your credit card.

I recently bought curtains for our baby's room in a sale. They weren't fantastic but they were cheap. Does this make me a bad mother? The market for baby equipment is vast and growing, as the age and therefore income of first-time mothers rises each year. At the Conran Shop, a three-wheel buggy made by Land-Rover, sells for £400. The shop assistant is keen to stress that this includes a rain cover and canopy. "What's so good about it?" I ask. "Well it's designed by the Land-Rover company, it has wheels like car tyre wheels. It is light and you can jog with it. It is suitable for all terrains." All terrains presumably being Kensington and Hampstead.

I admit that I would like such a buggy but £400 is more than I paid five years ago for a perfectly adequate car.

The complexity of buggy-buying has also increased since I had my first child 11 years ago and pushchairs came in flowery or striped fabric. These days you need an engineering degree to work out the pros and cons of your baby buggy being made of anodized aluminium, having bike-style caliper handbrakes with lock button for parking and whether to have 12-, 16-, or 20in wheels (all potential features of the new Babby Jogger 11 from the US). In fact so sophisticated have even papooses become that we we couldn't work out how to use a Baby Bjorn baby carrier that a friend gave us.

Along with the increased opportunity to buy expensive knick-knacks for your baby is the chance to compete with other parents. "There is massive competition between mothers," says Diane Kenwood, features editor of the magazine Having a Baby. "It starts from 'my labour was longer or shorter than yours' and continues to 'My child is sitting or standing earlier than yours'. I defy any mother to say she doesn't look at what other babies have and think, 'Why did she choose that buggy or those orange check bedclothes?' These accessories feed on the competitive instincts of mothers."

Most of the messages that parents get about what to buy their babies, is subliminal, says Kenwood. "I don't think the marketing is any more in your face, there is surreptitious pressure from the cult of the celebrity pregnancy. In the past you disappeared when you were pregnant, now being pregnant and a mother is the in thing. To be as gorgeous as a celebrity parent you need the same accessories. You can now accessorise your baby to within an inch of its life."

You can also buy an assortment of vital baby equipment. Now available is a Babysphere Apollo, a pushchair that has an air filter to protect babies from pollution. Mothercare will soon be selling a bottle that can sterilise itself and has new handles on some of its pushchairs that prevent wrist injury. Expensive, of course, doesn't always mean better. But that won't stop most parents. The Conran Shop for instance, will do you a tasteful highchair in natural beech for £159, and Mothercare list a hand-carved solid pine cot for around £300 and a car seat for £99. In Harrods some of the baby furniture is so cute it makes you cry (maybe only if you're pregnant) - as do the prices.

The only faint encouragement for those of us with slim wallets is watching those parents who buy DKNY and Christian Dior see the clothes go out of fashion before their kids have grown out of them.

In the past you disappeared when you were pregnant, now being pregnant and a mother is the in thing. To be as gorgeous as a celebrity parent you need the same accessories. You can now accessorise your baby to within an inch of its life." You can also buy an assortment of vital baby equipment. Now available is a Babysphere Apollo, a pushchair that has an air filter to protect babies from pollution. Mothercare will soon be selling a bottle that can sterilise itself and has new handles on some of its pushchairs that prevent wrist injury. Expensive, of course, doesn't always mean better. But that won't stop most parents. The Conran Shop for instance, will do you a tasteful highchair in natural beech for £159, and Mothercare list a hand-carved solid pine cot for around £300 and a car seat for £99. In Harrods some of the baby furniture is so cute it makes you cry (maybe only if you're pregnant) - as do the prices. The only faint encouragement for those of us with slim wallets is watching those parents who buy DKNY and Christian Dior see the clothes go out of fashion before their kids have grown out of them.

webTitle: End tariffs for poor nations, Byers urges EU

fields.headline: End tariffs for poor nations, Byers urges EU
fields.standfirst:
Debt relief: special report
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers will today today urge the European Union to tear down tariff barriers on goods from the world's 48 poorest countries so they can export their way out of poverty.
fields.body:
Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers will today today urge the European Union to tear down tariff barriers on goods from the world's 48 poorest countries so they can export their way out of poverty.

In a meeting this evening with his EU counterpart, Pascal Lamy, Mr Byers will propose the measure as a way of rebuilding trust between the developing world and the west, damaged by the collapse of the World Trade Organisation's attempts to launch a new round of global trade talks in Seattle last month. "As part of the post-Seattle agenda the EU must be prepared to offer increased market access to the goods from least developed countries," Mr Byers said, in an interview with the Guardian.

"We need to have a bonfire of tariffs as far as these countries are concerned."

Mr Byers believes the EU must offer a lead in two areas - reform of the WTO, whose decision-making process was severely criticised by delegates in Seattle, particularly from the developing countries - and tariff reform for the poorest countries.

EU negotiators in Seattle were pushing for all western countries to provide tariff-free access for the least developed countries. However, with the WTO paralysed since the failure of the talks, Mr Byers believes the EU should now move unilaterally.

Aid groups welcomed Mr Byers' pledge but warned that as well as cutting tariffs, Europe must tackle the damage wrought on agriculture in the third world by its subsidy bloated farming sector.

EU reluctance to reform agricultural policy contributed to the collapse of the Seattle talks. "If international trade rules are to benefit the poor this will be an important first step, but the real challenge for the EU will be to remove export subsidies that lead to the dumping of surpluses on poor countries," said Justin Forsyth, Oxfam's head of policy.

Earlier this week Mr Byers met with Mike Moore, the head of the WTO, to discuss options for the overhaul of the Geneva-based body. Among the proposals which have been floated is the notion of an "eminent persons group" of politicians to examine how to make the WTO more democratic.

webTitle: Autonomy and Intel in global pact

fields.headline: Autonomy and Intel in global pact
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Intel
Autonomy
fields.trailText: Autonomy, the Cambridge-based intelligent software company, has signed a worldwide partnership agreement with Intel, the world's largest chip manufacturer, to revolutionise business systems on the internet.
fields.body:
Autonomy, the Cambridge-based intelligent software company, has signed a worldwide partnership agreement with Intel, the world's largest chip manufacturer, to revolutionise business systems on the internet.

The British company will provide technology that automatically recognises the unstructured information contained in operations such as email and order processing - and directs them to the relevant department. The technology will be compatible with the new 64-bit Itanium processor Intel plans to launch in the summer.

The two companies claim the partnership will allow large-scale corporations to fully automate ordering systems and information processing leading to massive cost savings and increasing productivity.

The addition of such a high-profile name as Intel's to Autonomy's roster of partners is a major fillip for the company, which was founded by Mike Lynch in 1996.

It listed on Easdaq, the technology-laden European bourse, in July 1998 and was valued at more than £1bn at the end of last year.

Dominic Johnson, Autonomy's director of marketing, said: "This partnership will provide the foundation for some of the largest, fastest and most advanced e-business systems worldwide.

"Businesses increasingly need a solution that will scale with their growing operations whilst automating the processing of large amounts of in formation for employees and consumers alike.

"Companies will no longer need to bolt together 30 different programmes to make their systems work. This will do it automatically."

At the core of Autonomy's software is a technology which has the ability to recognise a piece of text and its main ideas. After identifying the text the technology is able to categorise it, link in other relevant text and send it on to the people it thinks should see it.

Research by Intel suggests only 5% of the necessary internet infrastructure is in place to cope with the needs the e-business environment will have by 2005. It believes one of the biggest demands will be from businesses looking to find new ways to transact, transfer, store and manage digital information in automatic, faster and more cost-effective ways.

An Intel spokesman said: "The combination of the Itanium processor and Autonomy's technology will soon enable enterprises to enjoy the benefits of faster and completely automatic e-business solutions."

More than 160 major corporations including Procter & Gamble, Lucent Technologies and Unilever already use Autonomy's technology for tasks including email routing and customer relationship management.

No money is changing hands between Intel and Autonomy but they will share marketing and sales costs.

The new technology is now being tested by three large corporations and its developers hope to bring it to market in the second half of next year.

fields.headline: Yahoo defies merger surge
fields.standfirst:
Portal takes sceptical view of AOL deal
E-finance: special report
Yahoo
fields.trailText: Yahoo has reiterated its determination to remain independent despite suggestions it will be forced into a defensive merger with either a content or cable company after America Online's $350bn merger with Time Warner.
fields.body:
Yahoo has reiterated its determination to remain independent despite suggestions it will be forced into a defensive merger with either a content or cable company after America Online's $350bn merger with Time Warner.

Executives at the market-leading portal insisted it could continue to offer shareholders growth and value by standing by its strategy of remaining independent while offering the widest choice of services by signing as many content partnerships as possible.

Analysts in the US have speculated that Yahoo, which yesterday reported fourth-quarter figures, might seek to emulate AOL's bid for Time Warner by trying to buy a large media player such as Walt Disney or one of the cable television companies.

Referring to Disney's recent acquisition of internet company Infoseek, which has yet to receive enthusiastic endorsement from the stock market, Yahoo president Jeff Mallett said: "You can go back and look at some of these other deals [between internet and media companies] and they have not necessarily panned out."

Mr Mallett said he thought it unlikely that AOL would offer Time Warner content on an exclusive basis to its subscribers, for fear of upsetting the internet business's existing providers and potentially reducing the choice available to customers.

Yahoo Europe reported figures for the first time, showing 550m page views on its eight-country network of local sites during December. More than 137m of them were in the UK.

Managing director Fabiola Arredondo said that Yahoo Europe turned a profit in 1999 but she would not give precise figures.

She added that her division now has 300 content provider agreements across the continent. "Our success has been based on delivering locally meaningful services across multiple devices for our users and on providing a flexible and effective marketing vehicle for our advertisers and merchants."

US analysts welcomed Yahoo's determination to remain independent. "I don't think in any way, shape of form that America Online buying Time Warner places more measurement on Yahoo to acquire traditional media content," said Henry Blodget, Merrill Lynch's internet analyst.

For the three months ended December 31 Yahoo recorded net revenues of $201m, compared with $91m in the same quarter of the previous year. Net profits rose from $13m to $57.5m. The increase in revenues was driven by higher advertising income and greater e-commerce revenues.

Earnings per share of 15 cents disappointed some more optimistic analysts who had been looking for 21 cents and Yahoo shares fell $22.375 to $375 in early trading. Ten days ago the shares were valued at $475, having more than doubled since June, and analysts remain split on what the stock's true valuation should be.

The company's relentless expansion was underlined last year when figures from Fletcher Research showed that as of November 1999 Yahoo had the widest reach of any internet company in the UK, with 55% of the internet population. The BBC was second with 40%, Freeserve was third with 27%.

Yahoo also has the widest reach in France, Germany, Spain and Italy, according to Fletcher.

webTitle: Big brewers left out in the cold

fields.headline: Big brewers left out in the cold
fields.trailText: The big brewers must be wondering what they have to do to secure support for their ailing shares. A positive trading statement from Whitbread yesterday sparked an initial flurry in the group's stock, which spread to rival Scottish & Newcastle.
fields.body:
The big brewers must be wondering what they have to do to secure support for their ailing shares. A positive trading statement from Whitbread yesterday sparked an initial flurry in the group's stock, which spread to rival Scottish & Newcastle.

But that was quickly extinguished and Whitbread ended another day in the doldrums, down 11p at 608p. S&N also closed down - 10p at 429.25p - while Bass, which missed out on the earlier excitement, fell 26.5p to 712.5p.

A pure market is supposed never to get the price wrong. But in the case of the brewers, the level of interest remains driven not by what they themselves are doing so much as by the attraction of alternatives."The sentiment's simply rotten," said one analyst. "There aren't going to be any fireworks so the price is sinking, and reflecting the fact that the excitement is somewhere else."

Nonetheless, Whitbread is generally thought to be getting things strategically right. David Thomas, the chief executive, is driving the group towards more dependence on its David Lloyd Leisure business, its hotels and managed pubs.

The trading statement said overall sales in December were ahead of the previous year and profits were growing faster than sales, even though the group closed many of its pubs and leisure clubs early on new year's eve.

The lack of detail in the statement caused some concerns - the group gave only the increase in volumes rather than revenues for its three premium beers. Nonetheless, a 14% rise for Boddingtons and a 19% growth in Stella Artois look strong. Thomas said the second half of the year was proving more positive than the first and spoke of the success of management's determination to achieve profit growth.

There is also the possibility that Whitbread and Bass will be encouraged to sell their brewing operations in an attempt to kick-start a rerating of the shares. The problem with that, however, is that the sale of the breweries would reduce the overall size and value of the companies and may hasten rather than delay the threat that they will be evicted from the FTSE100.

fields.headline: Candidates take debate underground
fields.standfirst: But London is not New York
fields.trailText: Stand by for another furious round in the London mayoral pre-contest, with the Dobbo and Livingstone camps throwing a fresh set of inaccuracies at each other over how London might finance the fixing of its decrepit underground system.
fields.body:
Stand by for another furious round in the London mayoral pre-contest, with the Dobbo and Livingstone camps throwing a fresh set of inaccuracies at each other over how London might finance the fixing of its decrepit underground system.

Before Christmas the hostilities centred on whether an issue of municipal bonds might bridge the £7bn-wide gap, with the debate running for weeks over whether or not this approach had been used successfully in New York to fix the infrastructure there. Comptrollers of every colour were wheeled out to explain how indeed the bonds had proved crucial in rescuing the subway from near-collapse in the early 1980s and banishing this symbol of American urban decay. Livingstone won that round.

However, now comes embarrassing news that New York has run into another funding crisis, with the city now planning to raise local taxes in order to keep its subway investment programme on track.

According to the New York metropolitan transportation authority's business plan for the next four years, New Yorkers can look forward to five extra taxes ranging from a new mortgage stamp duty to a special cut of existing petrol duties.

A levy on long-distance telephone calls is also on the way - which sounds very strange in a country which is supposed to be leading us all into the so-called internet century.

It seems officials at the subway authority believe people will willingly wear all this because the local populace can remember just how bad things used to be and does not want a return to those graffiti-strewn days.

So what are the lessons here for London? Well, first it should be noted that these fresh burdens on the people of New York do not mean the city's bond approach to financing has somehow failed. It has simply transpired that not enough money was raised - although the imposition of new taxes now provokes the question of why more bonds are not being issued to fund the shortfall instead.

Over here, in the fury of the great mayoral clashes it can easily be forgotten that it is more important for Londoners that a professional handle is kept on how the money is spent, rather than worrying over the mechanics of how the money might be raised.

Mr Dobson and Mr Livingstone should remember an old rule that New Yorkers are only now waking up to: a builders' estimate is always equal to half the final bill.

Courting Virgin

Judging by the membership list of the Virgin consortium bidding for the right to run one of the new mobile telephony licences published yesterday, we might have to admit that this scoffing-at-Branson thing is an unfortunate British trait and should stop at once.

The groans that accompanied the "Sir Richard" news at the new year were typical of an instinctive feeling in the City that Virgin is really a super PR machine with a middling brand attached, rather than the other way around.

But the feeling is clearly not shared by Paul Allen, founder of Microsoft. Nor does George Soros share this view, or Warren Buffett, nor even the staunchly conservative JP Morgan. Wall Street's finest are joining two shrewd firms of the British corporate world, Tesco and EMI, and are hitching a lift on Mr Branson's latest corporate vehicle in what promises to be a roller-coaster of a ride.

Then again, all this could be read as a sign that the American investment community is just so desperate to get a piece of European mobile action, that Allen et al will back anything that appears to have any chance of success.

America's mobile market, remember, is in a fractured mess, split by competing standards. The rush for mobiles over here meant it was by accident, not design, that Europe's major mobile service providers and manufacturers found themselves at the front of the digital race to bring mobility to the internet.

This is why MCI WorldCom, the firm that belittled our own BT three years ago when it tried to buy a bit of the US market, has also got its application form in for a third-generation mobile licence. The same goes for US mobile operator Nextell and American technological meteor Global Crossing.

The Americans are determined not to be left out of the loop this time around. And for this reason we should probably now tear up the prevailing assumption that all the existing British mobile operators will even be allowed to upgrade from GSM to the new world of UMTS. Their pockets might simply prove to be too shallow.

As for Virgin, Mr Branson clearly understands he is going to need every rich friend he can get.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Third rate rise expected
fields.body:
Third rate rise expected

The Bank of England's monetary policy committee is widely expected to announce an interest rate rise today, the third since September.

Most City economists predict a further quarter-point increase to 5.75%, but a few are anticipating a more aggressive half-point move.

Core inflation is at 2.2%, but rising house prices, falling unemployment and accelerating earnings growth suggest that without further monetary tightening it will breach the government's 2.5% target over the next two years, say analysts.

Microsoft set to be broken up

The American government favours breaking up Microsoft to settle the firm's anti-trust case, industry sources said yesterday. Details of the remedy remain unclear, but the US justice department and the 19 states involved in the case are said to favour breaking up the company. A spokesman for Microsoft declined to comment on the mediation process set up to work out a solution with the software group. "We're not going to speculate on what the government may be thinking," said Microsoft spokesman Mark Murray. "We think any talk of breaking up Microsoft is completely unwarranted. There's nothing in this case that would support such a step."

Net smokers pay hefty price

Tobacco firms warned that a new internet site offering cheap mail-order cigarettes would "open the floodgates" to the black market in Britain.

Officials said customers using the service - which offers "duty free" packets of 20 cigarettes for £2.49 - could be stumping up an extra £3 a packet in duty when they took delivery of their order.Duty-free-world.com , the consortium behind the website, announced that smokers could buy well-known brands such as Marlboro and Silk Cut at knock-down prices, with the duty being paid in Spain before the goods are shipped to UK customers' doors.

Boeing buys into satellite

Boeing is close to a deal to purchase the satellite manufacturing operations of General Motors' Hughes Electronics unit for $4bn (£2.4bn), it was reported last night. An announcement could take place today, after a meeting of Boeing's board.

Disney loses chairman

Walt Disney Studios chairman Joe Roth is expected to resign this week to form an independently financed film company, according to reports yesterday. The LA Times said Mr Roth's departure would be a serious loss for Disney.

Foulston quits Brands Hatch

webTitle: Thirteen bidders in battle for five mobile licences

fields.headline: Thirteen bidders in battle for five mobile licences
fields.trailText: The auction of licences in the next generation of mobile phones exploded into life yesterday as a mix of the world's largest telecommunications companies and wealthiest financiers lined up to bid.
fields.body:
The auction of licences in the next generation of mobile phones exploded into life yesterday as a mix of the world's largest telecommunications companies and wealthiest financiers lined up to bid.

The 13 bidders who will compete for the five licences include a consortium of Virgin, Tesco, and EMI, backed by Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen's Vulcan Ventures and George Soros's Quantum Industrial partners. Other investors in the Virgin-led bid include Berkshire Group, Blackstone and JP Morgan.

Other surprise names on the list are aggressive US telecoms company MCI WorldCom, recently privatised Irish telecoms company Eircom and Japanese bank Nomura.

The intense interest generated by the auction guarantees a huge windfall for the government, which set a combined reserve price on the licences of £500m. Previous estimates have suggested the licences will raise a total upwards of £1.5bn.

The presence of big names with deep pockets on the list - including WorldCom's Bernie Ebbers, who outgunned British Telecom in the bidding for MCI - will unnerve the four established networks. One licence has been reserved for a new bidder but new entrants can also bid alongside the other four, raising the prospect of one of the established networks losing out.

"It can't be ruled out that one of the existing networks won't get one of the new licences. The potential downside for them is enormous," said Alex Gunz, telecoms analyst at ABN Amro.

The Virgin bid also includes US mobile operator Nextell and Finnish network Sonera. A spokesman for Virgin said the consortium would bid "whatever is economically necessary" to secure a licence.

If Virgin wins, it is likely to relocate its Virgin Mobile service to its own network and could break up its joint venture with One2One.

The next generation of mobile phones, called variously third generation or UMTS, will enable high bandwidth applications such as high speed internet access and video phones.

The government will give notice of pre-qualification on February 14, and the auction will take place over a period of several weeks from March 6. The auction will involve simultaneous bids over a series of rounds until only one is left for each licence.

fields.headline: The unknown heart-throb
fields.standfirst: He's talented, he's phenomenally good-looking and theatre audiences love him. So why hasn't Stephen Dillane made it big on screen? He talks to  Bibi van der Zee
fields.trailText: To theatregoers, Stephen Dillane is one of the finest actors of his generation. His performance in Tom Stoppard's The Real Thing made him the Evening Standard's Best Actor of 1999. His Hamlet in 1994 for the Peter Hall Company was rated as one of the best of the decade, and Angels in America, where Dillane took one of the two lead roles, was universally acclaimed as one of the National's greatest ever shows.
fields.body:
To theatregoers, Stephen Dillane is one of the finest actors of his generation. His performance in Tom Stoppard's The Real Thing made him the Evening Standard's Best Actor of 1999. His Hamlet in 1994 for the Peter Hall Company was rated as one of the best of the decade, and Angels in America, where Dillane took one of the two lead roles, was universally acclaimed as one of the National's greatest ever shows.

But outside the theatre Dillane is virtually unknown. None of his films have done magnificently well (Welcome to Sarajevo was probably his biggest leading role), and if you want to remind people who he is, you have to mention performances: the good-looking one in The Rector's Wife, Horatio to Mel Gibson's Hamlet, Clov to Alun Armstrong's Hamm in Endgame. Then they either say "Nope, sorry, still can't place him", or agree that he is, after all, brilliant. It's odd, because he is so very good-looking, and such a good actor, that he really should have broken through to the big time. In Warsaw, where we meet for a meal during the filming of a TV series, he is just another anonymous Brit.

Dillane, 40, grew up in south London, the son of a surgeon, and got involved in theatre at school. He remembers being in Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead, and thinking of the moment where Rosencrantz points out towards the audience and shouts "Fire!" as "a very thrilling thing to be able to do". Then he toddled off to Exeter university and read history and politics, before starting work as a journalist at the Croydon Advertiser. He hated journalism "from the moment I walked in".

Why? "I just didn't fit in. It seemed very_" He hesitates for a long time, looking for the right word. This happens frequently throughout the interview. "Pinched," he eventually concludes. "There was someone else who joined at the same time - a very expansive sort of person - and he really got put down and shown his place. I didn't like that. I kept a low profile, but I felt inhibited - it all seemed very dangerous. It demanded a resilience that maybe I didn't have." After a couple of bruising encounters at NUJ meetings, and a few years going round cemeteries checking how many cremations they'd had that week, he read an interview with Trevor Eve about how he'd given up architecture to become an actor, and that was it. He packed in the shorthand ("I was never very fast; I doubt I can still do it") and headed off to Bristol Old Vic theatre school.

The theatre seems the last place of refuge for a sensitive soul like Dillane: rejections, bitchiness and politics are surely the bread and butter of the theatrical community. But Dillane claims never to have come across it. Sometimes he'll socialise with the cast, sometimes he won't. He's never been too closely associated with one company or director (although he works with Katie Mitchell whenever possible), and he tries to see it all as a job. Or so he says. But despite a jokey "Maybe I don't take work seriously enough", it's clear from his descriptions of his insecurity as an actor that at times he takes it all too seriously.

'I f you feel uncomfortable on stage," Dillane declares, "you can very easily descend into a sort of abyss, convinced you're the worst actor ever, that you're a disgrace to the profession, that you're a disgrace to yourself. It's an awful feeling. I've got better at relaxing, and just telling myself that I'm probably not the worst actor and that it's fine. But once it gets hold of you, and you feel like you're letting everybody down, it's terribly difficult to let go of." Does he still get it? "Oh yes. Oh god, yes."

Perhaps that's one reason he's not better known. I ask if he actually wants to be famous, and he spends a long pause trying to get at the egg yolk at the bottom of his soup. "I don't think so," he says finally, quietly. "It feels like a poisoned chalice to me." He dives back into his soup quickly and then surfaces to say: "I probably don't, because I keep taking decisions that turn me away from that. In some way these things are out of your control, but it's like when you get a script through, and it's associated with all sorts of people and you know it could be good for you and you find yourself either not going along, or going along and not working quite hard enough to get it. Some bit of you is holding you back. Maybe I'm not grown up enough: I don't want to spend 10 weeks of my life being miserable on a film set doing something I don't want to do."

Tom Stoppard said of Dillane's performance in The Real Thing that it had "such integrity as to scare the life out of an author", and this is probably true of every part Dillane takes on. He certainly thinks deeply about every question put to him. When, during one particularly long pause, I ask why he doesn't do what other actors do and just say whatever comes to mind, he explains that he wants to understand why he does what he does. "I'm curious myself."

The longest pauses, of course, are reserved for questions about his personal life. He admits to having two children, aged eight and one, but will go no further. Other sources reveal that he's had a long, live-in relationship with actress Naomi Wirthner.

As Karenin, the repressed husband in Channel 4's production of Anna Karenina (the reason he is in Poland), he will, I think, be brilliant. Of course, he won't even admit the possibility. He is useless at plugging himself. Asked about the film The Darkest Light, which is coming out this week, he starts trying to remember when he made it, and then is unable to recall the name of the film he did afterwards.

The way he talks about his looks is typical: he worries that work might get a little harder to find as he gets older. But he never made much use of them anyway, turning down numerous good-looking-guy roles after making the hearts of middle England flutter in 1994's The Rector's Wife. "I couldn't work my way into being a good-looking guy," he says. "There you are, being a good-looking guy, and what next?" I suggest flirting and he says he's never really been much good at that. "I think it basically takes a while for me to warm up." Not shy, he insists, just guarded. "I always have been."

fields.headline: Mountain sickness
fields.standfirst: Derek Malcolm picks his 100 greatest movies. This week, number 51: Les Blank's Burden of Dreams
fields.trailText: Derek Malcolm picks his 100 greatest movies. This week, number 51: Les Blank's Burden of Dreams
fields.body:
Films about film-making are usually deeply self-conscious, and sometimes deceiving. But there is one at least that succeeds in surpassing the movie whose making it describes. Les Blank's Burden of Dreams admittedly had it easier than most. The movie it examined was Werner Herzog's Fitzcarraldo, made on location deep in the rainforests of South America and a monument to Herzog's almost masochistic desire to do the impossible impossibly well.

Fitzcarraldo is the true story of the attempt by an arguably mad Irishman called Fitzgerald to build an opera house in the Amazon. He had initially planned to build a railroad across the continent, starting off with his profits from an ice factory he had built; this new plan was even more audacious.

Klaus Kinski, the conquistador of Aguirre, Wrath of God, played this excessive character when Jason Robards went down with amoebic dysentery, and the casting could scarcely have been bettered. Kinski's behaviour would have taxed a saint. On a wider front, almost everything that could go wrong with the production did. The film had to be moved some 1,200 miles when a border war broke out between the local Indians, and even at the new venue the tribesmen felt provoked enough to become alarmingly hostile.

Plane crashes, disease, rain and mud disturbed Herzog's efforts to achieve his tour de force in the film - getting a team of natives to pull an old steamship up a steep hillside using only block and tackle.

All this was meat and drink to Blank, a well-known ethnographic documentarist. But he doesn't take the mickey. He just records the scene, including Kinski's tempers, the Indians' suspicious and often threatening behaviour and Herzog's descent into near-hysteria.

Blank's film includes the only available record of some of the unused scenes with Robards and Mick Jagger, who left for a concert tour after all the delays, doubtless with some relief. It also shows the actual mechanisms by which Herzog hoped to move the old ship halfway up a mountain. A giant bulldozer augments the block-and-pulley but proves unequal to the task as the Brazilian engineer in charge of the operation storms off, complaining that it is virtually certain that lives will be lost.

This is warts-and-all stuff, made with sympathy but determined to show us as much of the truth as possible. Part of that truth is that Herzog seemed to identify with Fitzgerald (called Fitzcarraldo by the natives), and certainly his plan to make a film in such a place was almost as crazy as the Irishman's opera house daydream.

Fitzcarraldo, though full of notable sequences, doesn't entirely work; Blank's film, however, does. You don't have to have seen Fitzcarraldo to appreciate it. As Time Out said at the time, it takes on a crazy life of its own.

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Who will direct the movie version of Spiderman?
fields.trailText: Who will direct the movie version of Spiderman?
fields.body:
Sam Raimi 5-2

James Cameron 3-1

Richard Donner 5-1

Steven Spielberg 5-1

Jan de Bont 10-1

David Fincher 14-1

Debate among fans of the long-john-wearing arachnid boy has reached fever pitch over rumours that a film will be imminently green-lighted.

Variety announced earlier this week that Columbia wants Sam Raimi to direct its big-budget adaptation of the Marvel Comics franchise. The emergence of Raimi over the past two weeks comes with a web of intrigue and entanglements that has prevented Columbia from making a formal offer.

"Raimi has other films he is committed to direct", says Ed Nicholson, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler. "While Raimi is an avowed Spiderman fanatic, Sony needs the film for summer 2001. If the production companies can negotiate he'll be odds-on to direct, but as it is he is still a favourite."

Richard Donner has done it before with Superman, and he can do it again, says Ed. "And like Donner, Spielberg could bring just the right sprawling, fantastic, epic feeling it would need. But it might mean that Spidey has to find the child within, and that won't please the hardcore fans."

"James Cameron would also get the special effects right", says Ed. "But the characters are so important in Spiderman, it might be better off with an actor's director rather than such an obviously visual one. Nevertheless, his script treatment for the film on a Spiderman website is getting good feedback from the fans."

David Fincher and Jan de Bont are outsiders because they lack experience in super-hero flicks, says Ed. "Although Jan de Bont did Speed, his recent flick The Haunting and Twister suggests he is a great cinematographer, not a great director. And I can't imagine any studio executive looking at David Fincher's Fight Club and thinking he is the perfect choice for launching a new child-friendly franchise."
