webTitle: Cuban exiles thank God for Elian

fields.headline: Cuban exiles thank God for Elian
fields.standfirst: The 'miracle' of the young boy found at sea has empowered US rightwingers
fields.trailText: It is a humble home compared to some of the stucco palaces in Miami's Little Havana - and in the eyes of the faithful gathered around the fence, its modesty is fitting. For them, it is a shrine to a Cuban miracle.
fields.body:
It is a humble home compared to some of the stucco palaces in Miami's Little Havana - and in the eyes of the faithful gathered around the fence, its modesty is fitting. For them, it is a shrine to a Cuban miracle.

It is difficult to understand the ferocity of the movement to keep six-year-old Elian Gonzalez in Miami without witnessing the religious fervour with which he has been embraced by devout Catholic conservatives among the Cuban exile community here.

Outside the house, owned by Elian's great-uncle, Lazaro, a trio of 3ft figures have been planted like latterday saints: Mickey Mouse, Minnie Mouse and Santa Claus. They are just a few of the gaudy lorryful of gifts unloaded on the little boy since he was plucked out of the Florida straits on November 25 after seeing his mother and 12 other Cubans drown while attempting to reach the US coast. At night, the plastic trinity is illuminated by fairy lights.

The spiritual imagery is no accident. The coterie of rightwing activists who have surrounded Elian and now bask in the constant media glow emphasise the religious significance of his appearance at every turn.

"There is something mythical about him," said Jose Basulto, an exile leader. "He has come to us as a sign sent from God. It is too spiritual to put a finger on what he touches in the heart - but whatever it is, the child has united the Cuba community in exile."

Whatever other miracles he is being credited with, Elian has certainly come to the salvation of the Cuban right, which mass-produced images of his angelic face within hours of his recovery from the sea on November 25. Since then, his presence has provided a rallying cry and a shot of adrenaline at a time when the hardliners' influence among young Cuban Americans was dwindling, along with their absolutist influence on US foreign policy.

Before Elian was found bobbing on the waves clinging to a car inner tube, Washington had begun to lose its fear of the electoral clout wielded by the hardliners. In 1994, the US started returning refugees found on the open water back to Cuba, much to the disgust of Brothers to the Rescue, Mr Basulto's radical group, which patrolled the seas to guide them to an American haven.

The change in policy meant that Cubans were no longer a special case. They were no longer exiles waiting to return at any moment, but just another immigrant community.

Then in November 1997, Jorge Mas Canosa, the patriarchal boss of Cuban exile politics, died, leaving a vacuum which has been filled by new moderate groups, almost as resentful of the dominance of Mas Canosa's Cuban-American National Foundation in south Florida as they were of Fidel Castro's alleged tyranny across the straits.

webTitle: Reno - boy to go back to Cuba

fields.headline: Reno - boy to go back to Cuba
fields.trailText: The US attorney general, Janet Reno, yesterday brushed aside a challenge from a Miami court over the fate of Elian Gonzalez and stuck to her decision that the six-year-old Cuban boy should be returned to his father in Havana.
fields.body:
The US attorney general, Janet Reno, yesterday brushed aside a challenge from a Miami court over the fate of Elian Gonzalez and stuck to her decision that the six-year-old Cuban boy should be returned to his father in Havana.

But Ms Reno also took steps to avoid transforming the showdown into a street confrontation with Cuban exiles determined to keep Elian in Miami. He has been staying with relatives in the city since he was found floating in the Florida Straits in November.

Ms Reno dropped a Friday deadline for Elian's return and gave no new time limit in a letter to lawyers for the boy's US relatives, leaving the door open to an appeal.

But she dismissed a ruling on Monday by a Florida judge blocking Elian's repatriation and handing temporary custody to his Miami-based uncle, Lazaro. Ms Reno said the judgment had "no force or effect". Elian's legal guardian, she insisted, was his father, Juan Miguel, who is demanding the boy's return to Cuba.

Elian's mother and stepfather drowned when the boat bringing them to the US sank.

"The question of who may speak for a six-year-old child in applying for admission or asy lum is a matter of federal immigration law," Ms Reno wrote. She said Elian's return could only be challenged in federal courts, adding: "We are prepared to litigate in that forum."

Cuban exile activists said yesterday they would take up Ms Reno's challenge, but had no immediate plans to resume last week's street protests.

The case has become a litmus test in the US presidential campaign, with Republican candidates lining up to support the Cuban exiles. Meanwhile, the Democratic frontrunner and vice-president, Al Gore, has distanced himself from the attorney-general.

The affair has also illuminated the web of patronage and bartering of favours that characterises the Cuban exile dominance of Miami politics.

Rosa Rodriguez - the judge who ruled to keep Elian in Florida on the grounds that he would face "irreparable harm" in Cuba - was revealed to have had substantial political and business links with Armando Gutierrez, the chief spokesman for the exile campaign to block the boy's return.

According to public records, she paid Mr Gutierrez $10,000 (and his wife, Maritza, more than $53,000) for helping Ms Rodriguez's 1998 campaign for election as a circuit judge.

Ms Rodriguez defended her self yesterday, saying: "A judge has no ethical obligation to disclose participation by attorneys or participants in a past judicial election campaign."

An opinion poll yesterday found that 56% of Americans supported the Immigration and Naturalisation Service (INS) in its efforts to return Elian to his father, with only 36% opposing.

fields.headline: Les Blank: Burden of Dreams
fields.standfirst: Films about film-making are usually deeply self-conscious, and sometimes deceiving. But this is one at least that succeeds in surpassing the movie whose making it describes
fields.trailText: Films about film-making are usually deeply self-conscious, and sometimes deceiving. But this is one at least that succeeds in surpassing the movie whose making it describes
fields.body:
Films about film-making are usually deeply self-conscious, and sometimes deceiving. But there is one at least that succeeds in surpassing the movie whose making it describes. Les Blank's Burden of Dreams admittedly had it easier than most. The movie it examined was Werner Herzog's Fitzcarraldo, made on location deep in the rainforests of South America and a monument to Herzog's almost masochistic desire to do the impossible impossibly well.

Fitzcarraldo is the true story of the attempt by an arguably mad Irishman called Fitzgerald to build an opera house in the Amazon. He had initially planned to build a railroad across the continent, starting off with his profits from an ice factory he had built; this new plan was even more audacious.

Klaus Kinski, the conquistador of Aguirre, Wrath of God, played this excessive character when Jason Robards went down with amoebic dysentery, and the casting could scarcely have been bettered. Kinski's behaviour would have taxed a saint. On a wider front, almost everything that could go wrong with the production did. The film had to be moved some 1,200 miles when a border war broke out between the local Indians, and even at the new venue the tribesmen felt provoked enough to become alarmingly hostile.

Plane crashes, disease, rain and mud disturbed Herzog's efforts to achieve his tour de force in the film - getting a team of natives to pull an old steamship up a steep hillside using only block and tackle.

All this was meat and drink to Blank, a well-known ethnographic documentarist. But he doesn't take the mickey. He just records the scene, including Kinski's tempers, the Indians' suspicious and often threatening behaviour and Herzog's descent into near-hysteria.

Blank's film includes the only available record of some of the unused scenes with Robards and Mick Jagger, who left for a concert tour after all the delays, doubtless with some relief. It also shows the actual mechanisms by which Herzog hoped to move the old ship halfway up a mountain. A giant bulldozer augments the block-and-pulley but proves unequal to the task as the Brazilian engineer in charge of the operation storms off, complaining that it is virtually certain that lives will be lost.

This is warts-and-all stuff, made with sympathy but determined to show us as much of the truth as possible. Part of that truth is that Herzog seemed to identify with Fitzgerald (called Fitzcarraldo by the natives), and certainly his plan to make a film in such a place was almost as crazy as the Irishman's opera house daydream.

Fitzcarraldo, though full of notable sequences, doesn't entirely work; Blank's film, however, does. You don't have to have seen Fitzcarraldo to appreciate it. As Time Out said at the time, it takes on a crazy life of its own.

webTitle: Watchdog urges new rights for accused MPs

fields.headline: Watchdog urges new rights for accused MPs
fields.standfirst: Committee urges limit on number of special advisers, more openness            on sponsors, and curbs on task forces set up by Labour
fields.trailText: January 13 2000: Committee urges limit on number of special advisers, more openness on sponsors, and curbs on task forces set up by Labour.
fields.body:
MPs accused of serious misconduct should get legal aid from the taxpayer to be able to challenge the findings of an investigation of the parliamentary commissioner for standards, Lord Neill recommended yesterday.

The report recommends sweeping changes in the appeal procedures for MPs facing misconduct charges in the wake of the row over the `cash for questions'' scandal. This case led to controversy after Sir Gordon Downey, the former parliamentary commissioner for standards, found `compelling' evidence that former minister, Neil Hamilton, had taken up to £25,000 in cash from Harrods owner, Mohamed Al Fayed, for asking questions in the Commons. Sir Gordon's verdict was endorsed by a libel court jury last month.

The report by the committee on standards in public life also recommends new limits on the number of special advisers a new civil service act to enforce a code of conduct for political advisers curbs on task forces set up by the Labour government the recording of all formal meetings with lobbyists and ministers and the disclosure of sponsorship of government events above £5,000.

MPs

Lord Neill's recommendations on reforming investigations into MPs echo the findings of Lord Nicholls, who chaired a joint Commons and Lords investigation into parliamentary privilege last year.

Both he and Lord Neill say that the bribery and corruption laws should be extended to MPs and those who bribe MPs. The home office says that Jack Straw is keen in principle to introduce a new law but is reviewing the details.

Lord Neill recommends that where MPs are accused of serious conduct which falls short of bribery they should be entitled to challenge the findings of the parliamentary commissioner. The appeal would initially be heard by a tribunal of two to four senior MPs chaired by a lawyer. The MP would get legal aid and the tribunal would re-assess the facts and decide whether the charges are proved. The MP could appeal on this decision to another body chaired by a former judge. Lord Neill recommends that the hearings should be held in public but not broadcast.

He said yesterday: `These cases are very grave cases where the result of being found guilty is in effect to lead to the end of the MP's career. We consider that in cases of that gravity the defendant should have access to public money.'

He also recommends that the composition of the standards and privileges committee should be changed, with more senior MPs sitting in judgment of their peers. The chairman of the committee should be a member of the opposition rather than, as now, a senior government backbencher.

Advisers

The report recommends that Westminster follows the Scottish parliament and the Welsh assembly and limits the number of special advisers, and urges that their activities be subject to a code of conduct which could be backed by law through a new civil service act. This code will include spelling out relations between special advisers and their conduct with the media and civil servants. But Lord Neill dismissed suggestions that special advisers had necessarily broken Whitehall rules.

The number of special advisers appointed by the government is now 74 - up from 38 at the beginning of 1997. They are employed at a cost of £3.9m to the taxpayer.

`The considerable increase in numbers, particularly at No 10 where influential roles are played by special advisers raises the question of whether their authority outweighs that of objective advisers,'' the report said. The report says a new code of conduct should make clear that special advisers had a specific duty to uphold the impartiality of the civil service as well as regulating their contacts with the media.

Lord Neill said that while the committee had not concluded that there had been a ` politicisation '' of the civil service , they believed that the time had now come to `take stock'' of the situation.

He said that he would `deplore'' any spin doctor who briefed journalists on behalf of their minister against rival members of the government.

Lobbyists

He rejects the need for the registration of lobbyists but accepts evidence from Observer journalist Greg Palast that records of meetings between lobbyists and ministers, civil servants and special advisers should be kept. But he provides a loophole for special advisers - by saying they should only record meetings where the lobbyist tries to influence people rather than seek information.

Lord Neill said that even the recorded information will remain secret for 30 years under the present freedom of information act because it will relates `to the formulation or development of policy''.

Sponsors

The report accepts that government departments - notably the foreign office - have a right to get private company sponsorship for conferences and events. But Lord Neill introduces caveats, including putting the onus on ministers seeking sponsorship to ensure that this is in the public interest.

He says departments must publish details of all deals exceeding £5,000.

Lord Neill's committee has much stronger views about the politicisation of the NHS. It warns that the present system - which has seen a huge increase in political appointments under Labour - has caused `considerable disquiet' and welcomes the present inquiry being undertaken by Dame Rennie Fitch, the public appointments commisisoner, into its operation.

Patronage

Lord Neill also calls for restrictions on Labour's creation of 44 task forces from industry and research bodies to investigate problems from social exclusion to problems on housing estates.

He expresses concern that they could be a new form of political patronage under Labour and says they should only have a limited life to investigate particular problems. Any body lasting more than two years should be disbanded or become a properly accountable quango.

Main points

 MPs caught taking bribes to face criminal charges

 Legal aid for MPs

 accused of serious misconduct by the parliamentary commissioner

 Prime minister to investigate ministers accused of serious misconduct

 Ministers must record all meetings with lobbyists

 New code of conduct for special advisers and limits on future appointments

 Disquiet about NHS trust and authority appointment system

 Sponsorship of government conferences and events above £5,000 must be declared

 Labour's new task force bodies must be disbanded within two years or be subject to strict rules on appointments

fields.headline: £1.2bn wiped off Dixons' value
fields.standfirst:
Collapse in shares means internet service is worth more than 1,000-store chain
E-finance: special report
Dixons
fields.trailText: More than £1.2bn was wiped off the stock market value of electrical retailer Dixons yesterday as the group was forced to admit its profit margins are being hit by tumbling prices.
fields.body:
More than £1.2bn was wiped off the stock market value of electrical retailer Dixons yesterday as the group was forced to admit its profit margins are being hit by tumbling prices.

The price collapse leaves the vast Dixons empire - which includes Currys, PC World, The Link and Jakarta and is the UK's largest electrical retailer - appearing increasingly like an internet company with shopping offshoots.

The company is now valued at just over £5bn, but its 80% holding in internet service provider Freeserve is valued at £3.7bn. The 1,000-store business, therefore, is worth only a little more than a third of the loss-making net operation.

The price of the store group's shares slumped by 302p - more than 20% - as analysts took fright at the Dixons' warning, even though the company was also unveiling better than expected first half profits, a £121m cash handout to shareholders and a robust set of sales figures showing a 5% improvement in pre-Christmas trading.

Dixons reported a 0.7% decline in its profit margins last year, but yesterday chairman Sir Stanley Kalms said: "It is definitely 1% or more now."

Analysts described the information as an "unwelcome surprise", but Sir Stanley disagreed. "It may be unwelcome, but it is not a surprise. If analysts haven't noticed that prices are going down then they are out of touch and not doing their jobs properly."

He added: "We have had deflation for quite a few years now and it will carry on in some products.

"It is probably averaging 5% but on some products is much more. We are selling videos for £70 that cost £300 a few years ago, we have high quality computers for £400 - and just look what has happened to the price of mobile phones, down from £69 to £39".

But he warned that to start decribing Dixons as an internet company was "a flippant reaction", insisting that the company remained primarily a retailer and that he was unworried by the share price.

"It doesn't mean very much. It is just a knee-jerk reaction. We have had a good year and are pleased with our results."

The company was reporting profits up 14% in the six months to November 13.

Underlying profit, before tax, exceptional items and a £8.6m loss at Freeserve, rose to £92.5m, compared to £80.9m a year ago.

Shareholders are to receive a 25p a share cash handout after the company banked £219m from the sale of 20% of Freeserve last year.

The company said the product cycle and outlook was encouraging. "The digital TV boom hasn't even started yet, and DVD is going to have a major impact.

"In two or three years' time nobody will be buying video tape recorders. Digital cameras have also become a serious product group."

The company also announced its plans to make Dixons a major net retailer by the end of this year, with a £30m investment.

"Nobody understands e-commerce properly," said Sir Stanley. "Setting up a website is easy. It is like putting a carpet down in the street and putting a few goods out on it.

"You could do that from your bedroom. But successful e-commerce will be about fulfilment. It is about next-day delivery anywhere in the country, it is about servicing, repairs and returns," he said.

The price of the store group's shares slumped by 302p - more than 20% - as analysts took fright at the Dixons' warning, even though the company was also unveiling better than expected first half profits, a £121m cash handout to shareholders and a robust set of sales figures showing a 5% improvement in pre-Christmas trading. Dixons reported a 0.7% decline in its profit margins last year, but yesterday chairman Sir Stanley Kalms said: "It is definitely 1% or more now." Analysts described the information as an "unwelcome surprise", but Sir Stanley disagreed. "It may be unwelcome, but it is not a surprise. If analysts haven't noticed that prices are going down then they are out of touch and not doing their jobs properly." He added: "We have had deflation for quite a few years now and it will carry on in some products. "It is probably averaging 5% but on some products is much more. We are selling videos for £70 that cost £300 a few years ago, we have high quality computers for £400 - and just look what has happened to the price of mobile phones, down from £69 to £39". But he warned that to start decribing Dixons as an internet company was "a flippant reaction", insisting that the company remained primarily a retailer and that he was unworried by the share price. "It doesn't mean very much. It is just a knee-jerk reaction. We have had a good year and are pleased with our results." The company was reporting profits up 14% in the six months to November 13. Underlying profit, before tax, exceptional items and a £8.6m loss at Freeserve, rose to £92.5m, compared to £80.9m a year ago. Shareholders are to receive a 25p a share cash handout after the company banked £219m from the sale of 20% of Freeserve last year. The company said the product cycle and outlook was encouraging. "The digital TV boom hasn't even started yet, and DVD is going to have a major impact. "In two or three years' time nobody will be buying video tape recorders. Digital cameras have also become a serious product group." The company also announced its plans to make Dixons a major net retailer by the end of this year, with a £30m investment. "Nobody understands e-commerce properly," said Sir Stanley. "Setting up a website is easy. It is like putting a carpet down in the street and putting a few goods out on it. "You could do that from your bedroom. But successful e-commerce will be about fulfilment. It is about next-day delivery anywhere in the country, it is about servicing, repairs and returns," he said.

webTitle: How the Bank of England decides

fields.headline: How the Bank of England decides
fields.standfirst:
More about house prices
Bank raises interest rates
fields.trailText: The decision by the Bank of England to raise interest rates by a quarter of a percentage rate will mean higher borrowing costs for people with floating interest rates overdrafts and mortgages, or anyone planning to take out a new loan. Banks and building societies tend to raise rates within days or weeks of a decision by the Bank of England.
fields.body:
The decision by the Bank of England to raise interest rates by a quarter of a percentage rate will mean higher borrowing costs for people with floating interest rates overdrafts and mortgages, or anyone planning to take out a new loan. Banks and building societies tend to raise rates within days or weeks of a decision by the Bank of England.

The rise will eventually be good news for savers with deposit accounts, although it make take some time before the rates paid on their accounts move upwards to reflect the increase. One of the ways banks and building societies make money is to raise mortgage rates quickly but delay the rise in savings rates, in order to maximise the margin they make for themselves.

The Bank's monetary policy committee (MPC) - a group of nine experts drawn from the Bank of England and the outside world of academia and business - decided to raise its base lending rate by a quarter of a percentage point to 5.75 per cent.

There have been forecasts of strong house price growth for this year, and the quarter per cent rise is unlikely to have an immediate effect on demand for homes. Successive interest rate rises later in the year could, however, in theory, apply a gentle brake to house price inflation.

In a terse statement issued alongside the decision at noon, the MPC suggested that the shortage of workers in the UK's labour market and the inability of the economy to meet current demand were likely inflationary culprits.

The decision will, however, mean more pain for exporters, as an interest rate rise tends to push up the value of sterling and make it more expensive for overseas companies to buy British goods. It will also increase borrowing costs for business which are taking out loans in order to expand.

The committee's decision sets the Bank of England's official lending rate at the highest level for official interest rates since the start of January last year, when rates were 6 per cent. Today's decision was the third time the Bank has raised rates in the last five months. Analysts said the move was a 'proactive' one by the Bank, designed to head off an outbreak of inflation as the economy continues to expand strongly.

The decision reflects the need to keep inflation under control to avoid the 'boom and bust' economics which consumers and industry find so painful. The MPC is charged by the government to keep official retail price inflation - excluding the effects of mortgage payments - to 2.5 per cent within a two year horizon. The latest inflation figures showed prices rising at an annual rate of 2.2 per cent in November.

The move to raise rates was instantly criticised by a number of unions and business groups, including the Confederation of British Industry, the employers lobby group, that described the decision as 'unsurprising but still disappointing'.

Engineering Employers' Federation director-general Martin Temple also criticised the rate hike over the way the MPC had responded to recent economic data. "[The MPC] is too quick to react to short term data, inducing industry to manage in the short term," he said.

Union leaders attacked the interest rate rise, warning that firms will find it more difficult to expand and export. Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing Science and Finance union, said: "This is a disaster for manufacturing, particularly for jobs in the North."

fields.headline: Interest rates up 0.25%
fields.standfirst: Bank of England
fields.trailText: The Bank of England's monetary policy committee has raised interest rates by 0.25% to 5.75%, the first rise since November.
fields.body:
The Bank of England's monetary policy committee has raised interest rates by 0.25% to 5.75%, the first rise since November.

Some financial experts had speculated that the bank would raise the base rate to 6% to cool the consumer spending boom. However, it concluded that an increase of 0.25% would be enough to meet the underlying inflation target of 2.5% in the medium term. The committee anticipates that the underlying rate (which excludes mortgage payments), currently at 2.2%, will rise in the longer term.

The committee predicted that the domestic economy would continue to grow "robustly" and described the world economic outlook as "strengthened".

The rate rise is a blow to millions of homeowners who can expect their mortgage interest payments to go up on the back of the MPC's decision. It comes against the background of a continuing house market boom, accelerated growth in average earnings and falling unemployment, all stoking fears of rising inflation.

Union leaders criticised the interest rate rise, which they said would make expansion and exports harder.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said: "Some manufacturing sectors are beginning to expand but this will undermine confidence. The strength of sterling is already wiping out productivity gains and efficiency increases."

Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing Science and Finance union, described the rise as "a disaster for manufacturing, particularly for jobs in the North".

The director-general of the Confederation of British Industry, Digby Jones, described the MPC's decision as "unsurprising but still disappointing" after recent positive economic data.

fields.headline: Corruption of irony
fields.standfirst:
Widowers' Houses
Cottesloe, Royal National Theatre, London/touring
*
At the Cottesloe (0171-452 3000) tonight, then touring, returning to the Cottesloe from February 8-12
fields.trailText: When Fiona Shaw directs Bernard Shaw one expects something sparky. What I hadn't anticipated was an event as whimsical, vulgar and perverse as this total misreading of Shaw's first play: it's a production that not only shows an adolescent preoccupation with sex but also replaces Shaw's bitterly ironic attack on capitalism with a study of individual neurosis.
fields.body:
When Fiona Shaw directs Bernard Shaw one expects something sparky. What I hadn't anticipated was an event as whimsical, vulgar and perverse as this total misreading of Shaw's first play: it's a production that not only shows an adolescent preoccupation with sex but also replaces Shaw's bitterly ironic attack on capitalism with a study of individual neurosis.

Where to start? Maybe with Shaw's astonishing play, written in 1892, which shows how easily people accommodate themselves to corruption. Harry Trench, a young doctor, falls for Blanche Sartorius in the course of a Rhine tour, only to discover that her father's wealth derives from slum landlordism. Harry's savage indignation is somewhat punctured when he learns from Sartorius that his own modest income stems from the same source. By the end, however, all is put right. Sartorius, finding there is more money to be made from decency than dirt, cynically plans to repair his properties. Harry agrees to join him in a risky investment. And the hot-tempered Blanche, having rejected her lover's pious poverty, avidly reclaims him when he joins the capitalist rat race.

Clearly one of Shaw's points, in a society where the squares derive their money from the slums, is that people who live in glass houses can't afford to throw stones. With numbing literalism, Peter McKintosh's set actually consists of a stony terrace and a broken-windowed conservatory in which Sartorius ostensibly lives. Even more dauntingly, Fiona Shaw drags the play's erotic subtext kicking and screaming into the open. Harry kisses and crotch-grabs his travelling companion Cokane. Notwithstanding, Harry and Blanche don't just embrace on the Rhine but go at it hammer and tongs, observed by her father. And Lickcheese, Sartorius's sacked rent collector who uses his insider knowledge for personal profit, turns up in the last act sporting a black dress and matching beads.

None of this would matter very much - good plays outlive silly directors - if it weren't that it symbolises the production's whole shift of emphasis from the system to the individual. Shaw's ultimate black joke is that even the idealistic Harry and the impassioned Blanche end up complicit with capitalism: the happy ending is biliously ironic. So what do we get here? Blanche is transformed into a neurotically pregnant Hedda Gabler left gazing wanly at her estranged lover. Thus the most openly socialist play of the Victorian era is turned into a psychological case history; where Bernard Shaw's play attacks individualism, Fiona Shaw's production celebrates it. Pip Donaghy and Emma Bernbach, as the two Sartorii, are caught up in a punily conceptual production that tells you far more than you wish to know about its director and not nearly enough about its author.

webTitle: Ulster Bank moves into mobile era

fields.headline: Ulster Bank moves into mobile era
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Ulster Bank
fields.trailText: Ulster Bank aims to become one of the first banks in Britain to offer customers access to their accounts via mobile phones.
fields.body:
Ulster Bank aims to become one of the first banks in Britain to offer customers access to their accounts via mobile phones.

The bank is using an early version of WAP (wireless application protocol) handsets to hook up to the internet for the launch of the service in April.

It will initially offer recent account transactions, balances and cheque book ordering, with services being added as more sophisticated versions of the handsets become available. Later this year customers will be able to switch money from accounts or pay credit card bills from their phones.

"We see the development of our e-commerce and mobile commerce plans as central to the strategic development of our business," said Ulster Bank IT manager Martin Drayne. "The speed at which we proceed is hugely dependent on security and initial WAP phones don't have the heavy duty requirement for more advanced services. The technology should be available in three to four months."

The service will start with the Nokia 7110 handset which came on to the market at the end of last year and resembles an ordinary phone with a slightly larger screen. Software for the service has been put together by Irish company Macalla Software.

The Woolwich announced in October last year that it intends to pilot a similar service next month with a group of around 100 people.

Ulster Bank began an online service for access via PCs six months ago under the Anytime brand initially coined for its telephone banking service. Mobile phone access will come under the same umbrella.

The bank was recently put up for sale by parent company NatWest.

webTitle: British Gas to axe standing charges

fields.headline: British Gas to axe standing charges
fields.trailText: British Gas last night stole a march on its main competitors by announcing plans to abolish standing charges for both electricity and gas consumers.
fields.body:
British Gas last night stole a march on its main competitors by announcing plans to abolish standing charges for both electricity and gas consumers.

Standing charges - £51.32 a year for late-payers of gas bills and £26.83 for direct debit customers - were introduced in the 1930s and equate to a cover-charge or meter-rental.

From April British Gas, the trading arm of multi-utility Centrica, will introduce instead a two-tier tariff structure for both its 14.5m gas customers and 2.5m electricity consumers.

The new system, still leaving average British Gas bills higher than those of new suppliers in the liberalised energy market, was hailed by ministers and consumer groups.

Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, said it would benefit many consumers, "especially pensioners who use relatively small amounts of gas and electricity". The abolition of standing charges, he said, "is an excellent way forward to mark the beginning of a new century." Only a few, new, smaller suppliers have so far excluded standing charges.

Ann Robinson, Gas Consumers Council chairman, said: "Bills will be more transparent and consumers will only pay for the energy they use. Low users, for whom the standing charge made up a large part of their bill, will see reduced bills."

British Gas and other suppliers are cutting bills from April when consumers will pay a set unit rate for the first 4500kW hours of energy and a subsequent lower rate.

fields.headline: House prices rise 12.6%
fields.trailText: The London borough of Hackney saw house prices rise 37% in 1999, while the Wirral and Darlington were among areas that saw values fall 10% or more, according to a new survey, writes Rupert Jones .
fields.body:
The London borough of Hackney saw house prices rise 37% in 1999, while the Wirral and Darlington were among areas that saw values fall 10% or more, according to a new survey, writes Rupert Jones .

The cost of the average home rose 12.6% last year, and is expected to notch up growth of 11% in 2000, said Nationwide building society.

London remains the driving force, with prices up by more than 20% in 1999. But Nationwide group economist Alex Bannister said: "We think that this year we will see a more balanced picture, with London probably coming off a bit and price growth rippling out across the rest of the country."

Nine London boroughs saw prices increase by more than 30%, but in the Wirral prices fell by 20%.

webTitle: Brown acts to ban home loan rip-offs

fields.headline: Brown acts to ban home loan rip-offs
fields.trailText: Rip-off mortgage products are to be banned under legislation to be disclosed by chancellor Gordon Brown early next week in a radical change for financial services regulation.
fields.body:
Rip-off mortgage products are to be banned under legislation to be disclosed by chancellor Gordon Brown early next week in a radical change for financial services regulation.

Concern about missold loans, punitive lock-ins and hidden charges has persuaded the chancellor that the financial services authority's approach to regulation of policing salespeople and the sales process is not serving consumers.

He is expected to order the FSA to directly regulate products, using new 'CAT' standards (charges, access and terms) to set benchmarks. Details of the standards will not be released until Wednesday, but are believed to require that:

 variable rate mortgages track the Bank of England's base rate by a fixed percentage amount, possibly no more than 1% over base;

 mortgage interest be calculated every month or every day, rather than the annual basis used by many lenders;

 mortgage holders be able to pay off additional lump sums without penalty and with immediate interest savings;

 fixed and capped rate mortgages should not have early redemption penalties beyond the end of the offer period.

The move will please campaigners, including the Consumers' Association, who have argued that simply policing advisers has failed. But it is expected to horrify financial services companies which claim product regulation stifles innovation. The chancellor will make a private visit to the FSA next Thursday, and is expected to receive a cool reception from the product provider representatives on the FSA board.

Last night the director general of the Council of Mortgage Lenders, Michael Coogan, said: "We urge the government to tell the industry in clear terms whether decisions to intervene in the design of mortgages are in the pipeline."

In a Commons debate on mortgages last night Barry Gardiner, Labour MP for Brent North, said: "I want the products cleaned up. I'm fed up with seeing people ripped off."

webTitle: M&S sales dip as takeover talk increases

fields.headline: M&S sales dip as takeover talk increases
fields.trailText: The ailing Marks & Spencer group yesterday revealed Christmas sales dramatically worse than rival retailers and far removed from the store empire's glory days of just two years ago - but less shocking than many had forecast, writes Julia Finch.
fields.body:
The ailing Marks & Spencer group yesterday revealed Christmas sales dramatically worse than rival retailers and far removed from the store empire's glory days of just two years ago - but less shocking than many had forecast, writes Julia Finch.

In the 15 weeks to January 8 like-for-like sales of clothing, gifts and home furnishings (which exclude the impact of new store space) dipped by 8.8%, although the group's overall reputation was partially rescued by a 1.2% improvement in food sales. Overall, same-store sales were down by 5.3% on 1998.

Chief executive Peter Salsbury, who has now been grappling with Marks' problems for more than a year, described the figures as "clearly not good enough", but the retailer was keen to point out that it is making progress.

Last autumn same-store sales of general goods were down 11.8%, compared to yesterday's 8.8% decline.

Most City analysts remain unimpressed with M&S. Rowan Morgan at Teather & Greenwood said: "There is nothing to suggest the retailer is back on track." Others said the fact that there had not been further deterioration in performance could have eased the pressure on Mr Salsbury, if only for a few months, while his spring ranges are given a chance to perform.

The new ranges will be unveiled on January 24 with a 5% reduction in normal sales prices. A range of new designer collections will also be revealed, along with several new departments, including baby equipment.

The shares, which have been buoyed by takeover speculation, climbed 13.75p to 304.25p with some dealers suggesting a bid could come within days.

fields.headline: Cheap cars blocked
fields.standfirst: Competition inquiry unlikely to support move to cut prices
fields.trailText: The competition commission is set to deliver a savage blow to the hopes of consumers - and ministers - for a steep fall in British car prices this year.
fields.body:
The competition commission is set to deliver a savage blow to the hopes of consumers - and ministers - for a steep fall in British car prices this year.

The commission's long-awaited and much delayed report - due to be handed over to Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, later this month - is expected to conclude that powers to enforce lower prices could seriously damage the car industry.

Ministers, who ordered an inquiry into the gap between UK and European mainland car prices, have already repeatedly fallen out with the inquiry team headed by Denise Kingsmill QC, the commission's deputy chairman.

But well-placed sources said yesterday that the report is likely to prove a huge disappointment for those expecting radical steps to slash thousands of pounds off the price of new, used and leased cars.

Faced with a sharp decline in new year sales, as customers eagerly await the commission's report, dealers are warning that the March number-plate switch to "W" could prove a turkey unless ministers swiftly publish - and act on - the findings before then.

However senior industry sources said the inquiry team has concluded that any further cut in car-makers' margins could seriously damage the industry and ultimately hurt consumers by depressing used-car values.

The commission, insiders disclosed, has discovered that in the five years from 1994-98 the domestic car industry's margins averaged just 2%. Some manufacturers, including notably Rover, remained in negative territory throughout most of the period.

The commission had considered outlawing list prices for new cars but appears to have had second thoughts after being told this would have little or no impact - and advised by the inland revenue that it would dent its yield from company car tax.

Similarly, the inquiry team is said to have considered an early exit from the EU's "block exemption" from normal competition rules, scheduled to be reviewed in 2002, and allowing manufacturers to franchise dealers.

But amid evidence that the team is still gathering information from manufacturers and dealers, even this has proved problematic and has been abandoned as an option.

The report is likely, however, to recommend the "unbundling" of dealers' financial offers from car sales.

Uncertainty about the commission's findings, according to Alan Pulham of the Retail Motor Industry Federation, has effectively "killed" January's sales and could similarly hit March, a boom month for car buying.

It has led consumers to buy cars in mainland Europe or surf the internet for the best deals. Yesterday Reg Vardy, the car dealer group, said it would launch a new website covering its 80 UK showrooms in March to cope with a hoped-for sales rush that month.

Peter Vardy, the group's chairman and chief executive, announcing a 17.9% rise in pre-tax profits for the first half to £14.97m, said the industry needed clarity and a new structure on pricing. "The only cloud over the industry is the price issue," he said.

 Water and sewerage firms yesterday launched a rearguard action against plans to end their local monopolies, claiming that unlicensed operators could soon be supplying unfit water via their pipes. The competition act comes into force on March 1, forcing water firms to allow entrants access to their distribution systems. Ian Byatt, the director general of regulator Ofwat, has said he will impose fines if they impose unfair barriers to rivals.

But Water UK, the umbrella body for the firms, said there was a legal "black hole" that would allow new suppliers to operate without a licence and outside the monitoring regime of the drinking water inspectorate. It said that Mr Byatt should be given specific powers to license newcomers.

fields.headline: Essex boys cool down
fields.standfirst:
Candidate
Camden Falcon, London
***
fields.trailText:
Candidate
Camden Falcon, London
***
fields.body:
If Candidate have a manifesto, it's that light-hearted pop need not eschew intelligence. Take Leader, their current single and a highlight of their crisp, concentrated live set. It has a hook as buoyant as a helium balloon and an inane chorus ("Ba ba baa ba baa" on record, extending exuberantly to "Ba da diddly de da baa ba" live) that lingers naggingly in your head, but marries these to evasive lyrics about a world leader suffering from emperor's new clothes syndrome trying to get in with the avant garde. It's the kind of pop that gives chart fans the itches.

The trouble is, being different doesn't mean you're special, especially when you hail from Essex. Candidate may use the same warm guitars and tinny Casio keyboards as the American bands they admire (Smog, Sparklehorse and possibly Wheat, who they resemble a little), but they lack the mantle of cool that American bands almost automatically acquire. Decked out in battered leather jacket, neat black specs and a troubling hint of goatee, Joel Morris is a dry frontman who veers from sincerity to sarcasm with every utterance, but whose unassuming stance adds to the vague impression that his band are underwhelming.

That doesn't mean they're without merit. There's a clutch of fine songs where Leader came from, many yet to be released. On opener Starving Band, Morris's brother Alex conjures glinting birdsong noises from the bridge of his guitar; his hypnotic melody in the eerie If You Want Your Daughter is at once gentle as drizzle and violent as hailstones. On bass, Ian Painter deftly shifts between lolloping rhythms (on Bird Machine) and a seductive slide sound (Swim Home). Add classic indie-pop drums from Chris White and more odd lyrics and you get a mix that is simple but quirky, absorbing and appealing.

More intriguingly, you also get glimpses of bigger plans. There's the closing lyric to Load it All on Me, "We and only we are right", and the repeated mantra in Bird Machine, "The whole damn world is open wide". Then there's the fact that they limit their snappy, encore-less set to eight strong songs, and that they release all their own records. Hefner did in the early days; they're not "cool" either, but they are great, and perhaps that's what Candidate will be in a couple of years.

fields.headline: TransTec employees lose £700,000 share options
fields.standfirst: Receivers hunt for missing £8m debit notes
fields.trailText: More than 800 workers at the insolvent engineering group TransTec will lose share options with a face value of nearly £700,000 as a result of its collapse, it has emerged. A similar sum - £725,000 - is likely to be lost by an unnamed bank which lent the money to an employee share scheme at TransTec, founded by former Labour treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson
fields.body:
More than 800 workers at the insolvent engineering group TransTec will lose share options with a face value of nearly £700,000 as a result of its collapse, it has emerged. A similar sum - £725,000 - is likely to be lost by an unnamed bank which lent the money to an employee share scheme at TransTec, founded by former Labour treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson

Receivers Arthur Andersen confirmed yesterday that employee shareholders are not normally treated as secured creditors of a failed company. Any investment made by employees will also be lost.

Meanwhile Andersen staff are burrowing into the accounts to discover the fate of "debit notes" issued by Ford for payments of about £8m never explained in TransTec's accounts. Ford - a big client for TransTec's automotive products - claimed about £12m for alleged late deliveries of parts between 1996 and 1998. The £8m was paid back by reducing the cost of parts delivered after 1997. Ford produced a debit note and the price was discounted accordingly.

Somewhere between the TransTec post room and the office responsible for compiling annual reports and accounts for 1997 and 1998, the debit notes ceased to be attached to the proper documentation.

The discovery before Christmas of the concealment of the £12m Ford claim, which ought to have been in the annual report as a liability, triggered the decision by the group's banker HSBC to call in Andersens.

In notes to the 1998 accounts, TransTec declared exceptional costs of £15.8m, of which £14m came from the manufacturing division responsible for the Ford contract.

These costs, said the report, "principally comprise the write-off of foundry development costs and tooling expenditure of £9.3m, redundancy and reorganisation costs of £4m and provisions for vacant leasehold properties of £750,000."

In notes to the 1997 accounts, the group reported exceptional costs for £2.1m for redundancy and reorganisation of production facilities in manufacturing and £987,000 relating to the automotive business.

It is thought Andersens believe some or all of the £8m is somewhere in these exceptional figures for the two years, but one source said the problem with the £8m is that "you can't actually see it ... the whole accounting for it is quite odd".

Earlier this week Mr Robinson reiterated that he knew nothing of accounting irregularities or the Ford claim. He left TransTec after the 1997 election.

Talks are advanced for the sale of TransTec's plastics activities, and the Northern Ireland Office is supporting efforts to find a buyer for the automotive side, with a big plant near Londonderry.

fields.headline: Aged to perfection
fields.standfirst:
Gawain
Royal Opera House, London
****
Performances today, Saturday and Monday. Box office: 0171-304 4000
fields.trailText:
Gawain
Royal Opera House, London
****
Performances today, Saturday and Monday. Box office: 0171-304 4000
fields.body:
The delayed first performance of the Royal Opera's revival of Harrison Birtwistle's Gawain was a case of triumph over adversity. Roughly 20 minutes into the piece - at the point when the awesome pounding on the doors of Camelot heralds the phantasmagoric Green Knight's arrival - a stage manager appeared from the wings, stopped the orchestra and announced that the performance could not continue until a "serious technical problem" had been rectified. The cause of the chaos, it transpires, had nothing to do with the Opera House's controversially tricky computer stage system, but with a defective cable on the trap that heaves the Green Knight into view, a fault that could have occurred anywhere. Even so, a half-hour pause followed before we carried on.

Such an event could have proved disastrous, particularly in a work like Gawain, which is rooted in ritual theatre and relies upon musical and visual repetition for its effect. As it happened, the lost momentum was rapidly regained, and the opera soon re-exerted its powerful, at times insidious, magic.

In some respects Gawain casts its spell despite itself. Its balance of elements is awkward, its subject matter queasy. Engagement with the volatile score is sometimes hampered by the alienating effect of the very rituals on which it depends. In its vision of a universe governed, in the person of Morgan le Fay, by a malign, metaphysical female entity, it steers close to misogyny.

The score, conducted with fierce passion by Elgar Howarth, never lost its grip. Di Trevis's production still impresses with its combination of stark understatement and muted, if imposing special effects, though Alison Chitty's costumes (a mix of medieval Europe, kabuki and native American) have dated. The Green Knight's singing severed head remains a coup de theatre. The ending, in which Morgan le Fay vanishes uttering demonic laughter, while a Stravinskyan woodwing mocks the disconsolate, fallible Gawain, is still one of the most unnerving moments in contemporary music theatre.

John Tomlinson's electrifying Green Knight apart, the cast is new and there are some inequalities: Kathryn Turpin's Lady De Hautdesert is acidically voiced, which sits uneasily with the character's sensuality; Constance Hauman's Morgan, though sung with breathtaking ease and beauty of tone, suggests a skittish sprite rather than spiritual malignancy. On the other hand, Wilhelm Hartmann's Gawain is a touchingly credible innocent throughout, while Thomas Randle, scampering balletically as the Fool, is outstanding. Despite the interruption and my own qualms about the work, I found myself warming to it much more than I did in 1991 when the opera was new - and that is the highest compliment I can pay it.
